('97', 0, 1, 2, 47) 1. HINDUSTANI 1
('97', 0, 2, 3, 63) Shri Kakasaheb Kalelkar writes:
('97', 0, 3, 4, 95) If the Muslims of the Indian Union affirm their loyalty to the Union, will they accept Hindustani as the national language and learn the Urdu and Nagari scripts?
('97', 0, 3, 5, 257) Unless you give your clear opinion on this, the work of the Hindustani Prachar Sabha will become very difficult.
('97', 0, 3, 6, 370) Cannot Maulana Azad give his clear opinion on the subject?
('97', 0, 3, 7, 429) Kakasaheb says nothing new in his letter.
('97', 0, 3, 8, 471) But the subject has acquired added importance at the present juncture.
('97', 0, 3, 9, 542) If the Muslims in India owe loyalty to India and have chosen to make it their home of their own free will, it is their duty to learn the two scripts.
('97', 0, 3, 10, 692) It is said that the Hindus have no place in Pakistan.
('97', 0, 3, 11, 746) So they migrate to the Indian Union.
('97', 0, 3, 12, 783) In the event of a war between the Union and Pakistan, the Muslims of the Indian Union should be prepared to fight against Pakistan.
('97', 0, 3, 13, 915) It is true that there should be no war between the two dominions.
('97', 0, 3, 14, 981) They have to live as friends or die as such.
('97', 0, 3, 15, 1026) The two will have to work in close co operation.
('97', 0, 3, 16, 1075) In spite of being independent of each other, they will have many things in common.
('97', 0, 3, 17, 1158) If they are enemies, they can have nothing in common.
('97', 0, 3, 18, 1212) If there is genuine friendship, the people of both the States can be loyal to both.
('97', 0, 3, 19, 1296) They are both members of the same Commonwealth of nations.
('97', 0, 3, 20, 1355) How can they become enemies of each other?
('97', 0, 3, 21, 1398) But that discussion is unnecessary here.
('97', 0, 3, 22, 1439) The Union must have a common inter provincial speech.
('97', 0, 3, 23, 1493) I will go a step further and say that if the two States are friends, Hindustani should be the common speech between the two.
('97', 0, 3, 24, 1618) This does not mean that Urdu and Hindi will cease to exist as distinct forms of speech.
('97', 0, 3, 25, 1706) They must continue to live and progress.
('97', 0, 3, 26, 1747) But if the Hindus and the Muslims or rather people of all religions in India are friends, they must accept a common language evolved from Hindi and Urdu.
('97', 0, 3, 27, 1901) They should learn the two scripts.
('97', 0, 3, 28, 1936) This will be a test for the Muslims and the Hindus in the Indian Union.
('97', 0, 3, 29, 2008) It would be wrong to say that if the Muslims of the Union refuse to learn the Nagari script, Hindustani cannot become the national language.
('97', 0, 3, 30, 2149) Whether the Muslims learn the Nagari script or not, the Hindus and the people of all other religions ought to learn the two scripts.
('97', 0, 3, 31, 2282) It is possible that in view of the poisoned atmosphere of the
('97', 0, 4, 32, 2344) 1 The Hindi original of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 5 10 1947.
('97', 1, 0, 1, 2411) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 2
('97', 1, 1, 2, 2451) day, people may not appreciate this simple proposition.
('97', 1, 1, 3, 2507) If the Hindus wish to, they can boycott the Urdu script and Urdu words, but they will be the losers thereby.
('97', 1, 1, 4, 2616) Therefore those engaged in Hindustani Prachar should not weaken in their faith or efforts.
('97', 1, 1, 5, 2707) I agree that people like Maulana Azad and other prominent Muslims of the Indian Union should be the first to adopt Hindustani and the two scripts.
('97', 1, 1, 6, 2854) Who will take the lead if not they?
('97', 1, 1, 7, 2890) Difficult times lie ahead of us.
('97', 1, 1, 8, 2923) May God guide us aright.

('97', 1, 2, 10, 2997) 2. LETTER TO NARANDAS GANDHI September 27, 1947
('97', 1, 3, 11, 3045) NARANDAS, One may say you are now approaching old age.
('97', 1, 3, 12, 3100) You certainly have my blessings.
('97', 1, 3, 13, 3133) May you serve the people for many more years.
('97', 1, 3, 14, 3179) When you are too weak to serve I am not going to wish you the same.
('97', 1, 3, 15, 3247) Why should you ever become too weak?
('97', 1, 4, 16, 3284) Blessings from
('97', 1, 5, 17, 3299) BAPU From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.
('97', 1, 5, 18, 3350) Courtesy: Pyarelal
('97', 1, 6, 19, 3369) 3. LETTER TO PREMA KANTAK September 27, 1947
('97', 1, 7, 20, 3414) PREMA, You have lost your father, but if you think calmly, you will realize that you have gained many fathers in place of one.
('97', 1, 7, 21, 3541) All who are our seniors in age or superior to us in knowledge should be as fathers to us or, if they are women, mothers.
('97', 1, 7, 22, 3662) Those who are our equals in age are our brothers and sisters, and our juniors are our sons and daughters.
('97', 1, 7, 23, 3768) Then the world will never die for us.
('97', 1, 7, 24, 3806) Why then do you grieve over the passing away of your father?
('97', 1, 7, 25, 3867) Death, moreover, is man’s true friend.
('97', 1, 7, 26, 3906) Why then should we be unhappy when our dear ones meet their dearest friend?
('97', 1, 7, 27, 3982) When our dear ones leave us, we should engross ourselves in service with still greater devotion.
('97', 1, 7, 28, 4079) Blessings from BAPU
('97', 1, 8, 29, 4099) From a photostat of the Gujarati: G. N. 10456. Also C. W. 6895. Courtesy: Prema Kantak

('97', 2, 2, 3, 4263) [September 27, 1947 ] 1
('97', 2, 3, 4, 4287) BAHI SYED MAHMUD HAD, Your letter has been redirected to me by the Navajivan office.
('97', 2, 3, 5, 4372) It is not necessary to publish it.
('97', 2, 3, 6, 4407) I had said enough about it at Calcutta.
('97', 2, 4, 7, 4447) From the Hindi original: Pyarelal Papers.

('97', 2, 5, 10, 4573) 5. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 2, 6, 11, 4601) NEW DELHI, September 27, 1947
('97', 2, 7, 12, 4631) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Shall I tell you who is my special physician?
('97', 2, 7, 13, 4699) He is good for me and also good for you.
('97', 2, 7, 14, 4740) My physician today, in my thought, speech and action, is Rama, Ishwar, Rahim.
('97', 2, 7, 15, 4818) How can He become our physician?
('97', 2, 7, 16, 4851) We heard a bhajan addressed to the Lord who removes all miseries of mind, body and soul which human beings are subject to.
('97', 2, 7, 17, 4974) Hence I felt that the best, unfailing remedy is Ramanama.
('97', 2, 7, 18, 5032) I can suggest no other remedy to those who come to me.
('97', 2, 7, 19, 5087) Then take some earth and water treatment.
('97', 2, 7, 20, 5129) I know that one who has Ramanama inscribed in his heart needs neither earth nor water for treatment.
('97', 2, 7, 21, 5230) If we are destined to live we shall live.
('97', 2, 7, 22, 5272) If we have to die, let us die.
('97', 2, 7, 23, 5303) No one can ride two horses at the same time.
('97', 2, 7, 24, 5348) If I have faith in Ramanama I must remain firm in that.
('97', 2, 7, 25, 5404) Anyone not doing so will perish.
('97', 2, 7, 26, 5437) Rama is the saviour.
('97', 2, 7, 27, 5458) Does the person who has installed God in his heart ever die?
('97', 2, 7, 28, 5519) This body is transitory.
('97', 2, 7, 29, 5544) It may be living this moment and may die the next.
('97', 2, 7, 30, 5595) How then can I be proud of it?
('97', 2, 7, 31, 5626) It is futile to keep the body alive when the moment of death has arrived.
('97', 2, 7, 32, 5700) Guru Nanak was a great religious leader.
('97', 2, 7, 33, 5741) Other Gurus who came after him did write songs of devotion but they mentioned the name of Nanak in the refrain.
('97', 2, 7, 34, 5853) This is the culture of India.
('97', 2, 7, 35, 5883) Perhaps such things happen in many other countries.
('97', 2, 7, 36, 5935) Whatever that may be, I can only talk of the Indian culture.
('97', 2, 7, 37, 5996) Mirabai was a great devotee.
('97', 2, 7, 38, 6025) Mira’s name is found at the end of countless bhajans.
('97', 2, 7, 39, 6079) It was not she who used her name.
('97', 2, 7, 40, 6113) But Mira’s disciples found great satisfaction in attributing their
('97', 2, 8, 41, 6180) 1 The letter is written on a sheet of paper on which this date is scribbled.
('97', 3, 0, 1, 6257) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 4
('97', 3, 1, 2, 6297) compositions to her.
('97', 3, 1, 3, 6318) This is a wonderful thing.
('97', 3, 1, 4, 6345) It is said that Arjun Dev 1 was a great Guru and a great poet.
('97', 3, 1, 5, 6408) He said: “One may recite Ramanama or Khuda’s praise, one may serve Gosain or Allah”.
('97', 3, 1, 6, 6493) It is remarkable that this thing occurs in the Granth Saheb.
('97', 3, 1, 7, 6554) The allegations against the Sikhs today are, if true, a violation of the teachings of Guru Nanak.
('97', 3, 1, 8, 6652) That is not the way to bring glory to the Granth Saheb.
('97', 3, 1, 9, 6708) Nor can the Sikhs make any progress that way.
('97', 3, 1, 10, 6754) Some Sikh friends had a plain talk with me.
('97', 3, 1, 11, 6798) They told me that Guru Arjun Dev did not doubt the identity of Rama and Rahim or Krishna and Karim.
('97', 3, 1, 12, 6898) Then they told me that whether one went on pilgrimage or haj it meant one and the same thing.
('97', 3, 1, 13, 6992) One may perform puja or bow his head, one may worship God in a temple or bend oneself low in the name of God, one may read the Vedas or the Book.
('97', 3, 1, 14, 7138) The Book meant the Koran.
('97', 3, 1, 15, 7164) One may dress oneself in blue clothes or in white.
('97', 3, 1, 16, 7215) The Muslim wears blue clothes and the orthodox Hindu wears white.
('97', 3, 1, 17, 7281) Then, one may be called a Turk or a Hindu.
('97', 3, 1, 18, 7324) Turks means Muslims.
('97', 3, 1, 19, 7345) [Nanak] says that he who truly follows God’s laws knows His secret.
('97', 3, 1, 20, 7413) If I had the time I would have narrated so many things from the Hindu bhajans and kirtans that you would wonder whether the religious sentiment depicted there belonged to Hinduism or Sikhism.
('97', 3, 1, 21, 7605) why do we say today that the Muslims have got to leave this country?
('97', 3, 1, 22, 7674) Why is it said that the plan of settling the Muslims with the Hindus is a mistake and the fourth blunder of the Congress?
('97', 3, 1, 23, 7796) Whether the Congress implements it or not, it is my plan and if it is a mistake it is my mistake.
('97', 3, 1, 24, 7894) Others come to me and challenge my being a Mahatma and charge me with ruining Hinduism.
('97', 3, 1, 25, 7982) But I tell them that what they call my mistake is not a mistake.
('97', 3, 1, 26, 8047) The real thing is that we are all possessed by a madness today and talk all sorts of things.
('97', 3, 1, 27, 8140) When we get over that madness, we shall talk sense.
('97', 3, 1, 28, 8192) That is why I say that what I am saying cannot be a mistake.
('97', 3, 1, 29, 8253) Those who think I am making a mistake are themselves mistaken.
('97', 3, 1, 30, 8316) The whole world would blame you if you threw out 41 2 crore Muslims.
('97', 3, 1, 31, 8385) Would you then point at what is happening in Pakistan?
('97', 3, 1, 32, 8440) Because Pakistan is not following its religion should I start teaching the Hindus that they should also give up their religion?
('97', 3, 1, 33, 8568) I have never learnt such a thing.
('97', 3, 1, 34, 8602) If we protect our Muslim brethren and remain pure ourselves, it would have its own effect on Pakistan.
('97', 3, 1, 35, 8705) That is my reply to them.
('97', 3, 1, 36, 8731) Today we should consider what a Christian sister whom you know, Rajkumari Amrit Kaur, has to say.
('97', 3, 2, 37, 8829) 1 Fifth Guru of the Sikhs
('97', 4, 0, 1, 8855) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 5
('97', 4, 1, 2, 8902) She is the Health Minister.
('97', 4, 1, 3, 8930) She wishes to help everybody in the refugee camps, whether Hindu or Muslim.
('97', 4, 1, 4, 9006) But what can she do without support from others?
('97', 4, 1, 5, 9055) She cannot be partial.
('97', 4, 1, 6, 9078) She is trying to do her best for everybody.
('97', 4, 1, 7, 9122) She is partly Christian and partly Muslim and also partly Hindu.
('97', 4, 1, 8, 9187) Hence, all religions are the same to her.
('97', 4, 1, 9, 9229) She went there accompanied by some girls.
('97', 4, 1, 10, 9271) They all went there for doing service.
('97', 4, 1, 11, 9310) What was there to fear when they were out to do service?
('97', 4, 1, 12, 9367) But they told me that they were warned against serving the Muslims and were asked to go back if their intention was to serve the Muslims also.
('97', 4, 1, 13, 9510) I laughed when I heard that.
('97', 4, 1, 14, 9539) That merely said these things.
('97', 4, 1, 15, 9570) They were not going to do anything.
('97', 4, 1, 16, 9606) After all, those Muslims and a few Christians are not going to indulge in any rioting.
('97', 4, 1, 17, 9693) How will they do it?
('97', 4, 1, 18, 9714) What do they possess?
('97', 4, 1, 19, 9736) They are in a bad shape.
('97', 4, 1, 20, 9761) What is the point of threatening them?
('97', 4, 1, 21, 9800) Hence I thought I should mention this to you so that we should be on our guard and not indulge in such talk.
('97', 4, 1, 22, 9909) In the end I want to tell you that I had purposely mentioned war.
('97', 4, 1, 23, 9975) But our journalists always like to exaggerate things.
('97', 4, 1, 24, 10029) They have given the headlines that I wanted war.
('97', 4, 1, 25, 10078) There are telegrams coming from Calcutta that Gandhi also talks of war.
('97', 4, 1, 26, 10150) Will there be a war then?
('97', 4, 1, 27, 10176) What I had said was that I could not think of war even in a dream.
('97', 4, 1, 28, 10243) After all, would I give up my creed at a critical time?
('97', 4, 1, 29, 10299) My creed is non violence.
('97', 4, 1, 30, 10325) I have never waged war, nor should anyone else do so.
('97', 4, 1, 31, 10379) How can we achieve anything by fighting?
('97', 4, 1, 32, 10420) What I said was that if Pakistan was committing mistakes or if India was committing mistakes, with both the countries having their own independent Governments, how was it possible for one Government to secure justice from the other?
('97', 4, 1, 33, 10653) It would be different if the two Governments worked in co operation.
('97', 4, 1, 34, 10722) Let them have an arbitrator if they cannot work together.
('97', 4, 1, 35, 10780) If even that cannot be done, then we shall helplessly be dragged into war.
('97', 4, 1, 36, 10855) Does this imply advocating war?
('97', 4, 1, 37, 10887) I want to tell both India and Pakistan that they must come to a mutual settlement or accept an arbitrator.
('97', 4, 1, 38, 10994) But if the Pakistanis insist on taking India by force, then, as I said yesterday, India would have no alternative except to fight.
('97', 4, 1, 39, 11125) If I am given the charge of the Government I would follow a different path, because I have no military and police force under me.
('97', 4, 1, 40, 11255) But I am the only one to follow that path.
('97', 4, 1, 41, 11298) Who would support me?
('97', 4, 1, 42, 11320) Your Government will do what is expected of it when the time comes.
('97', 4, 1, 43, 11388) I would continue to chant only one refrain.
('97', 4, 1, 44, 11432) But, if people do not understand non violence, to whom can I address myself?

('97', 5, 1, 2, 11589) 6. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 5, 2, 3, 11617) NEW DELHI, September 28, 1947
('97', 5, 3, 4, 11647) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 5, 4, 5, 11669) Is there anybody in the meeting who is against the recitation from the Koran?
('97', 5, 5, 6, 11747) I shall respect your opposition, though I know that the rest of the people would be disappointed that the prayers will not take place.
('97', 5, 6, 7, 11882) With my unflinching faith in non violence, I can do nothing else.
('97', 5, 6, 8, 11948) Even so I cannot help saying that you should not disregard the opinion of such a big majority which does not agree with you.
('97', 5, 6, 9, 12073) From that point of view your behaviour is improper.
('97', 5, 6, 10, 12125) From what I am going to say later you must realize that the intolerance that you have shown under somebody’s instigation is the evidence of petulance and anger prevalent all over the country today, which has provoked Mr. Churchill to say many bitter things about India.
('97', 5, 6, 11, 12395) Let me explain to you in Hindustani Mr. Churchill’s speech a summary of which has been sent by Reuter and published in the newspapers this morning: 3
('97', 5, 7, 12, 12545) The fearful massacres which are occurring in India are no surprise to me.
('97', 5, 7, 13, 12619) We are, of course, only at the beginning of these horrors and butcheries, perpetrated upon one another, with the ferocity of cannibals, by the races gifted with capacities for the highest culture, and who had for generations dwelt, side by side, in general peace, under the broad, tolerant and impartial rule of the British Crown and Parliament.
('97', 5, 7, 14, 12965) I cannot but doubt, that the future will witness a vast abridgment of the population throughout what has for sixty or seventy years been the most peaceful part of the world and that, at the same time, will come a retrogression of civilization throughout these enormons regions, constituting one of the most melancholy tragedies which Asia has ever known.
('97', 5, 7, 15, 13320) You are all aware that Mr. Churchill is a great man.
('97', 5, 7, 16, 13373) He belongs

('97', 5, 8, 18, 13418) 2 The Hindustan Times, 29 9 1947, reports that the prayer was however held after the speech “inside Gandhiji’s room with only members of his party”.
('97', 5, 8, 19, 13567) 3 The paragraph from Winston Churchill’s speech of September 27, is reproduced from Mahatma.
('97', 6, 0, 1, 13660) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 7
('97', 6, 1, 2, 13707) to the blue blood of England.
('97', 6, 1, 3, 13737) Marlborough family is very famous in British history.
('97', 6, 1, 4, 13791) Mr. Churchill took the helm when Great Britain was in great danger after the Second World War started.
('97', 6, 1, 5, 13894) No doubt he saved the British Empire from a great danger at the time.
('97', 6, 1, 6, 13964) It would be wrong to argue that Great Britain could not have won without the help of the United States or other Allied nations.
('97', 6, 1, 7, 14092) Who else except a man of Mr. Churchill’s sharp political diplomacy could have brought all the friendly nations together?
('97', 6, 1, 8, 14213) Great Britain acknowledged the services of Mr. Churchill who in those days preserved the honour of that country.
('97', 6, 1, 9, 14326) But after winning the War the nation did not hesitate to choose the Labour Government in order to recover from the terrible loss of life and property which the British Isles had undergone during the War.
('97', 6, 1, 10, 14530) The British people saw the signs of the times and decided in favour of voluntary abdication from power to end the Empire and establishing instead the imperceptible rule of hearts.
('97', 6, 1, 11, 14710) India has been divided and then both the countries have voluntarily announced their decision to join the British Commonwealth.
('97', 6, 1, 12, 14837) The honourable step of granting independence to India was taken by all the parties representing the entire British nation.
('97', 6, 1, 13, 14960) Mr. Churchill and his party were also in line with others.
('97', 6, 1, 14, 15019) It may be a different thing that the future may or may not justify this step of the British people.
('97', 6, 1, 15, 15119) And this had nothing to do with my suggestion that because Mr. Churchill has been a party to the transfer of power, he is expected not to say or do anything which would deprive this measure of its value.
('97', 6, 1, 16, 15323) There is no doubt that in modern history there is no instance which can be compared with the transfer of power by the British.
('97', 6, 1, 17, 15450) I am reminded of the sacrifice of Priyadarshi Ashoka.
('97', 6, 1, 18, 15504) But Ashoka is incomparable and, moreover, he does not belong to modern history.
('97', 6, 1, 19, 15584) That is why I was pained to read the Reuter’s despatch of Mr. Churchill’s speech.
('97', 6, 1, 20, 15666) I take it for granted that this renowned news agency has not misreported Mr. Churchill’s speech.
('97', 6, 1, 21, 15763) By his speech Mr. Churchill has harmed his country which he has greatly served.
('97', 6, 1, 22, 15843) If he knew that India would be reduced to such a terrible state after freeing itself from the rule of the British Empire, did he, for a moment take the trouble of thinking that the entire responsibility for it lies with the builders of the British Empire and not with those “races” which, in Mr. Churchill’s opinion, are capable of giving birth to the greatest civilization?
('97', 6, 1, 23, 16218) In my view, Mr. Churchill has been too hasty in his sweeping generalization.
('97', 6, 1, 24, 16295) India’s population is several millions.
('97', 6, 1, 25, 16335) Out of these a few lakhs have taken to the path of barbarism.
('97', 6, 1, 26, 16397) But these people hardly count.
('97', 6, 1, 27, 16428) With confidence I invite
('97', 7, 0, 1, 16453) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 8
('97', 7, 1, 2, 16493) Mr. Churchill to come to India and study the situation himself.
('97', 7, 1, 3, 16557) But he must come not as a representative of his Party with fixed opinions, but as an impartial Englishman who values the prestige of his country more than any Party’s and intends to help the British Government in making this task a grand success.
('97', 7, 1, 4, 16804) This unique step of Great Britain would be judged from its consequences.
('97', 7, 1, 5, 16877) The vivisection of India unwittingly invited the two parts of the country to fight each other.
('97', 7, 1, 6, 16972) Granting freedom separately to the two parts seems like a blot on the graceful gift of freedom.
('97', 7, 1, 7, 17068) It is no use saying that either side is free to come out of the British Commonwealth.
('97', 7, 1, 8, 17154) This is easier said than done.
('97', 7, 1, 9, 17185) I do not wish to say anything more on that account.
('97', 7, 1, 10, 17237) What I have said is enough to show why Mr. Churchill should have been more careful while speaking on this subject.
('97', 7, 1, 11, 17352) He has run down his colleagues without even studying the situation.
('97', 7, 1, 12, 17420) Many of you have given ground to Mr. Churchill for making such remarks.
('97', 7, 1, 13, 17492) You still have sufficient time to reform your ways and prove Mr. Churchill’s prediction wrong.
('97', 7, 1, 14, 17587) I know nobody listens to me these days.
('97', 7, 1, 15, 17627) Had it not been so, and had the people continued to listen to me as they did before the negotiations for freedom started, there never would have been that show of barbarism which Mr. Churchill has described with such relish and gross exaggeration.
('97', 7, 1, 16, 17875) And also you would have been well on the way to solving your economic and other domestic problems.

('97', 8, 8, 13, 18451) I also enclose Pattani’s 2 wire.

('97', 8, 8, 16, 18561) I am under the impression that whatever Shamaldas does is done with the Sardar’s consent.
('97', 8, 8, 17, 18651) 3 Please ask the Sardar what reply I should send and let me know.

('97', 9, 2, 3, 19104) DEAR SIR HARISINGH 1, Many thanks for your letter.
('97', 9, 2, 4, 19155) I see that you can be carried away by your ideas.
('97', 9, 2, 5, 19205) But I cannot understand why you should disregard facts.
('97', 9, 2, 6, 19261) No one has displaced English from the great role belonging to it as an international medium.
('97', 9, 2, 7, 19354) No Indian to my knowledge has ever desired to banish English from India as a second language for study.
('97', 9, 2, 8, 19458) But some of us have undoubtedly desired to dethrone it from the place it has usurped.
('97', 9, 2, 9, 19544) Again what a fund of misinformation in your note, a copy of which you have been good enough to send me.
('97', 9, 2, 10, 19648) But I have neither time nor inclination to enter into a discussion with you.
('97', 9, 2, 11, 19725) Time will determine the issue.
('97', 9, 3, 12, 19756) Yours sincerely,

('97', 11, 11, 29, 23795) 13. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 11, 12, 30, 23824) NEW DELHI, September 29, 1947 My reference to the possibility of a war between the two sister Dominions seems, I am told, to have produced a scare in the West.
('97', 11, 12, 31, 23984) I do not know what reports were sent out by newspaper correspondents.
('97', 11, 12, 32, 24054) Summaries are always a dangerous enterprise except when they truly
('97', 11, 13, 33, 24121) 1 Minister, Medical and Public Health, Central Provinces 2 Ravi Shankar Shukla, Chief Minister, Central Provinces
('97', 12, 0, 1, 24235) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 13
('97', 12, 1, 2, 24283) reflect the speaker’s opinion.
('97', 12, 1, 3, 24314) An unwarranted summary of a pamphlet 1 I had written about South Africa in 1896 nearly cost me my life.
('97', 12, 1, 4, 24418) It was so hopelessly unwarranted that within twenty four hours of my being lynched, European opinion in South Africa was turned from anger into contrition that an innocent man was made to suffer for no fault that he had committed.
('97', 12, 1, 5, 24649) The moral I wish to draw from the foregoing version is that no one should be held responsible for what he has not said or done.
('97', 12, 1, 6, 24777) I hold that not a single mention of war in my speeches can be interpreted to mean that there was any incitement to or approval of war between Pakistan and the Union unless mere mention of it is to be taboo.
('97', 12, 1, 7, 24984) We have among us the superstition that the mere mention of a snake ensures its appearance in the house in which the mention is made even by a child.
('97', 12, 1, 8, 25133) I hope no one in India entertains such superstition about war.
('97', 12, 1, 9, 25196) I claim that I rendered a service to both the sister States by examining the present situation and definitely stating when the cause of war could arise between the two States.
('97', 12, 1, 10, 25372) This was done not to promote war but to avoid it as far as possible.
('97', 12, 1, 11, 25441) I endeavoured, too, to show that if the insensate murders, loot and arson by people continued, they would force the hands of their Governments.
('97', 12, 1, 12, 25585) Was it wrong to draw public attention to the logical steps that inevitably followed one after another?
('97', 12, 1, 13, 25688) India knows, the world should, that every ounce of my energy has been and is being devoted to the definite avoidance of fratricide culminating in war.
('97', 12, 1, 14, 25839) When a man vowed to non violence as the law governing human beings dares to refer to war, he can only do it so as to strain every nerve to avoid it.
('97', 12, 1, 15, 25988) Such is my fundamental position from which I hope never to swerve even to my dying day.
('97', 12, 2, 16, 26076) Harijan, 12 10 1947
('97', 12, 3, 17, 26096) 1Green Pamphlet; vide “The Grievances of the British Indians in South Africa: An Appeal to the Indian Public”, 14 8 1896.

('97', 13, 1, 2, 26259) 14. NOTE TO JAWAHARLAL NEHRU
('97', 13, 2, 3, 26288) [September 29, 1947] 1
('97', 13, 3, 4, 26311) So far as the war is concerned my speeches have been quite clear.
('97', 13, 3, 5, 26377) The summaries sent to America and elsewhere may be quite the contrary of what I might have said.
('97', 13, 3, 6, 26474) I shall deal with the question more fully in my written speech today.
('97', 13, 3, 7, 26544) As to the deteriorating situation I have told you quite firmly that you should dispense with Sardar, or he you.
('97', 13, 3, 8, 26656) He won’t shoulder the burden without you, hence you should take it up and reform the Cabinet with one mind.
('97', 13, 3, 9, 26764) Rajen Babu should give up food portfolio.
('97', 13, 3, 10, 26806) He will do so gladly.
('97', 13, 3, 11, 26828) I have always looked upon the wholesale accessions of States with suspicion.
('97', 13, 3, 12, 26905) They are probably a liability rather than an asset.
('97', 13, 3, 13, 26957) This sums up my reaction.
('97', 13, 3, 14, 26983) We may discuss these things more fully when I can speak.

('97', 14, 1, 2, 27654) 16. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 14, 2, 3, 27683) NEW DELHI, September 30, 1947
('97', 14, 3, 4, 27713) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 14, 4, 5, 27735) It seems to me that we have all become savages.
('97', 14, 4, 6, 27783) Both Hindus and Muslims have turned savage.
('97', 14, 4, 7, 27827) Who can determine who has committed more crimes and who has committed less?
('97', 14, 4, 8, 27903) We cannot go into these details.
('97', 14, 4, 9, 27936) The Government should try to recall the refugees from Pakistan, which can be done only in consultation with the Government there.
('97', 14, 4, 10, 28066) There are so many complications.
('97', 14, 4, 11, 28099) The Government is there to solve those complications.
('97', 14, 4, 12, 28153) The Government should look after its people or resign.
('97', 14, 4, 13, 28208) I have no doubt at all about it.
('97', 14, 4, 14, 28241) Today our Government is something which we can strengthen or bring down.
('97', 14, 4, 15, 28314) That is democracy.
('97', 14, 4, 16, 28333) People themselves should remain under control and exercise restraint.
('97', 14, 4, 17, 28403) They must know the meaning of discipline and observe it.
('97', 14, 4, 18, 28460) If they do not do this, they become worthless.
('97', 14, 4, 19, 28507) We must learn this thing if we want to stick to our duty.
('97', 14, 4, 20, 28565) We must inculcate this in our children from the time they start showing some understanding.
('97', 14, 4, 21, 28657) You must tell your children that the place of religion is in their hearts and it is not in your power to protect it.
('97', 14, 4, 22, 28774) You must tell them that you are their father and as their father you have to give them that training.
('97', 14, 4, 23, 28876) I have taught my children that they must protect their own religion.
('97', 14, 4, 24, 28945) One of my sons 1 is in South Africa.
('97', 14, 4, 25, 28982) Another 2 is drinking away somewhere.
('97', 14, 4, 26, 29020) I do not even know his whereabouts.
('97', 14, 4, 27, 29056) One son 3 is at Nagpur eking out his living with great difficulty.
('97', 14, 4, 28, 29123) One son 4 is here.
('97', 14, 4, 29, 29142) I cannot say that he is earning his livelihood with difficulty.
('97', 14, 4, 30, 29206) Shall I keep worrying about the religion of each one of them?
('97', 14, 4, 31, 29268) I am not worrying.
('97', 14, 4, 32, 29287) why should I?
('97', 14, 4, 33, 29301) They are all grown up.
('97', 14, 4, 34, 29324) I could protect their religion if they were young.
('97', 14, 4, 35, 29375) And that too in what manner?
('97', 14, 4, 36, 29404) I would tell them that if they were true Hindus they must have the courage to die for their religion, they could not save it by killing.
('97', 14, 4, 37, 29541) Now suppose one boy is having a lathi and another a revolver.
('97', 14, 4, 38, 29603) The boy having the revolver would kill the boy with the
('97', 14, 5, 39, 29659) 1 Manilal Gandhi 2 Harilal Gandhi 3 Ramdas Gandhi 4 Devdas Gandhi
('97', 15, 0, 1, 29725) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 16
('97', 15, 1, 2, 29766) But that is not the way to save religion.
('97', 15, 1, 3, 29808) As the boy with the lathi is killed his relatives appear.
('97', 15, 1, 4, 29866) The boy with the revolver being alone brings his revolver, or a brengun or a stengun.
('97', 15, 1, 5, 29952) And the people on the opposite side would bring ten stenguns.
('97', 15, 1, 6, 30014) They would force him to embrace Islam or Christianity and threaten him with their numbers and warn him that his weapons would not save him.
('97', 15, 1, 7, 30154) And then, although frightened, he would cry out that despite the compulsion he would still consider his religion dearer to him than his life.
('97', 15, 1, 8, 30296) Following any religion means belonging to God.
('97', 15, 1, 9, 30343) The same thing happened in the case of Prahlad.
('97', 15, 1, 10, 30391) He used to repeat the name of Rama.
('97', 15, 1, 11, 30427) His father said he should stop it, but Prahlad replied that he could utter no other name.
('97', 15, 1, 12, 30517) There is a beautiful bhajan about it: Prahlad writes the name of Rama while his guru is dictating another name.
('97', 15, 1, 13, 30629) He says that he can write no other name and he knows no other name.
('97', 15, 1, 14, 30697) It is a very sweet bhajan.
('97', 15, 1, 15, 30724) Prahlad says that his pen can shape no other name.
('97', 15, 1, 16, 30775) It is said that Prahlad was a mere boy of twelve.
('97', 15, 1, 17, 30825) Well, that twelve year old boy opposed his father and saved his religion.
('97', 15, 1, 18, 30899) I need not describe how he protected his religion.
('97', 15, 1, 19, 30950) All Hindus are familiar with the story.
('97', 15, 1, 20, 30990) But the important thing is that he could protect his religion all by himself.
('97', 15, 1, 21, 31068) Innumerable instances of this kind can be found in all religions.
('97', 15, 1, 22, 31134) Now we have our boys and girls.
('97', 15, 1, 23, 31166) If one believes that woman is weak, I would say that no woman in the world is weak.
('97', 15, 1, 24, 31250) All are strong.
('97', 15, 1, 25, 31266) All those who have firm faith in their religion are strong, not weak.
('97', 15, 1, 26, 31336) So I would suggest that we should first teach our boys and girls that they are not weak.
('97', 15, 1, 27, 31425) Children have their religion to strengthen them.
('97', 15, 1, 28, 31474) When people come to me I tell them that the Government should do everything in its power.
('97', 15, 1, 29, 31564) But it would be wrong to think that unless the Government did something everybody would be converted to Islam.
('97', 15, 1, 30, 31675) Millions of Muslims are living in India today.
('97', 15, 1, 31, 31722) It should be carefully considered who they are.
('97', 15, 1, 32, 31770) Not many of them have come from Arabia.
('97', 15, 1, 33, 31810) Those who came from Arabia did not constitute the millions.
('97', 15, 1, 34, 31870) Those millions who became Muslims were all Hindus.
('97', 15, 1, 35, 31921) Or, say, they were Buddhists.
('97', 15, 1, 36, 31951) What is the difference between Buddhists and Hindus?
('97', 15, 1, 37, 32004) In my view there is no difference.
('97', 15, 1, 38, 32039) Should we not have proper knowledge as to who inhabited Afghanistan?
('97', 15, 1, 39, 32108) Badshah Khan told me that the Afghans were originally Buddhists and later embraced Islam.
('97', 15, 1, 40, 32198) But, for that matter, have they forgotten their ancient culture?
('97', 15, 1, 41, 32263) How could they forget?
('97', 15, 1, 42, 32286) He told me that even the names of their villages were orginally in Sanskrit.
('97', 15, 1, 43, 32363) They have changed their names, dress and everything else; but they could not change what was
('97', 16, 0, 1, 32456) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 17
('97', 16, 1, 2, 32504) lying deep within.
('97', 16, 1, 3, 32523) How could they forget it?
('97', 16, 1, 4, 32549) And then, whether in Madras or Bengal or anywhere else, they were all Hindus.
('97', 16, 1, 5, 32627) You ask them as I ask myself, why they chose to embrace Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 6, 32690) I am to be blamed for their conversion to Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 7, 32739) I must do penance; you must, too.
('97', 16, 1, 8, 32773) Of course, if they have done the correct thing and accepted a religion which is nobler than Hinduism, then let us follow in their footsteps, recite the Kalma, swear by Islam and raise the cry for the victory of Islam!
('97', 16, 1, 9, 32991) But nothing like that happened.
('97', 16, 1, 10, 33023) Whom then shall we beat up and whom shall we drive out?
('97', 16, 1, 11, 33079) They are our own people.
('97', 16, 1, 12, 33104) They were all Hindus at the time of our grandfathers and great grandfathers, say, four generations ago, and got converted to Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 13, 33236) I have gone round all over the country and reminded the Hindus of their wickedness in considering untouchability part of their religion.
('97', 16, 1, 14, 33373) What has been the result?
('97', 16, 1, 15, 33399) One part of our community has become the fifth varna.
('97', 16, 1, 16, 33453) Originally there were four varnas and we made them five and considered the fifth varna as Ati Shudras.
('97', 16, 1, 17, 33556) We kept the fifth varna segregated from us.
('97', 16, 1, 18, 33600) We kept their food separate and declared that they could not live in our midst.
('97', 16, 1, 19, 33680) We decided to treat them as our slaves.
('97', 16, 1, 20, 33720) Later they turned to Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 21, 33748) So all of them were not originally Muslims.
('97', 16, 1, 22, 33792) Later on some Brahmins also were converted to Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 23, 33845) Quite a few of them also came from among Kshatriyas as also Vaishyas.
('97', 16, 1, 24, 33915) But their number was very small.
('97', 16, 1, 25, 33948) I have shown you how the present crores of Muslims had embraced Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 26, 34019) Untouchability drove them to Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 27, 34055) Today we are creating such uproar in India and want to beat up and harass the Muslims and drive them out of the country by any means.
('97', 16, 1, 28, 34189) No one ever bothers to think from where they should be driven out and where they should be pushed out.
('97', 16, 1, 29, 34292) We must realize that when someone is attacked and forced into accepting Islam, afterwards he is doomed for no fault of his.
('97', 16, 1, 30, 34416) But I move about among Muslims and my Muslim friends tell me that Islam has never advocated forcible conversion.
('97', 16, 1, 31, 34529) People may accept it voluntarily.
('97', 16, 1, 32, 34563) They may be made aware of the greatness of Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 33, 34613) But they cannot be brought to accept Islam by cheating or by paying money.
('97', 16, 1, 34, 34688) The Muslims in this country are all our blood brothers.
('97', 16, 1, 35, 34744) That is why I say that we must act only after careful thought.
('97', 16, 1, 36, 34807) We must consider why they were drawn to Islam.
('97', 16, 1, 37, 34854) Did they accept Islam for money?
('97', 16, 1, 38, 34887) Even if you want to earn money or do anything else, go anywhere in the world, you take your religion with you.
('97', 16, 1, 39, 34998) If you discard religion, you have discarded everything.
('97', 16, 1, 40, 35054) I want to tell you only one thing and it is that we should not try to kill any Muslim.
('97', 16, 1, 41, 35141) Let them kill if they want.
('97', 16, 1, 42, 35169) If they kill that
('97', 17, 0, 1, 35187) THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI 18
('97', 17, 1, 2, 35228) is bad.
('97', 17, 1, 3, 35236) We would consider them bad.
('97', 17, 1, 4, 35264) But if they are bad, why should we be bad in return?
('97', 17, 1, 5, 35317) We can return their wickedness with goodness.
('97', 17, 1, 6, 35363) If they drink liquor, should we also do the same?
('97', 17, 1, 7, 35413) I would call upon all Muslims, Hindus and Sikhs to come to their senses and see what religion teaches.
('97', 17, 1, 8, 35516) As Iqbal said, “religion does not teach mutual hatred”.
('97', 17, 1, 9, 35572) When Iqbal said this he was in London.
('97', 17, 1, 10, 35611) He was a great poet.
('97', 17, 1, 11, 35632) He had come to attend the Round Table Conference.
('97', 17, 1, 12, 35682) I was invited to a dinner arranged in his honour.
('97', 17, 1, 13, 35732) I went for the dinner.
('97', 17, 1, 14, 35755) He said that he was a Brahmin?
('97', 17, 1, 15, 35786) Why was he a Brahmin?
('97', 17, 1, 16, 35808) Because his forefathers were Brahmins.
('97', 17, 1, 17, 35847) Where did they live?
('97', 17, 1, 18, 35868) In Kashmir.
('97', 17, 1, 19, 35880) He said he belonged to Kashmir and was a Brahmin who was converted to Islam.
('97', 17, 1, 20, 35957) They were all converted to Islam not recently but long ago.
('97', 17, 1, 21, 36017) But they had Brahmin blood and Islamic culture in them.
('97', 17, 1, 22, 36073) So Iqbal said that religion did not teach us to hate one another.

('97', 21, 6, 12, 42338) 24. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 21, 7, 13, 42367) NEW DELHI, October 1, 1947
('97', 21, 8, 14, 42394) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, A lady writes to me in a letter that she is desirous of doing service and her husband also wishes to do the same, but no one shows them the way.
('97', 21, 8, 15, 42561) There are many people who pose such questions.
('97', 21, 8, 16, 42608) I have given only one reply to all of them and it is that the scope for Government jobs is very limited whereas the scope for service is immense.
('97', 21, 8, 17, 42754) Hence there is no need to ask anyone what should be done.
('97', 21, 8, 18, 42812) Anyone who wishes to serve can do so.
('97', 21, 8, 19, 42850) But we have become so helpless that we have to consult others.
('97', 21, 8, 20, 42913) Shall I then tell you what they should do?
('97', 21, 8, 21, 42956) After all, how much reputation does Delhi enjoy for being clean city?
('97', 21, 8, 22, 43026) There are so many camps here, and I know how clean they are.
('97', 21, 8, 23, 43087) People fall ill while they are there.
('97', 21, 8, 24, 43125) It is equally filthy where there has been bloodshed and destruction of property.
('97', 21, 8, 25, 43206) The Delhi Municipality has never been known for cleanliness.
('97', 21, 8, 26, 43267) Had Delhi been a clean city the hearts of the people would have been clean too.
('97', 21, 8, 27, 43347) Wherever we may be, if we keep our places clean, it will have its impact on the whole city.
('97', 21, 8, 28, 43439) Let every man keep his own house, his own heart clean.
('97', 21, 8, 29, 43494) I will tell that lady that if she is really keen to do service, not in name but in the true spirit of devotion, then there is ample
('97', 21, 9, 30, 43626) 1 The letter is placed in the source among those of this date.
('97', 22, 0, 1, 43689) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 23
('97', 22, 1, 2, 43737) scope for service in Delhi.
('97', 22, 1, 3, 43765) She need not inform me anything about her work either.
('97', 22, 1, 4, 43820) If she can work to clean the hearts of the people of Delhi, clean the hearts of all refugees here, then she will have done a great thing, and then, she and her husband will become an ideal couple.
('97', 22, 1, 5, 44017) Others will start following their example.
('97', 22, 1, 6, 44060) I have just received two telegrams.
('97', 22, 1, 7, 44096) One of the telegrams which is from a Muslim friend states that Indians used to be considered very sensible and that Hindus and Muslims were supposed to be living in amity.
('97', 22, 1, 8, 44268) But now what has gone wrong that they cannot sit together and are fighting with each other, indulging in mutual killing and behaving as savages?
('97', 22, 1, 9, 44413) Let us take the example of Delhi.
('97', 22, 1, 10, 44447) The Hindus and Sikhs of Delhi are willing to accept the Muslims in their fold provided they declare their loyalty to the Indian Union.
('97', 22, 1, 11, 44582) Those who wish to remain in the Indian Union, whether it is I or you or anybody else, have got to abide by this.
('97', 22, 1, 12, 44695) This condition is applicable not only to the Muslims but to everybody.
('97', 22, 1, 13, 44766) Then, the Muslims possess plenty of arms.
('97', 22, 1, 14, 44808) Quite a large stock of these arms has been recovered.
('97', 22, 1, 15, 44862) But not all arms have yet been surrendered.
('97', 22, 1, 16, 44906) Searches are going on with the help of the police.
('97', 22, 1, 17, 44957) But everything cannot come out with the help of the police.
('97', 22, 1, 18, 45017) So, if they are honest at heart and do not wish to fight against India, they should be loyal to the Union.
('97', 22, 1, 19, 45124) They should even fight any Muslim power attacking India.
('97', 22, 1, 20, 45181) And if they do not wish to fight against India, why do they need the arms?
('97', 22, 1, 21, 45256) There are very few Christians here, but they too would have to fight on behalf of the Union in the event of a war with another country like Germany or any other Christian country and will have to remain loyal to the country.
('97', 22, 1, 22, 45481) If the Muslims are loyal and they have no intention of fighting against India, why do they need the arms?
('97', 22, 1, 23, 45587) They must voluntarily surrender their arms.
('97', 22, 1, 24, 45631) This is all very well.
('97', 22, 1, 25, 45654) But the way this was said contained poison.
('97', 22, 1, 26, 45698) Today there are nearly 50,000 Muslims in the camps.
('97', 22, 1, 27, 45750) We have driven them out of Delhi.
('97', 22, 1, 28, 45784) Some have been killed.
('97', 22, 1, 29, 45807) However brave a person may be, he does not welcome death.
('97', 22, 1, 30, 45865) Somebody may want to do business or something else.
('97', 22, 1, 31, 45917) He takes comfort in the fact that he will at least be alive.
('97', 22, 1, 32, 45978) Where could they go after running away?
('97', 22, 1, 33, 46018) So they have taken shelter in the Purana Quila, and on the grounds near Humayun’s tomb.
('97', 22, 1, 34, 46106) They get wet in the rain and have to face a lot of hardship.
('97', 22, 1, 35, 46167) The are not able to have proper medical aid also.
('97', 22, 1, 36, 46217) Dr. Sushila Nayyar gives me the report of their condition.
('97', 22, 1, 37, 46276) She gives them four hours every day.
('97', 22, 1, 38, 46313) There are many pregnant women among the refugees.
('97', 22, 1, 39, 46363) Those women have to be delivered, for which some nurses are required.
('97', 22, 1, 40, 46433) Also some
('97', 23, 0, 1, 46443) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 23, 1, 2, 46484) medicines and many other things are needed.
('97', 23, 1, 3, 46528) All these things take time to arrange.
('97', 23, 1, 4, 46567) Why are those people living in such a condition?
('97', 23, 1, 5, 46616) The Hindus say they have driven them out and they have done nothing wrong in doing that.
('97', 23, 1, 6, 46705) They say that they can be brought back provided they become loyal to the country.
('97', 23, 1, 7, 46787) I say that they can be brought back only when their hearts become clean.
('97', 23, 1, 8, 46860) Granting that the Muslims are not loyal to the country and they refuse to surrender arms, does it mean that they should be slaughtered?

('97', 23, 1, 10, 47043) Out of these, suppose one lakh or even one crore have hidden arms in their houses.
('97', 23, 1, 11, 47126) Is your army, your police, not powerful enough to unearth those arms from their houses?
('97', 23, 1, 12, 47214) The police does not belong to the British nowadays.
('97', 23, 1, 13, 47266) You must realize what would be the outcome of slaughtering the Muslims, killing their children and their women.

('97', 23, 1, 16, 47509) For a few days after that we all lived like brothers.
('97', 23, 1, 17, 47563) Everything seemed well at that moment.
('97', 23, 1, 18, 47602) But today we have forgotten that we are brothers.
('97', 23, 1, 19, 47652) If they are killing us, the blame lies with the Muslim League.
('97', 23, 1, 20, 47715) There was anger at heart.
('97', 23, 1, 21, 47741) But in the glow of independence we forgot that they were our enemies at one time.
('97', 23, 1, 22, 47823) I witnessed this in Calcutta.
('97', 23, 1, 23, 47853) That was the condition all over the country.
('97', 23, 1, 24, 47898) But that spirit disappeared later and they were ready to slaughter the Hindus and the Sikhs and drive them away.
('97', 23, 1, 25, 48011) I have already said that along with those two conditions if we add one more condition, we can carry on our work in peace.
('97', 23, 1, 26, 48133) That condition is that we shall not take the law into our hands.
('97', 23, 1, 27, 48198) It is not up to us to punish them.
('97', 23, 1, 28, 48233) We admit that we had lost our senses.
('97', 23, 1, 29, 48271) I agree that the Muslim League was the first to be unreasonable.
('97', 23, 1, 30, 48336) As I have already said, let us show goodness in a greater measure than they do.
('97', 23, 1, 31, 48416) But if we try to compete with them in wickedness, it would bring about our downfall as well as theirs.
('97', 23, 1, 32, 48519) If they are doing wrong things our Government will set it right.
('97', 23, 1, 33, 48584) If any of our people are in Pakistan, whether Hindus, Sikhs or Christians, who are in a minority over there and are not well protected, if they are slaughtered and their daughters are kidnapped, if they are being deprived of their property or forcibly converted to Islam, our Government will take up the matter with Pakistan.
('97', 23, 1, 34, 48910) Who are we to retaliate?
('97', 23, 1, 35, 48935) I begin to think that there are some amongst us who are really murderers.
('97', 23, 1, 36, 49009) I do not quite know who they are, but they are definitely there, and are working to carry out pre planned murders, arson and forcible occupation of buildings.
('97', 23, 1, 37, 49168) I do not
('97', 24, 0, 1, 49177) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 25

('97', 25, 4, 19, 52874) 25. DISCUSSION WITH DOCTORS [October 2, 1947] 1
('97', 25, 5, 20, 52922) Doctors pressed him to take penicillin but Gandhiji refused.
('97', 25, 5, 21, 52983) 2 Ramanama was his penicillin, he said.
('97', 25, 5, 22, 53023) He would rather fall a martyr to his researches in the science of Ramanama than a casualty to theirs.
('97', 25, 5, 23, 53125) The doctors argued: Science had definitely established that there are specific causes for specific ailments.
('97', 25, 5, 24, 53234) You eradicate the cause and the disease goes.
('97', 25, 5, 25, 53280) On the other hand, anyone can be given cholera by introducing cholera germs into his system.
('97', 25, 5, 26, 53373) The laws of science are inviolable.
('97', 25, 6, 27, 53409) GANDHIJI: I call this arrogance.
('97', 25, 6, 28, 53442) Science has yet much to learn.
('97', 25, 6, 29, 53473) It has so far touched only the hem of the garment.
('97', 25, 6, 30, 53524) All illness is the result of the violation of the laws of nature, in other words, the penalty of sin against Him—since He and His law are one.
('97', 25, 6, 31, 53667) Therefore, when Ramanama holds full sway, all illness vanishes.
('97', 25, 6, 32, 53731) People have no idea of the full potency of Ramanama.
('97', 25, 6, 33, 53784) I am out to demonstrate it.
('97', 25, 6, 34, 53812) I must wish to live only to serve Him and live, therefore, through His grace alone.
('97', 25, 6, 35, 53896) I have plunged into this fire to discover the science of Ramanama just as a doctor or a scientist rushes into an area where an epidemic is raging to discover the laws of physical science.
('97', 25, 6, 36, 54084) I must discover it or perish in the attempt.

('97', 26, 0, 1, 54263) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 27
('97', 26, 1, 2, 54311) 26. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 26, 2, 3, 54340) NEW DELHI, October 2, 1947
('97', 26, 3, 4, 54367) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, A Sikh gentleman came to look me up today.
('97', 26, 3, 5, 54432) He said that somebody had remarked to him that it was all right that I had narrated the words of Guru Arjun Dev, but what did I have to say about the changes made in those words by Guru Govind Singh?
('97', 26, 3, 6, 54632) History says that Guru Govind Singh was a born enemy of the Muslims.
('97', 26, 3, 7, 54701) But there is no reason to believe in any such thing, because the 10th Guru almost repeated the words of Guru Arjun Dev.
('97', 26, 3, 8, 54821) And as for Guru Nanak, he recognized no distinction between the Hindus, the Muslims and the Sikhs.
('97', 26, 3, 9, 54920) It is all the same whether one worships in the temple or says namaaz.
('97', 26, 3, 10, 54990) If a Brahmin offers puja, it does not mean that the person belonging to other religion curses God.
('97', 26, 3, 11, 55089) Instead the Muslims say namaaz.
('97', 26, 3, 12, 55121) Puja and namaaz are one and the same.
('97', 26, 3, 13, 55159) All human beings are the same, though their languages are different.
('97', 26, 3, 14, 55228) Guru Govind Singh has said that all human beings are essentially one and their manifestations are many.
('97', 26, 3, 15, 55332) If that is so, I believe that we are all one and also many.
('97', 26, 3, 16, 55392) Though we appear different we are essentially one.
('97', 26, 3, 17, 55443) There are crores of individuals but they have the same human nature.
('97', 26, 3, 18, 55512) Guru Govind Singh has said that there is “the same air, the same body, the same word.” Then he says that whether called a god or a demon, a Yaksha or a Gandharva or a Turk, they are only different forms.
('97', 26, 3, 19, 55716) That is exactly what Guru Govind Singh says: “There are many forms to be seen but in essence they are the same.” Words mean the speech.
('97', 26, 3, 20, 55852) And speech is only one.
('97', 26, 3, 21, 55876) And the sun is one.
('97', 26, 3, 22, 55896) Can you say that there is one sun for the Muslims and another sun for us?
('97', 26, 3, 23, 55970) It is the same sun for all of us.
('97', 26, 3, 24, 56004) He says the air and water are also the same for everybody.
('97', 26, 3, 25, 56063) The Ganga as it flows does not forbid a Turk from taking its water.
('97', 26, 3, 26, 56131) Nor do the clouds that shower water say that they are bringing water not for the Muslims or the Parsis but only for the Hindus.
('97', 26, 3, 27, 56259) It is not as if the Union Government was meant only for the Hindus.
('97', 26, 3, 28, 56327) That can never happen.
('97', 26, 3, 29, 56350) Whether you mention the Koran or the Gita or the Puranas it is all the same.
('97', 26, 3, 30, 56427) Only the forms are different.
('97', 26, 3, 31, 56457) If you write in Arabic you say it is the Koran.
('97', 26, 3, 32, 56505) And then you write in Sanskrit or in the Devanagari script but if you understand well what is written, you will find it is the same thing.
('97', 26, 3, 33, 56644) So he ends by saying that we are all one.
('97', 26, 3, 34, 56686) That is what Guru Govind Singh has taught.
('97', 27, 0, 1, 56729) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 27, 1, 2, 56770) the gentleman that even if Guru Govind Singh had been an enemy of the Muslims, it was a wrong thing.
('97', 27, 1, 3, 56871) In the event of war both the Hindus and the Muslims died and got wounded.
('97', 27, 1, 4, 56945) But a sensible disciple of the Guru Saheb supplied water to the soldiers who were alive.
('97', 27, 1, 5, 57034) He gave water to the Hindus, the Muslims and the Sikhs.
('97', 27, 1, 6, 57090) He said it was the teaching of Guru Maharaj that there were neither Muslims nor Sikhs nor Hindus; they were only human beings and whoever needed water had to be provided.
('97', 27, 1, 7, 57261) Surely Guru Maharaj did not say that if the wounded person was a Hindu he should be given medical aid and if he happened to be a Muslim he should be left unattended?
('97', 27, 1, 8, 57427) He said that Guruji had fought against the Muslims.
('97', 27, 1, 9, 57479) So he did, but he fought against those Muslims who had abandoned the path of justice, and who had given up their religion.
('97', 27, 1, 10, 57602) He was a man given to charity, he was unattached, he was an incarnation of God.
('97', 27, 1, 11, 57682) For him there was no question of whether people belonged or did not belong to him.
('97', 27, 1, 12, 57765) But there is no doubt that he did defend himself and he did fight.
('97', 27, 1, 13, 57832) It would be a mistake on the part of Sikhs to claim to be non violent.
('97', 27, 1, 14, 57903) They keep kirpans.
('97', 27, 1, 15, 57922) But Guruji taught that the kirpan is meant for the protection of the innocent.
('97', 27, 1, 16, 58001) It is meant to fight against the tyrant who harasses people.
('97', 27, 1, 17, 58062) The kirpan is not meant for killing old women.
('97', 27, 1, 18, 58109) It is not meant for killing women and children, the innocent who are not guilty.
('97', 27, 1, 19, 58190) That is not the function of the kirpan.
('97', 27, 1, 20, 58230) The kirpan would be thrust into the belly of one who is guilty whether he is a Muslim or anybody else or even a Sikh whose guilt has been proved.
('97', 27, 1, 21, 58376) The way people pull out their kirpans these days is an act of barbarism.
('97', 27, 1, 22, 58449) It would not be wrong to deprive these people of their kirpans, because they have given up their religion.
('97', 27, 1, 23, 58556) The Sikhs have abused the kirpan.
('97', 27, 1, 24, 58590) Today is my birthday.
('97', 27, 1, 25, 58612) 1 I do not celebrate my birthday in the usual way.
('97', 27, 1, 26, 58663) I would say that on this day we must fast, spin and pray.
('97', 27, 1, 27, 58721) That, in my view, is the most appropriate way of celebrating one’s birthday.
('97', 27, 1, 28, 58798) For me today is the day of mourning.
('97', 27, 1, 29, 58835) I am surprised and also ashamed that I am still alive.
('97', 27, 1, 30, 58890) I am the same person whose word was honoured by the millions of the country.
('97', 27, 1, 31, 58967) But today nobody listens to me.
('97', 27, 1, 32, 58999) You want only the Hindus to remain in India and say that none else should be left behind.
('97', 27, 1, 33, 59089) You may kill the Muslims today; but what will you do tomorrow?
('97', 27, 1, 34, 59152) What will happen to the Parsis and the Christians and then to the British?
('97', 27, 1, 35, 59227) After all, they are also Christians.
('97', 27, 1, 36, 59264) They have faith in Christ and are surely not Hindus.
('97', 27, 1, 37, 59317) At present we

('97', 28, 1, 2, 59448) have some Muslims in our midst who belong to us.
('97', 28, 1, 3, 59497) If we are ready to kill them, let me tell you that I am not for it.
('97', 28, 1, 4, 59565) Ever since I came to India I have made it my profession to work for communal harmony, and I wish that though our religions are different we may live in amity like brothers.
('97', 28, 1, 5, 59738) But today we seem to have become enemies.
('97', 28, 1, 6, 59780) We assert that there can never be an honest Muslim.
('97', 28, 1, 7, 59832) A Muslim always remains a worthless fellow.
('97', 28, 1, 8, 59876) In such a situation, what place do I have in India and what is the point of my being alive?
('97', 28, 1, 9, 59968) I have now stopped thinking about living for 125 years.
('97', 28, 1, 10, 60024) I have stopped thinking in terms of 100 or even 90 years.
('97', 28, 1, 11, 60082) I am entering my 79th year today; but even that pains me.
('97', 28, 1, 12, 60140) I would tell those who understand me—and there are quite a few who do understand—that we should give up such bestiality.
('97', 28, 1, 13, 60261) I am not worried about what the Muslims do in Pakistan.
('97', 28, 1, 14, 60317) It is not that the Muslims become great by killing the Hindus they only become brutes.
('97', 28, 1, 15, 60404) But does it mean that I should also become a beast, a barbarian, insensitive?
('97', 28, 1, 16, 60482) I would stoutly refuse to do any such thing and I must ask you too not to do so.
('97', 28, 1, 17, 60563) If you really want to celebrate my birthday, it is your duty not to let anyone be possessed by madness and if there is any anger in your hearts you must remove it.
('97', 28, 1, 18, 60727) I would appeal to the people not to take the law into their hands but leave it to the Government to decide the issue.
('97', 28, 1, 19, 60845) If you remember this much, I would consider it a good act on your part.
('97', 28, 1, 20, 60917) This is all I wish to tell you.

('97', 29, 0, 1, 60989) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 29, 1, 2, 61030) 27. OUTRAGEOUS ANALOGY
('97', 29, 2, 3, 61053) A correspondent, who from his name appears to have Hindi as his mother tongue, writes thus in English:
('97', 29, 3, 4, 61156) This is with reference to your many and continued appeals to treat Muslims as brothers and guarantee their safety so that they do not migrate from here to Pakistan.
('97', 29, 3, 5, 61321) A man was walking along one cold day, when he came across a snake lying frozen with the cold.
('97', 29, 3, 6, 61415) Taking pity on the reptile, he picked it up and thinking to give it warmth, put it in his pocket.
('97', 29, 3, 7, 61513) The warmth soon revived the snake, and the first thing it did was to dig its poisonous fangs into his saviour and kill him.
('97', 29, 3, 8, 61637) Anger has betrayed this correspondent into an outrageous analogy.
('97', 29, 3, 9, 61703) To liken a human being, however degraded he may be, to a snake to justify inhuman treatment, is surely a degrading performance.
('97', 29, 3, 10, 61831) To damn crores of human beings for the faults of a few or many belonging to a particular faith seems to me to be the height of madness.
('97', 29, 3, 11, 61967) The correspondent should also remember that I have known rabidly fanatical Muslims to use the very analogy in respect of Hindus.
('97', 29, 3, 12, 62096) No Hindu would like to be regarded as a snake.
('97', 29, 3, 13, 62143) To treat a man as a brother is not to say that he should be trusted even when he is proved untrustworthy.
('97', 29, 3, 14, 62249) And is it not a sign of cowardice to kill a man and his family for fear that he may prove untrustworthy?
('97', 29, 3, 15, 62354) Picture a society in which every man is permitted to judge his fellow.
('97', 29, 3, 16, 62425) Yet that is the state to which we are being reduced in some parts of India.
('97', 29, 3, 17, 62501) Lastly, let me, for the sake of snake kind, correct a common error [and say] that eighty snakes out of every hundred are perfectly harmless and they render useful service in nature.
('97', 29, 4, 18, 62683) NEW DELHI, October 3, 1947
('97', 29, 5, 19, 62710) Harijan, 12 10 1947

('97', 32, 1, 2, 65459) 31. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 32, 2, 3, 65488) NEW DELHI, October 3, 1947
('97', 32, 3, 4, 65515) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, I find satyagraha being carried on in many places in the country.
('97', 32, 3, 5, 65603) I really wonder if what people describe as satyagraha is satyagraha or duragraha.
('97', 32, 3, 6, 65685) What is happening in the country is that people talk of one thing and act quite to the contrary.
('97', 32, 3, 7, 65782) Today every employee, whether belonging to the Post Office or the Telegraph Office, or the Railways or to the Indian States, must examine wherever he is trying to offer satyagraha, whether it stands for truth or untruth.
('97', 32, 3, 8, 66003) If it is for untruth, there is no need to offer it and if it is for truth it should surely be offered under all circumstances.
('97', 32, 3, 9, 66130) Whatever is done with a selfish motive cannot be called satyagraha.
('97', 32, 3, 10, 66198) That would be like insisting on untruth.
('97', 32, 3, 11, 66239) I have explained quite a few conditions for satyagraha.
('97', 32, 3, 12, 66295) I have said that two things are essential in satyagraha.
('97', 32, 3, 13, 66352) One is that the point on which we insist should be truth and another that our insistence should be necessarily non violent.
('97', 32, 3, 14, 66476) Those who are carrying on satyagraha today should act with due deliberation.
('97', 32, 3, 15, 66553) If the basic thing is not truth and there is recourse to force in pressing for the demand, then it would be well to give it up.
('97', 32, 3, 16, 66681) If the thing is poisonous, if it is duragraha and an untruth and if we go on demanding what we possibly cannot get, then let me tell you that we cannot remain non violent in making such a demand.
('97', 32, 3, 17, 66877) This cannot be non violence, it is only violence.
('97', 32, 3, 18, 66927) It is impossible that anyone should make an unjust demand and at the same time claim to be non violent.
('97', 32, 3, 19, 67031) If I am in charge of the refugee camps I would tell the people living in those camps that they must clean their places themselves.
('97', 32, 3, 20, 67162) Should they only play cards and dice and gamble or simply remain idle?
('97', 32, 3, 21, 67233) I know there is not enough food and water for them.
('97', 32, 3, 22, 67285) But if for that reason they start refusing to do any work, they will fall a prey to vices.
('97', 32, 3, 23, 67376) And then there are not just half a dozen persons in those camps.
('97', 32, 3, 24, 67441) Thousands are living in those camps.
('97', 32, 3, 25, 67478) No one can say when they will be able to return to their homes.
('97', 32, 3, 26, 67542) We shall certainly provide food for them; but let them at least do some work to earn it.
('97', 32, 3, 27, 67631) They can start by cleaning their camps and then offer to do other jobs like spinning, weaving, carpentry, smithery, tailoring, etc.
('97', 33, 0, 1, 67763) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 33, 1, 2, 67804) There are plenty of things one can find to do in India.
('97', 33, 1, 3, 67860) These people may have been millionaires yesterday; but today they have lost their millions.
('97', 33, 1, 4, 67952) Such things happen often in the world.
('97', 33, 1, 5, 67991) Then it becomes necessary to begin afresh and start working.
('97', 33, 1, 6, 68052) If somebody comes and says that he was once a millionaire and cannot work, all our plans will be upset.
('97', 33, 1, 7, 68156) We cannot then succeed.
('97', 33, 1, 8, 68180) Very respectfully I would like to say that we cannot proceed that way.
('97', 33, 1, 9, 68251) Whatever work we carry on should be ideal from every point of view.
('97', 33, 1, 10, 68319) It should be clean and there should be nothing shoddy.
('97', 33, 1, 11, 68374) Let me tell you that our difficulties are likely to be solved to a great extent if people do their own work.
('97', 33, 1, 12, 68483) And if we get absorbed in our work our anger will also subside.
('97', 33, 1, 13, 68547) The desire for revenge in our hearts will also die out.
('97', 33, 1, 14, 68603) Goodness lies in recognizing evil as evil and then meeting it with goodwill.
('97', 33, 1, 15, 68680) Therein lies the good of the country.
('97', 33, 1, 16, 68718) We will not inflict suffering on anyone but will try to make others happy by undergoing hardships ourselves.
('97', 33, 1, 17, 68827) If we do this, we shall be acting not only for the good of India but of the world.
('97', 33, 1, 18, 68910) Today the world is watching how India is conducting herself.
('97', 33, 1, 19, 68971) Now is the real moment of our test.
('97', 33, 1, 20, 69007) We have attained independence.
('97', 33, 1, 21, 69038) What are we going to do now?

('97', 35, 6, 15, 71037) 36. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 35, 7, 16, 71066) NEW DELHI, October 4, 1947

('97', 43, 1, 5, 89862) I would however be happy if even though they should go mad, they remained free.
('97', 43, 1, 6, 89942) But if, anybody casts an evil eye on India and tries to subjugate her because our people have gone mad he is not going to succeed.
('97', 43, 1, 7, 90073) I have already told you that even if we continue to be crazy the British are not going to return.
('97', 43, 1, 8, 90171) They cannot come back.
('97', 43, 1, 9, 90194) Once they have thrown out something, are they going to swallow it back?
('97', 43, 1, 10, 90266) But the world is watching all that is happening.
('97', 43, 1, 11, 90315) How will the world react when it sees what is happening here?
('97', 43, 1, 12, 90377) The world will not allow such a thing to happen to India.
('97', 43, 1, 13, 90435) Nor will India allow it to happen.
('97', 43, 1, 14, 90470) But if other powers under the U. N. O. come her for investigation, we will not be able to stop them.
('97', 43, 1, 15, 90571) If then we continue to be mad and lose our heads we will lose our freedom to them.
('97', 43, 1, 16, 90654) Even if I am the only one left I will continue to warn the world that it may completely destroy us if it so wishes, but it can never enslave us again.
('97', 43, 1, 17, 90805) It is my vow never to be a slave again.
('97', 43, 1, 18, 90845) It is for all of you to adhere to that vow, to make it a reality.
('97', 43, 1, 19, 90911) I alone cannot do it.
('97', 43, 1, 20, 90933) I cannot save India single handed.
('97', 43, 1, 21, 90968) How can I be sure about myself?
('97', 43, 1, 22, 91000) Who can say how long I am going to be alive?
('97', 43, 1, 23, 91045) How is India going to be affected if God takes me away?
('97', 43, 1, 24, 91101) How can I save India all by myself?
('97', 43, 1, 25, 91137) It all depends on God.
('97', 43, 1, 26, 91160) If He is by my side and is merciful, India can be saved.
('97', 43, 1, 27, 91217) I think that so long as I am alive, nobody can take advantage of the disturbed conditions in the country and say, let us enslave it and capture it.
('97', 43, 1, 28, 91365) I only wish that God may fulfil this desire of mine through you.
('97', 43, 2, 29, 91430) [From Hindi]
('97', 43, 3, 30, 91443) Prarthana Pravachan—I, pp.
('97', 44, 0, 1, 91470) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 45

('97', 44, 4, 11, 92053) 40. LETTER TO MAGANBHAI P. DESAI
('97', 44, 5, 12, 92086) NEW DELHI, October 6, 1947
('97', 44, 6, 13, 92113) MAGANBHAI,
('97', 44, 7, 14, 92124) I could read your letter only today.
('97', 44, 7, 15, 92161) It is 5.15 a.m.
('97', 44, 7, 16, 92177) now when I am writing this.
('97', 44, 7, 17, 92205) It took me fairly long to read the letter.
('97', 44, 7, 18, 92248) Your reply cannot be published in Harijan.
('97', 44, 7, 19, 92291) If it is published, we should also discuss the subject in Harijan, I am not prepared for that.
('97', 44, 7, 20, 92386) Moreover I am of an entirely different view.
('97', 44, 7, 21, 92431) Plans about a new university seem untimely to me just now.
('97', 44, 7, 22, 92490) Besides, so long as separate States have not been formed, why raise the question of a separate university?
('97', 44, 7, 23, 92597) According to our, or rather only my, view, education at all levels must be self supporting.
('97', 44, 7, 24, 92689) And finally, when the very existence of India is being threatened and the people are engaged in a fratricidal war, is it proper to discuss schemes like this?
('97', 44, 7, 25, 92847) If, however, you wish me to think over the matter further you may write to me.

('97', 46, 4, 10, 95206) 44. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 46, 5, 11, 95235) NEW DELHI, October 6, 1947
('97', 46, 6, 12, 95262) Those who ought to know all about our food problem have gathered together on the invitation of Dr. Rajendra Prasad to give him the benefit of their advice on the grave food crisis.
('97', 46, 6, 13, 95443) Any mistake made on this important matter may mean avoidable starvation and death of millions therefrom.
('97', 46, 6, 14, 95548) India is not unfamiliar with starvation and death of tens of thousands, if not millions, due to famine, natural or man made.
('97', 46, 6, 15, 95673) I claim that in a well ordered society there should always be pre arranged methods of successful treatment of scarcity of water and food crops.
('97', 46, 6, 16, 95817) This is, however, not the occasion for describing a well ordered society and for showing how it would deal with the matter.
('97', 46, 6, 17, 95941) Our concern, for the present, is to see whether we can, with a fair hope of success, deal with the present food crisis.
('97', 46, 6, 18, 96061) I think we can.
('97', 46, 6, 19, 96077) The first lesson we must learn is of self help and self reliance.
('97', 46, 6, 20, 96143) If we assimilate this lesson, we shall at once free ourselves from disastrous dependence upon foreign countries and ultimate bankruptcy.
('97', 46, 6, 21, 96280) This is not said in arrogance but as a matter of fact.
('97', 46, 6, 22, 96335) We are not a small country dependent for our food supply upon outside help.
('97', 46, 6, 23, 96411) We are a sub continent, a nation of nearly 400 millions.
('97', 46, 6, 24, 96468) We are a country of mighty rivers and a rich variety of agricultural land, with inexhaustible cattle wealth.
('97', 46, 6, 25, 96577) That our cattle give much less milk than we need is entirely our own fault.
('97', 46, 6, 26, 96653) Our cattle wealth is any day capable of giving us all the milk we need.
('97', 46, 6, 27, 96725) Our country, if it had not been neglected during the past few centuries, would today not only be providing herself with sufficient food, she would also be playing a useful role in supplying the outside world with much needed food stuffs of which the late war has unfortunately left practically the whole world in want.
('97', 46, 6, 28, 97044) This does not exclude India.
('97', 47, 0, 1, 97073) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 47, 1, 2, 97114) distress is growing instead of showing signs of decreasing.
('97', 47, 1, 3, 97174) My suggestion does not include ungrateful rejection of free supply that any foreign country may wish to offer us.
('97', 47, 1, 4, 97288) All I say is that we must not go begging.
('97', 47, 1, 5, 97330) It demoralizes.
('97', 47, 1, 6, 97346) Add to this the difficulty of internal transport of food stuffs from one place to another.
('97', 47, 1, 7, 97437) We have not the requisite facility for rapid movement of grains and other food stuffs from place to place.
('97', 47, 1, 8, 97544) Further add to this the remote possibility of delivery of uneatable stuff.
('97', 47, 1, 9, 97619) We dare not lose sight of the fact that we have to deal with human nature.
('97', 47, 1, 10, 97694) In no part of the world is it to be found perfect or even very nearly so.
('97', 47, 1, 11, 97768) Next let us see what possible foreign aid we can get.
('97', 47, 1, 12, 97822) I am told that not more than three per cent of our present wants.
('97', 47, 1, 13, 97888) If this information is correct, and I have had it checked by several experts who confirm the figure, I am sure the case for reliance on outside help falls to the ground.
('97', 47, 1, 14, 98058) The slightest dependence on outside help is likely to deflect us from exploring to the fullest extent our immense internal possibilities in the shape of utilizing every inch of arable land for growing crops for daily food in the place of growing money crops.
('97', 47, 1, 15, 98317) We must reclaim waste land which is capable of being placed under immediate cultivation.
('97', 47, 1, 16, 98406) Centralization of food stuffs, I apprehend, is ruinous.
('97', 47, 1, 17, 98462) De centralization easily deals a blow to black marketing, saves time and money in transport to and fro.
('97', 47, 1, 18, 98566) Moreover the villager who grows India’s cereals and pulses knows how to save his crops against rodents.
('97', 47, 1, 19, 98670) The movement of grain from station to station makes it liable to be eaten by rodents.
('97', 47, 1, 20, 98756) This costs the country many millions and deprives it of tons of grain, every ounce of which we badly need.
('97', 47, 1, 21, 98863) If every Indian were to realize the necessity of growing food wherever it can be grown, we should most probably forget that there was scarcity of food stuffs in the land.
('97', 47, 1, 22, 99034) I have by no means dealt fully with the fascinating and absorbing subject of growing more food, but I hope I have said enough to stimulate interest and turn the wise towards the thought of how every individual can help in the laudable enterprise.
('97', 47, 1, 23, 99281) Let me now show how to deal with the three per cent of grain we might possibly get from outside.
('97', 47, 1, 24, 99378) Hindus observe a fast or a semifast every eleventh day each fortnight.
('97', 47, 1, 25, 99449) Muslims and others are not prohibited from denying themselves, especially when it is for the sake of the starving millions.
('97', 47, 1, 26, 99573) If the whole nation realized the beauty of this partial self denial, India would more than cover the deficit caused by
('97', 48, 0, 1, 99692) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 49
('97', 48, 1, 2, 99740) the voluntary deprivation of foreign aid.
('97', 48, 1, 3, 99782) Personally I hold that rationing has very limited use, if any.
('97', 48, 1, 4, 99845) If the producers were left to themselves, they would bring their produce to the market and everyone would get good and eatable grain, which today is not easily obtainable.
('97', 48, 1, 5, 100017) I shall close this hurried review of the food crisis by drawing attention to President Truman’s reported advice to the American people that they should eat less bread, and thus save the much needed grain for starving Europe.
('97', 48, 1, 6, 100242) He added that Americans would not lose in health by the recommended act of self denial.
('97', 48, 1, 7, 100330) I tender my congratulations to President Truman on this philanthropic gesture.
('97', 48, 1, 8, 100409) I must decline to endorse the suggestion that at the back of this philanthropy there is a sordid motive of deriving a pecuniary advantage for America.
('97', 48, 1, 9, 100560) A man must be judged by his action, not the motive prompting it.
('97', 48, 1, 10, 100625) God alone knows men’s hearts.
('97', 48, 1, 11, 100655) If America would deny herself for the sake of hungry Europe, should we fail to do this little act of self denial for ourselves?
('97', 48, 1, 12, 100783) If many must die of starvation, let us at least earn the credit of having done our best in the way of selfhelp, which ennobles a nation.
('97', 48, 1, 13, 100920) Let us hope that the Committee that Dr. Rajendra Prasad has called together will not disperse without presenting a work able solution of the food crisis that faces the country.
('97', 48, 2, 14, 101097) Harijan, 19 10 1947
