('97', 51, 10, 14, 104245) 52. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 51, 11, 15, 104274) NEW DELHI, October 7, 1947
('97', 51, 12, 16, 104301) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, In my speech yesterday there was no mention at all of what is going on between Hindus and Muslims these days.
('97', 51, 12, 17, 104433) But today something has happened and I should not keep quiet about it.
('97', 51, 12, 18, 104504) It has happened not here but at Dehra Dun.
('97', 51, 12, 19, 104547) A Muslim gentleman was murdered.
('97', 51, 12, 20, 104580) As far as I know, he had committed no crime.
('97', 51, 12, 21, 104625) Nor had he taken the law into his own hands.
('97', 51, 12, 22, 104670) But he was killed because he happened to be a Muslim.
('97', 51, 12, 23, 104724) I was pained about it and wondered where we would stop if we went on at this rate.
('97', 51, 12, 24, 104807) Today I find that I have a large number of Muslim friends.
('97', 51, 12, 25, 104866) I feel hesitant to tell them to leave
('97', 51, 13, 26, 104904) 1 From Dilhiman Gandhiji—I, p.
('97', 51, 13, 27, 104935) 85 2 ibid 3 Gandhiji was asked: “Could Ramanama set a broken bone?”
('97', 52, 0, 1, 105003) VOL. 97: 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 53
('97', 52, 1, 2, 105051) this place.
('97', 52, 1, 3, 105063) How would they go away?
('97', 52, 1, 4, 105087) I find that today the Muslims are not safe in the trains.
('97', 52, 1, 5, 105145) Anyone who so pleases throws them out of the compartments or slaughters them.
('97', 52, 1, 6, 105223) I understand that a similar thing is happening in Pakistan.
('97', 52, 1, 7, 105283) But what are we going to gain by continuing to behave in this manner?
('97', 52, 1, 8, 105353) Let us at least know ourselves.
('97', 52, 1, 9, 105385) Let us at least recognize our religion.
('97', 52, 1, 10, 105425) Everyone follows his own religion.
('97', 52, 1, 11, 105460) What does our religion teach us?
('97', 52, 1, 12, 105493) Or are we acting without any regard for our religion?
('97', 52, 1, 13, 105547) Has the Congress lost its senses?
('97', 52, 1, 14, 105581) After all, what did the Congress do for 60 years?
('97', 52, 1, 15, 105631) If the Congress has been making a mistake so far, it is the enemy of the country, and I would say that it should be removed from the scene.
('97', 52, 1, 16, 105771) Let even those who profess to be Congressmen say it in clear terms that they are leaving the Congress and forming another party.
('97', 52, 1, 17, 105900) There is no room for any complaint about it.
('97', 52, 1, 18, 105945) Do whatever you like but this much I can say before the whole world and our people that we should not take the law into our own hands.
('97', 52, 1, 19, 106080) If we do it, we shall be driving ourselves to ruin and lose our independence and then, if some other power comes and subjugates India, we shall realize with shock what a terrible blunder we had make.
('97', 52, 1, 20, 106280) This is not a good thing.
('97', 52, 1, 21, 106306) There was a mongoose which killed a snake to save a child.
('97', 52, 1, 22, 106365) Its mouth was smeared red with blood.
('97', 52, 1, 23, 106403) The child’s mother had gone to the well to fetch water.
('97', 52, 1, 24, 106459) When she returned, the mongoose rushed to her jumping as through saying that it had saved her child.
('97', 52, 1, 25, 106560) But she thought it had killed the child and threw the pitcher on the mongoose.
('97', 52, 1, 26, 106639) The water was gone, the pitcher was broken and the mongoose died.
('97', 52, 1, 27, 106705) When the woman entered the house she saw the child playing in the cradle and the dead snake lying nearby.
('97', 52, 1, 28, 106811) Then she realized that the mongoose had been her friend.

('97', 72, 4, 24, 152927) 61. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 72, 5, 25, 152956) NEW DELHI, October 11, 1947
('97', 72, 6, 26, 152984) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 72, 7, 27, 153006) Today is the twelfth day of the latter half of Bhadrapad.
('97', 72, 7, 28, 153064) In Gujarat, that is, in Kathiawar and Cutch, the day is known as Rentia Baras.
('97', 72, 7, 29, 153143) On this day people’s attention is drawn towards the charkha and allied activities.
('97', 72, 7, 30, 153226) People do not give up once they start on something, but today I think the atmosphere is unfavourable for an enthusiastic celebration of Rentia Dwadashi.
('97', 72, 7, 31, 153379) I have given a wider interpretation to the charkha and India has accepted it as a symbol of non violence.
('97', 72, 7, 32, 153485) Today that symbolic meaning is lost.
('97', 72, 7, 33, 153522) Had that meaning been retained, we would not have witnessed what we see today.
('97', 72, 7, 34, 153601) Even then let me remind you of that meaning.
('97', 72, 7, 35, 153646) It was enough that my
('97', 73, 0, 1, 153668) 74 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 73, 1, 2, 153709) birthday was celebrated on October 2. But for the past many years my birthday has been celebrated according to the Hindu calendar also and the days in between are utilized for plying the charkha with great zeal.
('97', 73, 1, 3, 153921) But today I do not find the atmosphere for it.
('97', 73, 1, 4, 153968) Even so, if by the grace of God some regard the charkha as a symbol of non violence it would indeed be good.
('97', 73, 1, 5, 154077) It would be gratifying if even five persons take it as such, and still better if a crore do so.
('97', 73, 1, 6, 154173) But even if there is one such person it will be good.
('97', 73, 1, 7, 154227) That is why I have drawn your attention to it.
('97', 73, 1, 8, 154274) There is Mandal Saheb in Karachi who is a Minister in the Pakistan Cabinet.
('97', 73, 1, 9, 154350) It is said that he is a Harijan from Bengal, but the Qaid e Azam has given him a place in the Cabinet.
('97', 73, 1, 10, 154453) On his suggestion something was accepted.
('97', 73, 1, 11, 154495) Some two or three others whose names I have forgotten also support his view.
('97', 73, 1, 12, 154572) It is not possible for all the others to be with him.
('97', 73, 1, 13, 154626) But what does it matter if even one or two are supporting him?
('97', 73, 1, 14, 154689) A circular has been issued that all the Harijans in Sind should wear a badge round their arms, with the words indicating that they are untouchables, so that no one should harass them and throw them out.
('97', 73, 1, 15, 154892) According to me the logical result of this would be (it would be fine if it was only my suspicion) that all those Harijans would for the present get employment, but later on if they stayed on there (all of them are not going to stay there; some have already left and some are going to leave, according to reports I have received from many letters) they would have to embrace Islam ultimately.
('97', 73, 1, 16, 155285) If this is to be the result, it would be a dangerous situation.
('97', 73, 1, 17, 155349) If any person wants to give up his religion and accept some other religion and thinks he is doing a good thing, he is entitled to do so.

('97', 73, 1, 23, 155791) I will have settled my accounts with God and would act in accordance with my conscience even if the world protests.

('97', 73, 1, 29, 156414) Religion is a matter of the heart.

('97', 75, 4, 5, 159138) 62. A STUDENT’S PERPLEXITY 2
('97', 75, 5, 6, 159167) Here is an extract from a pupil’s letter to his teacher who sends it to me for comment:
('97', 75, 6, 7, 159255) Two things completely possess me: my nationalism and my overbearing carnal passions.
('97', 75, 6, 8, 159340) These always create seeming contradictions in my behaviour, and inconsistency in my decisions.
('97', 75, 6, 9, 159435) I want to be the first servant of my country and at the same time enjoy the physical pleasures of the world.
('97', 75, 6, 10, 159544) I must confess I do not believe in God although I am sometimes terribly afraid of Him.
('97', 75, 6, 11, 159631) All existence seems to me to be an enigma.
('97', 75, 6, 12, 159674) I do not know what awaits me at the end.
('97', 75, 6, 13, 159715) I have seen dead bodies burning: my mother’s was the last, and the scene influenced me terribly.
('97', 75, 6, 14, 159812) I cannot bear to think that such shall be my fate.
('97', 75, 6, 15, 159863) I feel sick at the sight of a wound; and to think that my body shall burn one day!
('97', 75, 6, 16, 159946) I know, there is no escape.
('97', 75, 6, 17, 159974) To me, there does not seem to be any life beyond.
('97', 75, 6, 18, 160024) That is why I am afraid.
('97', 75, 7, 19, 160049) There are only two courses open to me: either to brood over it and pine away, or to enjoy the physical pleasures of the world, be lost in them and forget the end.
('97', 75, 7, 20, 160212) I confess (I have confessed to you things which I have never confessed to anybody else) that I have chosen the latter course.
('97', 75, 8, 21, 160338) This world is the only reality; its joys are worth having for anything.
('97', 75, 8, 22, 160410) Feeling for my wife who died recently was genuine feeling; but that feeling was not because she was dead but because I was left alone.
('97', 75, 8, 23, 160545) For the dead there are no problems; for the living there are all.
('97', 75, 8, 24, 160611) I do not believe in any pure love; the so called love is nothing but sex.
('97', 75, 8, 25, 160685) If there were anything like pure love, I should have felt more attachment for my parents than for my wife; but the reverse was the case.
('97', 75, 8, 26, 160822) I have been a loyal husband but I could not have assured my wife that I would love her even after her death.
('97', 75, 8, 27, 160931) My feeling would perhaps arise from the inconvenience that her passing away might cause me.
('97', 75, 8, 28, 161023) You might call this cynicism but there it is.
('97', 75, 8, 29, 161069) Please write to me and guide me.
('97', 75, 8, 30, 161102) This extract covers three things.
('97', 75, 8, 31, 161136) (1) Conflict between carnal
('97', 75, 9, 32, 161164) 1 According to a report in Harijan, 19 10 1947, it was proposed to resume the satyagraha in South Africa on October 12. 2 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 19 10 1947.
('97', 76, 0, 1, 161355) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 77
('97', 76, 1, 2, 161404) desire and nationalism, (2) God and future life and (3) Undefiled love and sex.
('97', 76, 1, 3, 161484) The first is well stated.
('97', 76, 1, 4, 161510) Carnal desire was the reality, nationalism was the fashion of the day.
('97', 76, 1, 5, 161581) Nationalism in the sense of power politics is quite consistent with satisfaction of carnal desire.
('97', 76, 1, 6, 161680) Instances from life can be multiplied.
('97', 76, 1, 7, 161719) I have in mind nationalism in the sense of a burning love for the nation including the poorest.
('97', 76, 1, 8, 161815) It must burn as it always has burnt carnal desire and the like.
('97', 76, 1, 9, 161879) Thus there is no conflict but always victory of the latter over the former.
('97', 76, 1, 10, 161955) All embracing love of the nation leaves not a minute for any occupation that interferes with that ruling pursuit.
('97', 76, 1, 11, 162069) He is lost who is possessed by carnal desire.
('97', 76, 1, 12, 162115) Uncertain faith in God and the future springs from the lust for life.

('97', 78, 9, 22, 165766) 67. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 78, 10, 23, 165795) NEW DELHI, October 12, 1947
('97', 78, 11, 24, 165823) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Today also quite a few blankets have been received.
('97', 78, 11, 25, 165897) As for the quilts I may say that they are being made by the mills as well.
('97', 78, 11, 26, 165972) Those quilts too will be arriving.
('97', 78, 11, 27, 166007) From the way blankets and quilts are coming, I have started hoping that the people who have been put here, that is, in Delhi and its neighbourhood, will have no trouble during winter.
('97', 78, 11, 28, 166191) Arrangements are also being made to reach blankets, quilts and warm clothing to the needy.
('97', 78, 11, 29, 166282) One thing should be remembered that the blankets that are being received will wear out in the end, but just now they can give protection against rain and dew.
('97', 78, 11, 30, 166441) But the trouble with the quilts is that it will not be possible to save them from rain.
('97', 78, 11, 31, 166529) God willing, it may not rain during the winter, but the dew is inevitable.
('97', 78, 11, 32, 166604) Everybody may not get a blanket.
('97', 78, 11, 33, 166637) I even doubt if there will
('97', 79, 0, 1, 166664) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 79, 1, 2, 166705) be enough tents to accommodate all.
('97', 79, 1, 3, 166741) I had mentioned one thing while talking to some people, and I want to mention it here too.
('97', 79, 1, 4, 166832) Those who get the quilts can protect themselves against the dew if they spread newspapers on the quilts.
('97', 79, 1, 5, 166937) Then the dew will not pass through.
('97', 79, 1, 6, 166973) Another remarkable thing about the quilts is that the amount of cotton used for making them gives sufficient warmth.
('97', 79, 1, 7, 167090) When cotton breaks and forms into lumps the quilt can be opened up, the cover washed and the cotton used again after carding.
('97', 79, 1, 8, 167216) With this the quilt becomes a new piece.
('97', 79, 1, 9, 167257) It is a very useful thing for those who use it carefully.
('97', 79, 1, 10, 167315) A great calamity has befallen us.
('97', 79, 1, 11, 167349) But those who think of God and work in the name of God find something to learn even from such a calamity.
('97', 79, 1, 12, 167455) Two things are possible.
('97', 79, 1, 13, 167480) One thing is that a person gets panicky or becomes enraged in the face of a calamity, and makes himself more miserable.
('97', 79, 1, 14, 167600) But even in the midst of trouble if he thinks that he is having trouble for no fault of his own and yet he is never going to give up God and is always going to seek His help, he can create for himself happiness even in the midst of misery.
('97', 79, 1, 15, 167840) Many of the people who have come as refugees here were well to do.
('97', 79, 1, 16, 167907) They had lots of money and other property.
('97', 79, 1, 17, 167950) They had big mansions, now all lost and gone.
('97', 79, 1, 18, 167996) I have already said that till the people who have left their homes go back and are able to live in safety they will be a great burden on both the Governments.
('97', 79, 1, 19, 168155) If we want to survive, if we want to remain free, we shall have to atone for the sin of this exchange of population.
('97', 79, 1, 20, 168272) Atonement means making amends for our mistakes.
('97', 79, 1, 21, 168320) Then only would it be true expiation.
('97', 79, 1, 22, 168358) It cannot be done in any other way.
('97', 79, 1, 23, 168394) When somebody really rectifies the mistakes he may have committed, he has done sufficient expiation.
('97', 79, 1, 24, 168495) If we mean to correct our mistakes, then the people who have come here to save their lives must be in a position to go back.
('97', 79, 1, 25, 168620) This may happen when the time comes, but what will you do in the meantime?
('97', 79, 1, 26, 168695) I wish to suggest that in the meantime if good doctors are available—among the refugees there are doctors, lawyers and many others—they should give medical service and those under them also do the same, they can render really great service and even from these troubled times we can learn a new lesson.
('97', 79, 1, 27, 168997) When I went to visit the refugees I was told that 75 per cent of them were businessmen.
('97', 79, 1, 28, 169085) It was a shock to me and I wondered how so many traders would be able to do their business here.
('97', 79, 1, 29, 169182) Millions of traders have arrived here and if all of them start doing business all at once, everything will be in a mess.
('97', 79, 1, 30, 169303) If they decide to put in some effort, learn to do something new, then it will be somegwhat better.
('97', 79, 1, 31, 169402) Let those
('97', 80, 0, 1, 169412) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 81
('97', 80, 1, 2, 169461) traders who were earlier engaged in business forget their past.
('97', 80, 1, 3, 169525) It is a rule in the world that when we cannot get one particular thing, we must look for something else.
('97', 80, 1, 4, 169630) Let us not sit idle, or waste time in gambling and drinking.
('97', 80, 1, 5, 169691) We have got to do some work.
('97', 80, 1, 6, 169720) le us work hard.
('97', 80, 1, 7, 169737) Those who are businessmen but are ablebodied and can use their hands and feet should do some work.
('97', 80, 1, 8, 169836) There are quite a few jobs that do not require any particular training.
('97', 80, 1, 9, 169908) Let them concentrate on such things and co operate with one another.
('97', 80, 1, 10, 169977) At the same time let them develop an attitude of working together.
('97', 80, 1, 11, 170044) Then out of this hellish situation which has been created for us, we shall be able to create heaven.
('97', 80, 1, 12, 170145) I had decided to tell you about all this and thought that today I would explain everything in detail and through you convey it to everyone.
('97', 80, 1, 13, 170285) The refugees and also the country would derive great benefit from it.
('97', 80, 1, 14, 170355) And then, out of the misery that has befallen us we shall create happiness.
('97', 80, 1, 15, 170431) In this connection I want to say what we should do about the quilts we have not yet received but are going to get from various places.
('97', 80, 1, 16, 170566) What shall we do about them?
('97', 80, 1, 17, 170595) The cloth used in the quilts can be removed and washed if it has become dirty.
('97', 80, 1, 18, 170674) The cotton can be kept back.
('97', 80, 1, 19, 170703) Cotton does not get spoilt at all.
('97', 80, 1, 20, 170738) It can be dried and cleaned with hand.
('97', 80, 1, 21, 170777) We do not even need a carding bow.
('97', 80, 1, 22, 170812) It is another matter if we want to use that cotton for spinning.
('97', 80, 1, 23, 170877) That cotton can be easily used for making new mattresses or quilts.
('97', 80, 1, 24, 170945) I think if we make these things ourselves, they will be made cheaper and quicker.
('97', 80, 1, 25, 171027) There is enough cloth lying with the mills.
('97', 80, 1, 26, 171071) I do not wish to discuss the food problem at this stage.
('97', 80, 1, 27, 171128) There is enough stock of cotton out of which quilts can be made in a short time.
('97', 80, 1, 28, 171209) If these quilts are given to the people they would have protection in winter.
('97', 80, 1, 29, 171287) These people must be taught how to prepare these things and given hope in the midst of despair which surrounds them.
('97', 80, 1, 30, 171404) There is a bhajan which says that hope springs from unending despair.
('97', 80, 1, 31, 171474) This is true.
('97', 80, 1, 32, 171488) It is a poetic expression.
('97', 80, 1, 33, 171515) We desire to have a glimpse of hope concealed in the deepest despair.
('97', 80, 1, 34, 171585) What should we do to have that glimpse?
('97', 80, 1, 35, 171625) The people who have been thrown on the streets must first realize that they belong to India, not to the Punjab or the North West Frontier Province or Sind.
('97', 80, 1, 36, 171781) All those provinces are in India and so the people from those parts also belong to India.
('97', 80, 1, 37, 171871) They can become and remain Indians only on the condition that they are not a burden on others.
('97', 80, 1, 38, 171966) Just as milk becomes sweet when you add sugar to it and then you cannot separate sugar from the milk and the milk

('97', 81, 1, 2, 172121) remains what it was, they too should mix and mingle with people wherever they go like sugar in milk and not quarel or nurse hatred towards each other.
('97', 81, 1, 3, 172272) They must be mutually helpful and co operative and put in hard work.
('97', 81, 1, 4, 172341) Then they can reform the province where they go and the people belonging to that province will say that they are willing to accommodate any number of such persons.
('97', 81, 1, 5, 172505) It is my hope that those among the refugees who are able to work and whom my voice can reach must persuade others to be good men.
('97', 81, 1, 6, 172635) They should not be a burden anywhere but should live, as I have said, in amity and mutual adjustment.
('97', 81, 1, 7, 172737) They should not cheat anyone.

('97', 81, 1, 10, 172865) We were born to serve.
('97', 81, 1, 11, 172888) If we live like this, we will forget that we were once plunged in misery and sorrow.

('97', 81, 4, 23, 173431) 68. A BITTER LETTER
('97', 81, 5, 24, 173451) A Muslim friend writes:
('97', 81, 6, 25, 173475) I am a Muslim of nationalist views.
('97', 81, 6, 26, 173511) Throughout my life, if I may be allowed to call my twenty one years’ existence so, I have never been able to think of myself in terms of Hindu or Muslim, however hard my elder brother, father and other relatives tried to make me do so.
('97', 81, 6, 27, 173747) Naturally the Islamia College, Jullundur, would not admit me as I was a Quisling to my community.
('97', 81, 7, 28, 173845) My father with my other relations left Jullundur in April but I did not accompany them because East Punjab, and more so India, was equally my country as it was for my friends of the other creed.
('97', 81, 7, 29, 174040) But brutal happenings of August have disappointed me beyond words.
('97', 81, 7, 30, 174107) Even those boys who had organized processions with me in January, 1946 when Indain National Army people were being tried, wanted to have my life.
('97', 81, 7, 31, 174253) After all I was a Muslim for them by killing whom they would get applause from members of their own
('97', 82, 0, 1, 174353) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 83
('97', 82, 1, 2, 174402) community.
('97', 82, 1, 3, 174413) So I had to run for my life to Delhi where I thought that this treatment could not be meted out to those who believed in United India rather than in Pakistan.
('97', 82, 1, 4, 174572) But it is worse here.
('97', 82, 1, 5, 174594) Even my friends with whom I am putting up look upon me with suspicious eyes.
('97', 82, 2, 6, 174671) Now tell me, my dear apostle of liberty and equality, whether I should go back to my parents in Western Pakistan to be their but throughout my life and against my conscience, or I should stay in India as a hostage whose life is always sought against crimes committed by his inhuman co religionists.
('97', 82, 2, 7, 174970) I have condensed the foregoing but little.
('97', 82, 2, 8, 175013) The bitterness has not been touched.
('97', 82, 2, 9, 175050) Assuming that the letter is accurate, there is ample excuse for bitterness.
('97', 82, 2, 10, 175126) A persons’s worth is, however, tested under the most adverse circumstances.
('97', 82, 2, 11, 175202) Fair weather friends are many.
('97', 82, 2, 12, 175233) They are worthless, “a friend in need is a friend indeed.” Have not persons belonging to the same faith, fought against one another exactly as the Hindus and the Muslims are doing now?
('97', 82, 2, 13, 175418) What was to be expected of ordinary human beings after uninterrupted preaching of the hymn of hate all these long years?
('97', 82, 2, 14, 175539) If the correspondent will justify his nationalism, he must not deny himself at the crucial moment.
('97', 82, 2, 15, 175638) We must avoid imitation of Judas Iscariot.
('97', 82, 2, 16, 175681) 1 Hence I have no hesitation in advising the correspondent to return to his home in Jullundur even if he is to be cut to pieces by his erstwhile friends.
('97', 82, 2, 17, 175835) Such martyrs will be saviours of Hindu Muslim unity.
('97', 82, 2, 18, 175888) If he proves as good as his word, I prophesy that his parents will receive him with open arms.
('97', 82, 2, 19, 175983) Is it not the lot of us mortals that the innocent suffer for the guilty?
('97', 82, 2, 20, 176056) It is as well that they do.
('97', 82, 2, 21, 176084) The world is the richer and better for the sufferings of the innocent.
('97', 82, 2, 22, 176155) I need not be an “apostle of liberty and equality” to reiterate this plain truth.
('97', 82, 3, 23, 176237) NEW DELHI, October 1 3, 1947 Harijan, 19 10 1947

('97', 83, 1, 2, 176406) 69. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('97', 83, 2, 3, 176437) NEW DELHI, October 13, 1947
('97', 83, 3, 4, 176465) Yesterday I made some remarks about the refugee camps which were missed in the English condensation.
('97', 83, 3, 5, 176566) Let me extend them this evening as I attach great importance to them.
('97', 83, 3, 6, 176636) Though we have our fairs, religious and other, and have our Congress sessions and conferences, as a people we are not accustomed to camp life strictly so called.
('97', 83, 3, 7, 176798) I have attended many Congress sessions, conferences, and other camps.
('97', 83, 3, 8, 176868) I attended the Kumbh Mela of 1915 at Hardwar and had the privilege of serving in the Servants of India Camp together with my co workers who had returned from South Africa.
('97', 83, 3, 9, 177040) Though I have nothing to record except kind personal attention to me and mine, my observation of the camp life our people lived is none too happy.
('97', 83, 3, 10, 177187) We lack the sense of social hygiene, the result being dangerous insanitation and dirt with the attendant risk of outbreak of infectious and contagious diseases.
('97', 83, 3, 11, 177348) Our latrines are generally beyond description.
('97', 83, 3, 12, 177395) Absence of this class of provision is perhaps an apt description.
('97', 83, 3, 13, 177461) People think that they can perform these functions anywhere not excluding even the much frequented banks of the sacred rivers.
('97', 83, 3, 14, 177588) Spitting anywhere without the slightest consideration for the neighbours is almost accepted as a right.
('97', 83, 3, 15, 177692) Nor are our cooking arrangements any better.
('97', 83, 3, 16, 177737) Flies are everywhere welcome companions.
('97', 83, 3, 17, 177778) We forget that they might have sat a moment ago on any kind of dirt and thus might have become easy carriers of infection.
('97', 83, 3, 18, 177901) Accomm odation is not always planned.
('97', 83, 3, 19, 177939) This is not an exaggerated picture.
('97', 83, 3, 20, 177975) I must not omit the babble of noise one has to tolerate in these camps.
('97', 83, 3, 21, 178047) For method, planning and almost perfect sanitation, give me a military camp.
('97', 83, 3, 22, 178124) I have never recognized the necessity of the military.
('97', 83, 3, 23, 178179) But that is not to say that nothing good can come out of it.
('97', 83, 3, 24, 178240) It gives valuable lessons in discipline corporate existence, sanitation, and an exact time table containing provision for every useful activity.
('97', 83, 3, 25, 178385) There is almost pindrop silence in such camps.
('97', 83, 3, 26, 178432) It is a city under canvas brought into being inside of a few hours.
('97', 83, 3, 27, 178500) I would like our refugee camps to approach that ideal.
('97', 83, 3, 28, 178555) Then there is no inconvenience, rain or
('97', 83, 4, 29, 178595) 1 Since Gandhiji was observing silence his written speech was read out after the prayers.
('97', 84, 0, 1, 178685) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 85
('97', 84, 1, 2, 178734) no rain.
('97', 84, 1, 3, 178743) These camps become quite inexpensive provided that all work including the building up of this canvas city is done by the refugees who are their own sweepers, cleaners, road makers, trench diggers, cooks, washermen.
('97', 84, 1, 4, 178958) No work is too low for them.
('97', 84, 1, 5, 178987) Every variety of work connected with the camp is eqaully dignified.
('97', 84, 1, 6, 179055) Careful and enlightened supervision can bring about the desirable and necessary revolution in social life.
('97', 84, 1, 7, 179162) Then indeed the present calamity would be turned into a blessing in disguise.
('97', 84, 1, 8, 179240) Then no refugee will become a burden wherever he goes.
('97', 84, 1, 9, 179295) He will never think of himself alone, but always think of the whole of his fellow sufferers and never want for himself what his fellows cannot have.
('97', 84, 1, 10, 179444) This is not to be done by brooding but by prompt action under wise supervision and guidance.
('97', 84, 1, 11, 179537) Blankets and quilts continue to come.
('97', 84, 1, 12, 179575) Soon it will, I hope, be possible to say that there will be no dearth of this protection against the coming winter.

('97', 85, 6, 8, 180451) 72. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 85, 7, 9, 180480) NEW DELHI, October, 14, 1947
('97', 85, 8, 10, 180509) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 85, 9, 11, 180531) Today also many blankets have been received.
('97', 85, 9, 12, 180576) There is an institution called the Arya Kanya Vidyalaya here.
('97', 85, 9, 13, 180638) Two teachers and some students from that institution came today.
('97', 85, 9, 14, 180703) They have collected money to buy blankets.
('97', 85, 9, 15, 180746) How much could they have collected?
('97', 85, 9, 16, 180782) They got a few blankets.
('97', 85, 9, 17, 180807) But they told me something which I thought was a great thing and I was happy when they started talking about keeping a fast.
('97', 85, 9, 18, 180932) I told them that every lunar month has two halves, the bright fortnight and the dark fortnight.
('97', 85, 9, 19, 181028) If they fix one day in each fortnight and keep a fast on that day, we shall be saving all the food that we get from outside.
('97', 85, 9, 20, 181153) I consider it a grave mistake to spend money and get food from outside.
('97', 85, 9, 21, 181225) By observing such fasts we save ourselves from making such a mistake.
('97', 85, 9, 22, 181295) After they heard my suggestion the teachers of the Vidyalaya had a consultation with the girls.
('97', 85, 9, 23, 181391) They did not compel anyone.
('97', 85, 9, 24, 181419) But they decided to keep a fast on every Thursday and give in charity whatever they would be saving thereby.
('97', 85, 9, 25, 181528) They would try to give whatever they were able to save.
('97', 85, 9, 26, 181584) They also said that they would grow food on some land they had.
('97', 85, 9, 27, 181648) They have taken upon themselves two tasks—to eat less and grow more food.
('97', 85, 9, 28, 181722) I appreciated this much more than the blankets that have come from them.
('97', 85, 9, 29, 181795) They were followed by the Ambassador of Iran and his wife.
('97', 85, 9, 30, 181854) They sat for a little while but left behind a big pile of blankets.
('97', 85, 9, 31, 181922) They wanted me to distribute the blankets if I could.
('97', 85, 9, 32, 181976) I told them I was a beggar and would
('97', 86, 0, 1, 182013) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 87
('97', 86, 1, 2, 182062) receive whatever was available and pass it on to the needy.
('97', 86, 1, 3, 182122) Many Sikh gentlemen came to me.
('97', 86, 1, 4, 182154) They came in two or three groups.
('97', 86, 1, 5, 182188) I discussed many things with them.
('97', 86, 1, 6, 182223) There is no point in telling you what I discussed.
('97', 86, 1, 7, 182274) There was nothing secret about it.
('97', 86, 1, 8, 182309) But the gist of my discussion which they and all others should well understand is that we are going to achieve nothing by indulging in such mutual fights.
('97', 86, 1, 9, 182464) Passing judgments, giving punishment, acting in retaliation and so on are the things to be done by the Government.
('97', 86, 1, 10, 182579) Let us do whatever we can through the Government.
('97', 86, 1, 11, 182629) I think they were all in agreement with this.
('97', 86, 1, 12, 182675) The rest of the discussion I shall leave out.
('97', 86, 1, 13, 182721) Then I heard another thing.
('97', 86, 1, 14, 182749) Some people have been arrested.
('97', 86, 1, 15, 182781) We are having our own Government and if it arrests some people it is free to do so.
('97', 86, 1, 16, 182865) Quite often it is possible that innocent people get arrested.
('97', 86, 1, 17, 182927) Our Government should not deliberately make the mistake of arresting innocent persons.
('97', 86, 1, 18, 183014) Nor should it arrest anyone wilfully.
('97', 86, 1, 19, 183052) But whatever we may do, a human being is a human being after all.
('97', 86, 1, 20, 183118) He is prone to make mistakes.
('97', 86, 1, 21, 183148) He is no angel.
('97', 86, 1, 22, 183164) And he is certainly no God.
('97', 86, 1, 23, 183192) So he is bound to make mistakes.
('97', 86, 1, 24, 183225) If by mistake some innocent persons were arrested, what was the need to launch an agitation?
('97', 86, 1, 25, 183318) But I hear there is some agitation going on against the arrest of some innocent persons.
('97', 86, 1, 26, 183407) It is for the Government to decide whether or not those persons are guilty.
('97', 86, 1, 27, 183483) I can understand if some evidence is placed before the Government to establish the innocence of a particular person.
('97', 86, 1, 28, 183600) But harassing the Government in this manner, getting somebody released by resorting to agitation, is not the proper thing to do.
('97', 86, 1, 29, 183729) When we fought against British imperialism and were jailed we used to demand the release of the prisoners saying that they were not guilty.
('97', 86, 1, 30, 183869) That was indeed true.
('97', 86, 1, 31, 183891) But they were guilty in the eyes of the Government, not ours.
('97', 86, 1, 32, 183953) In those days we agitated against the British in protest against the arrest of our leaders.
('97', 86, 1, 33, 184045) But against whom should we agitate now?
('97', 86, 1, 34, 184085) Our Government in effect is a Panchayat Raj.
('97', 86, 1, 35, 184130) The leaders represent the Panchayat.
('97', 86, 1, 36, 184167) It is we who have made them leaders.
('97', 86, 1, 37, 184204) That is why I say this is not the time to intimidate our Government by resorting to agitations.
('97', 86, 1, 38, 184300) First and foremost, it is our own Government.
('97', 86, 1, 39, 184346) It does not have the military strength which the British used to have in India.
('97', 86, 1, 40, 184426) The British had the entire Navy at their command, because of which it used to be said that they were invincible and unrivalled.
('97', 86, 1, 41, 184554) It is another matter if that claim cannot hold good today.
('97', 86, 1, 42, 184613) Whatever it is, they had everything at their command.
('97', 86, 1, 43, 184667) By dint of that force they
('97', 87, 0, 1, 184694) 88 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 87, 1, 2, 184735) ruled over us.
('97', 87, 1, 3, 184750) Now we are our own rulers.
('97', 87, 1, 4, 184777) If we know that no other power is ruling over us and those who are ruling over us have been elected by us, we can also remove them.
('97', 87, 1, 5, 184909) That is why I say that we should not take such an agitational approach.
('97', 87, 1, 6, 184981) The next thing I want to mention, about which I have already told you a number of times, is how we can establish perfect peace in India.
('97', 87, 1, 7, 185118) It is a very complicated problem.
('97', 87, 1, 8, 185152) I am not all that happy that there is not much trouble in Delhi.
('97', 87, 1, 9, 185217) There may be stray murders here and there, but it is not a regular feature as it used to be.
('97', 87, 1, 10, 185310) This is good.
('97', 87, 1, 11, 185324) The Government can be happy about it, but I cannot.
('97', 87, 1, 12, 185376) This is because I have not come here to rule.
('97', 87, 1, 13, 185422) I have stayed on here by sheer coincidence.
('97', 87, 1, 14, 185466) I stayed here in the hope that I would bring together both the sides which are riven with hatred and would be helpful in doing that.
('97', 87, 1, 15, 185599) These communities used to quarrel in the past too.
('97', 87, 1, 16, 185650) But they used come together once the quarrel was over.
('97', 87, 1, 17, 185705) But today our hearts are poisoned, as if we had been enemies for several centuries.
('97', 87, 1, 18, 185789) This is unthinkable.
('97', 87, 1, 19, 185810) We should not be cowards, neither the Muslims nor the Sikhs, nor the Hindus.
('97', 87, 1, 20, 185887) Then we would be frightened of nobody.
('97', 87, 1, 21, 185926) The Muslims should cease to be frightened of the Sikhs and stop running away in fear.
('97', 87, 1, 22, 186012) The Hindus and the Sikhs should give up fear of the Muslims.
('97', 87, 1, 23, 186073) The Hindus, the Sikhs and the Muslims should no longer fear one another, if we wish to become a great military power.
('97', 87, 1, 24, 186191) And, if we choose, India can develop a great non violent and invincible army.
('97', 87, 1, 25, 186269) We have two alternatives before us and there is no third way out.
('97', 87, 1, 26, 186335) The way we are following is no way at all.
('97', 87, 1, 27, 186378) It is the way of barbarism.
('97', 87, 1, 28, 186406) There is no way in it to march forward.
('97', 87, 1, 29, 186446) Thus, I wish to point out the way that can bring us close to one another.
('97', 87, 1, 30, 186520) The most important thing is that the Hindus, the Muslims and the Sikhs should stop blaming one another as they are doing now.
('97', 87, 1, 31, 186646) Let them all see their own mistakes and see them magnified like a mountain.
('97', 87, 1, 32, 186722) The Muslims should not say that even though they committed mistakes at one time, the mistakes the Hindus and the Sikhs are committing today are so great that their earlier mistakes count for nothing.
('97', 87, 1, 33, 186922) Nor should the Hindus retort by saying that even though they have committed mistakes, their mistakes are nothing compared to what the Muslims have done.
('97', 87, 1, 34, 187075) What is so very great in answering mistakes with mistakes?
('97', 87, 1, 35, 187134) If we Hindus and Sikhs try to satisfy ourselves by saying that that has always happened in the world, I would say that it is not the correct way.
('97', 87, 1, 36, 187280) That way we can never sit together with a clean conscience.
('97', 87, 1, 37, 187340) Today things have reached such a stage that the Pakistan Government
('97', 88, 0, 1, 187408) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 89
('97', 88, 1, 2, 187457) refuses to take in such a large number of Muslims.
('97', 88, 1, 3, 187508) And then we begin to wonder if this is due to treachery on their part.

('97', 88, 1, 5, 187610) But how does it affect us if it is there and they have some hidden motive?
('97', 88, 1, 6, 187685) If we do not have enough courage not to be driven by suspicion, we are going to perish.

('97', 88, 1, 10, 187977) If we know that we have committed a mistake, we must admit it.

('97', 88, 1, 12, 188148) If we become such enemies, the result can be only unfortunate.

('97', 88, 1, 19, 188655) But why should we make any mistakes?
('97', 88, 1, 20, 188692) We will not do so.
('97', 88, 1, 21, 188711) If we mutually resolve that we shall have healthy competition and instead of giving two blows for one shall remain calm even in the face of provocation and resolve to remain free from guilt, compete in being good, then let me tell you that all is well with us.
('97', 88, 1, 22, 188972) And then I can leave Delhi with an easy mind.

('97', 88, 1, 40, 189680) Should they all go away from here?

('97', 90, 4, 9, 192599) NEW DELHI, October 15, 1947
('97', 90, 5, 10, 192627) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 90, 6, 11, 192649) Many persons come to see me every day.
('97', 90, 6, 12, 192688) Some of them leave with me blankets and money for the refugees.
('97', 90, 6, 13, 192752) A lady has given me today a cheque for Rs. 2,000. Two persons also came to see me on behalf of the Muslims.
('97', 90, 6, 14, 192860) They have collected blankets and some money which they have passed on to me.
('97', 90, 6, 15, 192937) They are craftsmen.
('97', 90, 6, 16, 192957) They have not even given their names.
('97', 90, 6, 17, 192995) I asked them to distribute those things themselves among their own fellowmen who have suffered.
('97', 90, 6, 18, 193091) But they said they wanted to hand over the things in Gandhi’s hands, because such things should be distributed among the Hindus and the Sikhs who have suffered in West Punjab.
('97', 90, 6, 19, 193267) I was touched by their sentiment.
('97', 90, 6, 20, 193301) In the present conditions even if a few Muslims or Hindus or Sikhs do things like these, they must be written down in letters of gold.
('97', 90, 6, 21, 193436) They said that at one time they considered me an enemy of the Muslims; but now they were convinced that I was a friend to everyone.
('97', 90, 6, 22, 193568) So am I, and I claim to be one.
('97', 90, 6, 23, 193600) I do not need a certificate from anyone for that.
('97', 90, 6, 24, 193650) I have lived in that spirit not for five or seven years but for the last 60 years.
('97', 90, 6, 25, 193733) It is generally said that every Sikh regards the Muslim as his enemy and vice versa.
('97', 90, 6, 26, 193818) But this is absolutely incorrect.
('97', 90, 6, 27, 193852) It is true that a considerable number of Sikhs went wild, as did a large number of Hindus and Muslims.
('97', 90, 6, 28, 193955) But for that reason to say that the whole community of Sikhs is like that or that all Muslims are the same is quite unjust.
('97', 90, 6, 29, 194079) I have with me innumerable instances showing how the Sikhs and the Hindus saved Muslims and the Muslims saved the Sikhs and the Hindus by keeping them in their own houses.
('97', 90, 6, 30, 194251) Not only from

('97', 91, 1, 4, 194460) Let them give up publishing the news about the Hindus and the Muslims killing each other.
('97', 91, 1, 5, 194550) That does nothing but harm.
('97', 91, 1, 6, 194578) The Press has become very powerful in the present world.
('97', 91, 1, 7, 194635) It can render great service if it so chooses.

('97', 92, 1, 2, 196574) 76. ACTION IN INACTION 1
('97', 92, 2, 3, 196599) A Correspondent writes:
('97', 92, 3, 4, 196623) In your article “My Duty” 2 you say that you have not reached that state.
('97', 92, 3, 5, 196697) The sentence looks simple enough but I would like you to expand the meaning a little.
('97', 92, 3, 6, 196783) There is a stage in life when a man does not need even to proclaim his thoughts, much less to show them by outward action.
('97', 92, 3, 7, 196906) Mere thoughts act.
('97', 92, 3, 8, 196925) They attain that power.
('97', 92, 3, 9, 196949) Then it can be said of him that his seeming inaction constitutes his action.
('97', 92, 3, 10, 197026) I must confess that I am far from that state.
('97', 92, 3, 11, 197072) All I can say is that my striving is in that direction.

('97', 93, 3, 4, 198015) SUNDARLAL,
('97', 93, 4, 5, 198026) I got your two letters.
('97', 93, 4, 6, 198050) The description 1 that you have given does not tally with that of the others.
('97', 93, 4, 7, 198128) I have carefully gone through Mirza Saheb’s 2 statement.
('97', 93, 4, 8, 198185) Yesterday I gave it to Jawaharlal to read.
('97', 93, 4, 9, 198228) He has taken it with him.
('97', 93, 4, 10, 198254) Tell Mirza Saheb that I received his telegrams and did what was possible.
('97', 93, 4, 11, 198328) But what could I do?
('97', 93, 4, 12, 198349) The statements on the two sides were such that I had to keep silent.
('97', 93, 4, 13, 198418) You must realize that I have very little power.
('97', 93, 4, 14, 198466) The Government is not in my hands and I do not want to interfere in the affairs of the Government.
('97', 93, 4, 15, 198565) Nor can I do so.
('97', 93, 4, 16, 198582) I understand my limitations.
('97', 93, 5, 17, 198611) Blessings from BAPU SHRI PANDIT SUNDARLALJI C/O LALA ACHINTRAM BRADLAUGH HALL

('97', 94, 1, 2, 198917) 79. LETTER TO ANAND AND GANGI HINGORANI
('97', 94, 2, 3, 198957) NEW DELHI, October 16, 1947
('97', 94, 3, 4, 198985) ANAND AND GANGI, I have your letter.
('97', 94, 3, 5, 199022) The condition of Sind is distressing.
('97', 94, 3, 6, 199060) I am pained by Father’s condition.
('97', 94, 3, 7, 199095) I just don’t know what to do.
('97', 94, 3, 8, 199125) Do what both of you consider your duty.
('97', 94, 3, 9, 199165) If you have understood and assimilated my point, why should you go to America?
('97', 94, 3, 10, 199244) However, if you feel depressed all the time because you are hard of hearing, go to any place in the world and get yourself cured.

('97', 94, 6, 14, 199485) 80. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 94, 7, 15, 199514) NEW DELHI, October 16, 1947
('97', 94, 8, 16, 199542) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 94, 9, 17, 199564) I have been forgetting to talk about Mysore.
('97', 94, 9, 18, 199609) You must be aware of what has happened there.
('97', 94, 9, 19, 199655) Sir Ramaswamy Mudaliar is the Dewan of Mysore.
('97', 94, 9, 20, 199702) Mysore has joined the Indian Union.
('97', 94, 9, 21, 199738) The people of that State are well educated.
('97', 94, 9, 22, 199782) They have resorted to satyagraha quite often.
('97', 94, 9, 23, 199828) This time too the people offered satyagraha.
('97', 94, 9, 24, 199873) They wanted adequate share for the people in the administration.
('97', 94, 9, 25, 199938) The Prince would remain and the people would be loyal to him; but he should withdraw from administration.
('97', 94, 9, 26, 200044) This should have actually happened, but it did not.
('97', 94, 9, 27, 200096) Hence the satyagraha.
('97', 94, 9, 28, 200118) The people sent me a telegram before launching the satyagraha.
('97', 94, 9, 29, 200181) They informed me that there was no cause for me to worry.
('97', 94, 9, 30, 200239) They said they had decided to resort to satyagraha after a great deal of thought and they would strictly conform to the rules of satyagraha.
('97', 94, 9, 31, 200380) They were ready to face any hardships in the pursuit of their goal.
('97', 94, 9, 32, 200448) But the Dewan, Sir Ramaswamy Mudaliar, is a very great man.
('97', 94, 9, 33, 200508) He has travelled all over the world.
('97', 94, 9, 34, 200545) He realized that
('97', 95, 0, 1, 200562) 96 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 95, 1, 2, 200603) the people could no longer be ill treated.
('97', 95, 1, 3, 200646) How long could it go on?
('97', 95, 1, 4, 200671) The result was that all those who had been taken prisoners were released and the issue was settled between the Mysore State and the people.
('97', 95, 1, 5, 200811) All the legitimate demands of the people were accepted by the State.
('97', 95, 1, 6, 200880) The ruler, the Dewan and the people should be congratulated on this settlement.
('97', 95, 1, 7, 200960) The State has agreed to rule with the consent of the people.
('97', 95, 1, 8, 201021) There are many other such Princes.
('97', 95, 1, 9, 201056) Let them also follow this example and, like the King of England, rule with the consent of the people.
('97', 95, 1, 10, 201158) How wonderful it would be if they abided by the will of the people and did not overstep the limit!
('97', 95, 1, 11, 201257) Another thing which I want to say is that the place where I stay belongs to the Birla brothers.
('97', 95, 1, 12, 201353) They allow everyone to come in.
('97', 95, 1, 13, 201385) We must appreciate their good gesture.
('97', 95, 1, 14, 201424) Usually lakhs of people attend the prayer meetings.
('97', 95, 1, 15, 201476) But here the prayer meetings have been small.
('97', 95, 1, 16, 201522) Actually I did not expect even the present number.
('97', 95, 1, 17, 201573) Those attending these prayer meetings also include people who have come from the Punjab.
('97', 95, 1, 18, 201662) I was very pained to learn that some people picked fruits from the trees around.
('97', 95, 1, 19, 201743) Nobody should touch a single fruit on the trees.
('97', 95, 1, 20, 201792) Why talk of fruit, not even a leaf should be plucked.
('97', 95, 1, 21, 201846) The gardener would not at all like people picking fruits like that.
('97', 95, 1, 22, 201914) There is a time even for picking fruits.
('97', 95, 1, 23, 201955) They should not be plucked before their time.
('97', 95, 1, 24, 202001) People who come here come to worship.
('97', 95, 1, 25, 202039) Let our hearts be pure at least during the prayer meeting.
('97', 95, 1, 26, 202098) During that period we should think of nothing but God.
('97', 95, 1, 27, 202153) How then can we resort to stealing?
('97', 95, 1, 28, 202189) It may be that we are all passing through troubled times.
('97', 95, 1, 29, 202247) But let us not give up our good behaviour.
('97', 95, 1, 30, 202290) I have received another complaint too.
('97', 95, 1, 31, 202329) People keep coming to see me throughout the day.
('97', 95, 1, 32, 202378) Some of them say that by praising Government officers, the police and the military I have given them a certificate of efficiency.
('97', 95, 1, 33, 202508) I have not said any such thing.
('97', 95, 1, 34, 202540) Even if I did, it was a folly on my part or I must have been off my guard.
('97', 95, 1, 35, 202615) But I have not said it at all.
('97', 95, 1, 36, 202646) What I said was that they should all rise to the occasion.
('97', 95, 1, 37, 202705) Not that they have already reached that level.
('97', 95, 1, 38, 202752) It is one thing to say that a person should have such and such qualities and another thing for him to have those qualities.
('97', 95, 1, 39, 202876) In any case, since I do not know anyone of them, how could I give them any certificate?
('97', 95, 1, 40, 202964) How do I know that they are all working according to the law?
('97', 95, 1, 41, 203026) Our duty is to abide by the instructions of the police and the military, because they are given a certain authority.
('97', 96, 0, 1, 203143) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 97
('97', 96, 1, 2, 203192) If we wish to have Panchayat Raj the first rule is that we should follow its orders.
('97', 96, 1, 3, 203277) We have not yet achieved the full benefits of Panchayat Raj.
('97', 96, 1, 4, 203338) Had we been truly non violent, this would not have been so.
('97', 96, 1, 5, 203398) Even so, the British rule has ended.
('97', 96, 1, 6, 203435) The Governor General, though he is a high ranking officer in the Navy and belongs to the royal family, has remained here as our servant.
('97', 96, 1, 7, 203572) He has to go by the opinion of our cabinet of Ministers.
('97', 96, 1, 8, 203629) He is not our master.
('97', 96, 1, 9, 203651) Rather, we are his masters.
('97', 96, 1, 10, 203679) Thus ours is a democratic government and we must all abide by the laws made by it.
('97', 96, 1, 11, 203762) If anyone has any complaint against Government officers the remedy lies in approaching Government or getting the complaint published in the newspapers.
('97', 96, 1, 12, 203914) If any officer has taken to bribery or is inefficient, action should be taken against him.
('97', 96, 1, 13, 204005) Those who indulge in graft are committing a crime against themselves and against the country.
('97', 96, 1, 14, 204099) Recently some military officers were found flogging people at the railway station.
('97', 96, 1, 15, 204182) No officer has a right to flog anyone.
('97', 96, 1, 16, 204221) But in retaliation if we also start whipping we fall victims to the same evil.
('97', 96, 1, 17, 204300) Before independence, Government officers used to behave like our masters and not servants.
('97', 96, 1, 18, 204391) They were loyal to the British Government, and if they took bribes in those days, they were committing a crime against the British Government.
('97', 96, 1, 19, 204534) But if the officers take bribes now, they are committing a crime against India.
('97', 96, 1, 20, 204614) There is such a lot of difference in this.
('97', 96, 1, 21, 204657) Some people from Noakhali have also come to me.
('97', 96, 1, 22, 204705) East Pakistan is no small country after all.
('97', 96, 1, 23, 204750) Places like Dacca and Tripura are in East Pakistan.
('97', 96, 1, 24, 204802) Those people tell me that the Hindus in Dacca are fleeing.
('97', 96, 1, 25, 204861) They fear some atrocities there.
('97', 96, 1, 26, 204894) Those Bengali friends have requested me to say something.
('97', 96, 1, 27, 204952) I can say only what I have been saying all along.
('97', 96, 1, 28, 205002) Nobody should leave his country or his home like that.
('97', 96, 1, 29, 205057) The brave have nothing to fear.
('97', 96, 1, 30, 205089) If at all, they are afraid only of God.
('97', 96, 1, 31, 205129) They should not run away in cowardice.
('97', 96, 1, 32, 205168) They must have the courage to die.
('97', 96, 1, 33, 205203) They must tell the Pakistan Government that they wish to remain loyal to Pakistan and stay on there.
('97', 96, 1, 34, 205304) They must assure it that they will not betray and cut at the roots of Pakistan.
('97', 96, 1, 35, 205384) They must say that the Government may kill them, but cannot abduct their daughters.
('97', 96, 1, 36, 205468) If the Government forbids the name of Rama they must insist on uttering that name.
('97', 96, 1, 37, 205551) If it says they should not beat drums on the Dussehra Day, they must insist on doing so and explain that that is part of their religion.
('97', 96, 1, 38, 205688) But it is very wrong that influential people run away from there in order to save their lives while the poor, helpless people stay on there.
('97', 96, 1, 39, 205829) There is a large population of Shudras there.
('97', 96, 1, 40, 205875) How can they be expected to show the requisite courage?
('97', 96, 1, 41, 205931) If I am a
('97', 97, 0, 1, 205941) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 97, 1, 2, 205982) businessman possessing a lot of money, should I run away?
('97', 97, 1, 3, 206040) That is not my dharma.
('97', 97, 1, 4, 206063) If the lawyers, doctors, tradesmen, etc., find that they have got to leave their places, they should see that the poor have found their safety first.
('97', 97, 1, 5, 206213) It is not human to run away leaving the poor behind.
('97', 97, 1, 6, 206266) That can never bring glory to Hinduism, Islam or Sikhism.
('97', 97, 1, 7, 206324) Wherever you go, you should always keep the poor with you.
('97', 97, 1, 8, 206383) Unfortunately I am not in East Pakistan today.
('97', 97, 1, 9, 206430) God has not given me the power to be present everywhere.
('97', 97, 1, 10, 206487) I am just a human being and helpless at that.
('97', 97, 1, 11, 206533) But I can certainly make my voice reach them all, and that I am doing.
('97', 97, 1, 12, 206604) Those Bengali friends told me that I should request Dr. Ambedkar to do something in the matter.
('97', 97, 1, 13, 206700) He has done considerable work among the depressed classes.
('97', 97, 1, 14, 206759) On this occasion he too should say a few things to the people there.
('97', 97, 1, 15, 206828) Let him tell them that it is sinful to keep alive at the cost of one’s religion.
('97', 97, 1, 16, 206909) Such words would give them some strength.
('97', 97, 1, 17, 206951) I am also requested to send Suhrawardy Saheb over there.
('97', 97, 1, 18, 207008) It would be proper too that he went there.
('97', 97, 1, 19, 207051) But Suhrawardy Saheb is not here.
('97', 97, 1, 20, 207085) He should be here in a day or two.
('97', 97, 1, 21, 207120) But Khwaja Nazimuddin is already there.
('97', 97, 1, 22, 207160) He too says that no Hindu or Sikh will be killed in Pakistan.
('97', 97, 1, 23, 207222) Suhrawardy Saheb too will go there to help him.
('97', 97, 1, 24, 207270) How can he avoid going there?
('97', 97, 1, 25, 207300) Today, it is in the interest of everybody that Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs should live in amity.
('97', 97, 1, 26, 207395) If this does not happen, both India and Pakistan will perish.

('97', 98, 1, 2, 208242) 82. LETTER TO JULIAN HUXLEY 1
('97', 98, 2, 3, 208272) [Before October 17, 1947] 2
('97', 98, 3, 4, 208300) I learned from my illiterate, but wise, mother that all rights to be deserved and preserved came from a duty well done.
('97', 98, 3, 5, 208420) The very right to live accrues to us only when we do the duty of the citizenship of the world.
('97', 98, 3, 6, 208515) From this one fundamental statement perhaps it is easy enough to define the duties of man and woman and correlate every right to some corresponding duty to be first performed.
('97', 98, 3, 7, 208691) Every other right can be shown to be usurpation hardly worth fighting for.
('97', 98, 4, 8, 208766) The Hindustan Times, 19 10 1947
('97', 98, 5, 9, 208798) 83. A PUZZLE 3
('97', 98, 6, 10, 208813) A friend writes:
('97', 98, 7, 11, 208830) It would be well not to discuss even by way of joke the possibility of a war between our two States.
('97', 98, 7, 12, 208931) But you have gone so far as to express the opinion 4 that in the event of a war between the two, the Muslims of the Union should fight against those of Pakistan.
('97', 98, 7, 13, 209093) Does it not then follow that the Hindus and other non Muslims [of Pakistan] should do likewise?
('97', 98, 7, 14, 209189) Now if such a war arises out of the communal question, no argument is likely to make the Muslims of the Union fight those of Pakistan and likewise the Hindus and the Sikhs of Pakistan.
('97', 98, 7, 15, 209374) If, however, a war takes place between the two for other than the communal cause, you will not contend that the Hindus of Pakistan and the Muslims of the Union should fight Pakistan.
('97', 98, 7, 16, 209557) It is undoubtedly true that the possibility of a war between the two States should not be discussed by way of a joke.
('97', 98, 7, 17, 209675) The adverb “even” does not fit in.
('97', 98, 7, 18, 209710) For, if the possibility be a reality, it would be a duty to discuss it.
('97', 98, 7, 19, 209782) It might be folly not to do so.
('97', 98, 8, 20, 209814) 1 This was one of the 60 replies to a request by UNESCO to thinkers and philosophers throughout the world for their opinions.
('97', 98, 8, 21, 209940) On the basis of the answers a report was to be submitted to the U. N. Human Rights Commission in Geneva in December.
('97', 98, 8, 22, 210057) 2 According to a Reuter report, dated “Lake Success, October 18”, the letter was published in the United Nations’ Weekly Bulletin of October 17. 3 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 26 10 1947. 4 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 26 9 1947 and “Hindustani”, 27 9 1947.
('97', 99, 0, 1, 210347) 100 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 99, 1, 2, 210389) It is my firm opinion that the rule that applies to the Muslims of the Union must in the same circumstances apply to the Hindus and other non Muslims of Pakistan.
('97', 99, 1, 3, 210552) I have expressed this view in my after prayer speeches as also in my talks with friends here.
('97', 99, 1, 4, 210646) Of course, behind the opinion lies a train of reasoning.
('97', 99, 1, 5, 210703) Loyalty cannot be evoked to order.
('97', 99, 1, 6, 210738) If circumstances do not warrant it, it may be said to be impossible to achieve.
('97', 99, 1, 7, 210818) There is a large number of people who do not believe in the possibility of such genuine loyalty and hence laugh at my opinion.
('97', 99, 1, 8, 210945) Surely there is nothing to laugh at in conceiving such a possibility.
('97', 99, 1, 9, 211015) The Muslims of the Union will fight those of Pakistan when they regard it as a duty, in other words, when it is clear to them that they are being fairly treated in the Union and that the non Muslims are not so treated in Pakistan.
('97', 99, 1, 10, 211246) Such a state is not beyond the range of possibility.
('97', 99, 1, 11, 211299) Similarly if the non Muslims of Pakistan clearly feel that they are being fairly treated there and that they can reside there in safety and yet the Hindus of the Union maltreat the minorities, the minorities of Pakistan will naturally fight the majority in the Union.
('97', 99, 1, 12, 211567) Then the minorities will not need any argument to induce them to do their duty.
('97', 99, 1, 13, 211647) It was our misfortune that the country was divided into two parts.
('97', 99, 1, 14, 211714) The division was avowedly by reason of religious cleavage.
('97', 99, 1, 15, 211773) Behind it might be economic and other causes.
('97', 99, 1, 16, 211819) They could not have brought out the cleavage.
('97', 99, 1, 17, 211865) The poison that fills the air arose also from the same communal cause.
('97', 99, 1, 18, 211936) Irreligion masquerades as religion.
('97', 99, 1, 19, 211972) It sounds nice to say that it would have been better if there had been no communal question.
('97', 99, 1, 20, 212065) But how could the fact be undone?
('97', 99, 1, 21, 212099) It has been repeatedly asked whether in the event of a war between the two, the Muslims of the Union will fight against the Muslims of Pakistan and the Hindus of one against those of the other.
('97', 99, 1, 22, 212293) However unlikely it may appear at present, there is nothing inherently impossible in the conception.
('97', 99, 1, 23, 212394) There is any day more risk in distrusting the profession of loyalty than in trusting it and courageously facing the danger of trusting.
('97', 99, 1, 24, 212530) The question can be more convincingly put in this way: Will the Hindus ever fight the Hindus and the Muslims their co religionists for the sake of truth and justice?
('97', 99, 1, 25, 212696) It can be answered by a counter question: Does not history provide such instances ?
('97', 99, 1, 26, 212780) In solving the puzzle the great stumbling block in the way is
('97', 100, 0, 1, 212842) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 101
('97', 100, 1, 2, 212892) that truth is at a discount.
('97', 100, 1, 3, 212921) Let us hope that in this holocaust, there are some who will stand firm in their faith in the victory of truth.
('97', 100, 2, 4, 213032) NEW DELHI, October 17, 1947 Harijan, 26 10 1947
('97', 100, 3, 5, 213080) 84. LETTER TO CHAMAN KAVI
('97', 100, 4, 6, 213106) NEW DELHI, October 17, 1947
('97', 100, 5, 7, 213134) BHAI CHAMAN KAVI,
('97', 100, 6, 8, 213152) You seem to be after me.
('97', 100, 6, 9, 213177) Your letter went to Pyarelal.
('97', 100, 6, 10, 213207) He is in Noakhali.
('97', 100, 6, 11, 213226) I keep moving about.
('97', 100, 6, 12, 213247) Your letter therefore, after much wandering, reached me only yesterday.
('97', 100, 6, 13, 213319) You are far away.
('97', 100, 6, 14, 213337) You do not know the situation here.
('97', 100, 6, 15, 213373) I have been away from the Ashram for a long time.
('97', 100, 6, 16, 213423) I went away to Bihar, leaving Pyarelal in Noakhali.
('97', 100, 6, 17, 213475) You do not know all this and yet you indulge in wild guesses.
('97', 100, 6, 18, 213537) Pyarelal has already written to you.
('97', 100, 6, 19, 213574) Do you know where I was, where Pyarelal was, after Mahadev passed away?
('97', 100, 6, 20, 213646) Do you know that from the prison I wrote letters to no one?
('97', 100, 6, 21, 213706) After my release from jail 1 I was ill for some time and as soon as I was a little better I started my incessant touring.
('97', 100, 6, 22, 213828) If, therefore, I have failed to cope with some of your letters, it is nobody’s fault; only the circumstances are to blame.
('97', 100, 6, 23, 213951) It is only your latest letter that makes me aware that you are a Muslim.
('97', 100, 6, 24, 214024) Nonetheless this awareness will be only momentary.
('97', 100, 6, 25, 214075) What more can I write?
('97', 100, 6, 26, 214098) There is nothing worth writing about.
('97', 100, 6, 27, 214136) What can I say about the atmosphere which is full of poison?
('97', 100, 6, 28, 214197) Let us all pray.
('97', 100, 6, 29, 214214) My resolve is to ‘do or die’.
('97', 100, 6, 30, 214244) The Lord, our Master, is there to see me through it.
('97', 100, 6, 31, 214297) Noone can undo what He has willed.
('97', 100, 6, 32, 214332) Won’t you now have a hearty laugh?
('97', 100, 7, 33, 214367) From a copy of the Gujarati: Pyarelal Papers.

('97', 101, 0, 1, 214449) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 101, 1, 2, 214491) 85. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS 1
('97', 101, 2, 3, 214520) October 17, 1947 2
('97', 101, 3, 4, 214539) Q. In case the UNO fails to do justice by the Indians in South Africa, what line of action would you advise the South African Indians to take?
('97', 101, 4, 5, 214682) A. I cannot even think of failure in satyagraha.
('97', 101, 4, 6, 214731) It never fails.
('97', 101, 4, 7, 214747) This is my firm belief.
('97', 101, 5, 8, 214771) What effect do you think the failure of the UNO to deal justly with the South African Indian dispute will have on the future of that organization?
('97', 101, 5, 9, 214918) If the UNO fails to deal justly with the South African Indian dispute, the UNO will lose its prestige.
('97', 101, 5, 10, 215021) I have no doubt that the UNO can prosper only if it is just.
('97', 101, 6, 11, 215082) And what will be the effect of the failure on the world?
('97', 101, 6, 12, 215139) About the effect on the world no one knows.
('97', 101, 6, 13, 215183) At least I do not.
('97', 101, 7, 14, 215202) Racial inequality must be removed if there is to be peace in the world.
('97', 101, 7, 15, 215274) What is your advice to those who agree with this but do nothing to fight the evil of racial inequality?
('97', 101, 7, 16, 215378) Those who agree that racial inequality must be removed and yet do nothing to fight the evil are impotent.
('97', 101, 7, 17, 215484) I cannot have anything to say to such people.
('97', 101, 7, 18, 215530) After all the underdogs will have to earn their own salvation.
('97', 101, 8, 19, 215593) What remedy do you propose for the elimination of racial prejudice and antagonism from the affairs of mankind?
('97', 101, 8, 20, 215704) The solution is largely in India’s hands.
('97', 101, 8, 21, 215746) If everything is all right in India internally, she is likely to play an effective part in straightening out affairs.

('97', 106, 4, 13, 226847) 87. NOTES
('97', 106, 5, 14, 226857) TRUE ADULT EDUCATION Of all the numerous letters and telegrams received for the Charkha Jayanti, a letter in Hindustani received from the Indore Adult Education Association most arrested my attention.
('97', 106, 5, 15, 227058) The purport of it is that the Association in question instead of wasting time in performing some flattering function, devoted the Jayanti week to doing urgent and useful work, i.e., young and old, rich and poor, official, and non official, banded together in destroying a noxious weed harmful to man and beast.
('97', 106, 5, 16, 227369) If such co operation became the abiding feature of any locality, it would constitute the best education for young and old and change the face of the society in which it was done.
('97', 106, 6, 17, 227548) SEASONABLE QUOTATIONS From among letters and telegrams received during my little fast in Calcutta in September last, I kept the following for the Harijan.
('97', 106, 6, 18, 227703) It is from Prof.
('97', 106, 6, 19, 227720) Horace Alexander.

('97', 106, 7, 23, 227998) I am reminded of two sayings: From Browning: “To dry one’s eyes and laugh at a fall, And baffled, get up and begin again, So the chase takes up one’s life, that’s all.” And from the Old Testament: “Though He slay me, yet I will trust Him.”

('97', 129, 5, 13, 267801) NEW DELHI, October 21, 1947
('97', 129, 6, 14, 267829) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 129, 7, 15, 267851) Today also I heard of an incident.
('97', 129, 7, 16, 267886) In this it was not a Muslim who was killed but a Hindu.
('97', 129, 7, 17, 267942) He was a Government employee.
('97', 129, 7, 18, 267972) He was doing his duty where he had been sent when somebody shot at him.
('97', 129, 7, 19, 268044) I have not heard that he had committed any crime.
('97', 129, 7, 20, 268094) The man with the revolver felt that the victim did not do what he was told and so he killed him.

('97', 129, 7, 26, 268543) Similarly a man makes an officer his aim.
('97', 129, 7, 27, 268585) That officer had received orders to carry out a certain task at the place.
('97', 129, 7, 28, 268660) But the killer had a fancy to kill him.
('97', 129, 7, 29, 268700) If we continue like this, we are going to land ourselves in a terrible situation.
('97', 129, 7, 30, 268782) No man can then live in peace.
('97', 129, 7, 31, 268813) It is said that there are many countries inhabited by savages where no one can live in safety because those who posses arms murder people and they have no qualms about it.
('97', 129, 7, 32, 268985) The one who kills a person cannot bring him back to life.
('97', 129, 7, 33, 269043) This is a fact.

('97', 129, 7, 38, 269257) But the Hindus desire to pounce upon the Muslims and the Muslims want to pounce upon the Sikhs and the Sikhs want to jump at the Muslims.

('97', 134, 9, 22, 278348) No sin could be greater than this.

('97', 134, 9, 29, 278684) For this is the only non violent way to battle with the terrible violence that confronts us.

('97', 134, 9, 31, 278814) But that is no reason to believe that non violence is ineffective.

('97', 142, 1, 2, 292962) 131. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 142, 2, 3, 292992) NEW DELHI, October 23, 1947
('97', 142, 3, 4, 293020) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 142, 4, 5, 293042) Two persons have written to me “We are refugees.
('97', 142, 4, 6, 293091) We are living under the protection of our friends.
('97', 142, 4, 7, 293142) We are very much troubled on account of the cold weather.
('97', 142, 4, 8, 293200) Kindly let us know from where we can get blankets and quilts.
('97', 142, 4, 9, 293262) Is there any such provision for refugees?” They say they belong to Rawalpindi.
('97', 142, 4, 10, 293341) Like that there are innumerable people.
('97', 142, 4, 11, 293381) However, the quilts and blankets are actually being collected for the people accommodated in the refugee camps, and who as is very evident have nothing to cover themselves with.
('97', 142, 4, 12, 293559) Hence provision is being made for them.
('97', 142, 4, 13, 293599) Quite a large stock has been distributed and more will be distributed.
('97', 142, 4, 14, 293670) These are not just a handful of people.
('97', 142, 4, 15, 293710) They are there in thousands.
('97', 142, 4, 16, 293739) Quite likely, there are lakhs and lakhs of such people who should get these things.
('97', 142, 4, 17, 293823) One of the camps at Kurukshetra has been taken over by the Central Govenment.
('97', 142, 4, 18, 293901) A large number of people are accommodated there and many more keep coming.
('97', 142, 4, 19, 293976) There are many such camps even in the city of Delhi.

('97', 142, 4, 22, 294169) They too are refugees.

('97', 144, 1, 19, 299059) How it is caused is a long story.
('97', 144, 1, 20, 299093) I believe it is disease of the body and there is no difference between leprosy and cough.
('97', 144, 1, 21, 299183) A victim of leprosy suffers more pain and when he starts losing his thumbs, hands and nose, he becomes really very ugly.
('97', 144, 1, 22, 299304) But it is not that he suffer more pain because he becomes ugly.
('97', 144, 1, 23, 299368) I would say that we should have greater contempt for people who have wicked hearts.
('97', 144, 1, 24, 299452) A person who has an unclean body which is the result of an unclean mind and who has a perverse outlook, instead of listening to the bhajans is interested in listening to the stories of wicked men, is a real leper.
('97', 144, 1, 25, 299666) There are countless people suffering from this disease, and nobody ever bother about them.
('97', 144, 1, 26, 299757) But since everybody does not contract the disease of leprosy, we are repelled by those who have it.

('97', 146, 3, 7, 303258) 133. WHITHER AHIMSA, WHITHER KHADI?
('97', 146, 4, 8, 303294) A correspondent from Kathiawar writes:
('97', 146, 5, 9, 303333) As in many other districts or provinces so in Kathiawar people are fast losing their faith in khadi and ahimsa.
('97', 146, 5, 10, 303445) Many Congressmen and Gandhians have begun to ask how non violence can work in matters political.
('97', 146, 5, 11, 303542) The writer of the letter adduces a number of arguments giving illustrations.
('97', 146, 5, 12, 303619) I have, however, satisfied myself with qouting the salient part of the letter.
('97', 146, 5, 13, 303698) It contains three errors.
('97', 146, 5, 14, 303724) I have been explaining of late that neither in Kathiawar nor in other parts of India have people real faith in non violence or khadi.
('97', 146, 5, 15, 303858) It is true that I had deceived myself into believing that people were wedded to non violence with khadi as its symbol.
('97', 146, 5, 16, 303977) As a matter of fact, in the name of non violence people manifested only the outward peaceableness of the impotent.
('97', 146, 5, 17, 304092) They never even attempted to drive violence from their hearts.
('97', 146, 5, 18, 304155) He who runs can see for himself the verification of this fact.
('97', 146, 5, 19, 304218) It had become patent to everyone, when I went to Rajkot in connection with the Rajkot imbroglio, that there was no Rama in Rajkot and, therefore, Kathiawar.
('97', 146, 5, 20, 304375) Hence it is hardly correct to say that their faith is only now beginning to wane.
('97', 146, 5, 21, 304457) It is equally improper to question now the efficacy of non violence in matters political.
('97', 146, 5, 22, 304547) What was the people’s fight against the foreign power, if it was not a political matter?
('97', 146, 5, 23, 304636) Indeed, the disgraceful fight between brother and brother that we are wit nessing today is much less political.
('97', 146, 5, 24, 304748) Today, irreligion is stalking the country in the name of religion.
('97', 146, 5, 25, 304815) Even the outward peace that we were able to observe
('97', 146, 6, 26, 304867) 1 The message reported under the date line: “Peshawar, October 24”.
('97', 146, 6, 27, 304935) 2 A translation of this also appeared in Harijan, 2 11 1947.
('97', 147, 0, 1, 304996) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 147, 1, 2, 305038) in the fight against the foreign power is conspicuous by its absence today.
('97', 147, 1, 3, 305114) The third error consist in the distinction the correspondent makes between Congressmen and Gandhians.
('97', 147, 1, 4, 305216) The distinction is baseless.
('97', 147, 1, 5, 305245) If there is any Gandhian, it must be I. I am not so arrogant as to make any such claim.
('97', 147, 1, 6, 305333) A Gandhian means a worshipper of Gandhi.
('97', 147, 1, 7, 305374) Only God has worshippers.
('97', 147, 1, 8, 305400) I have never claimed to be God.
('97', 147, 1, 9, 305432) How then can I have worshippers?
('97', 147, 1, 10, 305465) Moreover, how can it be said that those who call themselves Gandhians are not Congressmen?
('97', 147, 1, 11, 305556) There are innumerable servants of the Congress although they are not four anna members registered in the Congress register.
('97', 147, 1, 12, 305680) The reader should know that I myself belong to that category.
('97', 147, 1, 13, 305742) Hence the distinction made is false.
('97', 147, 1, 14, 305779) I have repeatedly said that I have neither any part nor any say in many things that are going on in the country today.
('97', 147, 1, 15, 305898) It is no secret that the Congress willingly said good bye to non violence when it accepted power.
('97', 147, 1, 16, 305996) Again I believe that the method of rationing of food and clothing is highly injurious to the country.
('97', 147, 1, 17, 306098) If I had my way, I would not buy a grain of food stuff from outside India.
('97', 147, 1, 18, 306173) It is my firm belief that even today there is enough food in the country.
('97', 147, 1, 19, 306247) It has been hidden because of the rationing.
('97', 147, 1, 20, 306292) Again, if people followed me, there would be no deadly quarrel between Hindus, Sikhs and Muslims.
('97', 147, 1, 21, 306390) It is clear that my writ does not run any longer.
('97', 147, 1, 22, 306440) Mine is a voice in the wilderness.
('97', 147, 1, 23, 306475) As for khadi, it has some kind of a place, if we separate it from ahimsa.
('97', 147, 1, 24, 306549) But it does not have the pride of place it would have had as a symbol of ahimsa.
('97', 147, 1, 25, 306630) Those who are in the political field wear khadi as a matter of convention.
('97', 147, 1, 26, 306705) Today we see the triumph not of khadi but of mill cloth, for we have assumed that but for the manufactures from our mills, millions would have to go naked.
('97', 147, 1, 27, 306861) Can there be a greater delusion than this?
('97', 147, 1, 28, 306904) We grow enough cotton in the country.
('97', 147, 1, 29, 306942) We have any number of handlooms and spinning wheels.
('97', 147, 1, 30, 306995) India is not unused to the art of hand spining and hand weaving, but somehow or other the fear has seized us that the millions will not take to hand spinning and weaving hand spun yarn for their own needs.
('97', 147, 1, 31, 307201) A haunted man sees fear even when there is no cause for it.
('97', 147, 1, 32, 307261) And many more die of fright than of the actual disease.
