('97', 152, 4, 8, 315550) 139. OF NEW UNIVERSITIES 1
('97', 152, 5, 9, 315577) There seems to be a mania for establishing new universities in the provinces.
('97', 152, 5, 10, 315655) Gujarat wants one for Gujarati, Maharashtra for Marathi, Karnataka for Kannada, Orissa for Oriya, Assam for Assamese and what not.
('97', 152, 5, 11, 315786) I do believe that there should be such universities if these rich provincial languages and the people who speak them are to attain their full height.
('97', 152, 5, 12, 315936) At the same time I fear that we betray ourselves into undue haste in accomplishing the object.
('97', 152, 5, 13, 316031) The first stop should be linguistic political redistribution of provinces.
('97', 152, 5, 14, 316106) Their separate administration will naturally lead to the establishment of universities where there are none.
('97', 152, 5, 15, 316215) The province of Bombay absorbs three languages : Gujarati, Marathi and Kannada and, therefore, stunts their growth.
('97', 152, 5, 16, 316331) Madras absorbs four : Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam and Kannada.
('97', 152, 5, 17, 316391) Thus, there is overlapping also.
('97', 152, 5, 18, 316424) That Andhra Desha has an Andhra University is true.
('97', 152, 5, 19, 316476) I my opinion it does not occupy the place it would, if Andhra was a separate administrative unit, free from foreign control;.
('97', 152, 5, 20, 316602) India attained that freedom only two months ago.
('97', 152, 5, 21, 316651) The same thing can be said of the Annamalai University.
('97', 152, 5, 22, 316707) Who can say that Tamil has come to its own in that University ?
('97', 152, 5, 23, 316771) There should be a proper background for new universities.
('97', 152, 5, 24, 316829) They should have feeders in the shape of schools and colleges which will impart instruction through the medium of their respective provincial languages.
('97', 152, 5, 25, 316982) Then only can there be a proper milieu.
('97', 152, 5, 26, 317022) University is at the top.
('97', 152, 5, 27, 317048) A majestic top can only be sustained if there is a sound foundation.
('97', 152, 5, 28, 317117) Though we are politically free, we are hardly free from the subtle domination of the West.
('97', 152, 5, 29, 317208) I have nothing to say to that school of politicians who believe that knowledge can only come from the West.
('97', 152, 5, 30, 317316) Nor do I subscribe to the belief that nothing good can come out of
('97', 152, 6, 31, 317383) 1 A Gujarati version of this appeared in Harijanbandhu, 2 11 1947.
('97', 153, 0, 1, 317450) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 153, 1, 2, 317492) the West.
('97', 153, 1, 3, 317502) I do fear, however, that we are unable as yet to come to a correct decision in the matter.
('97', 153, 1, 4, 317593) It is to be hoped that no one contends that because we seem to be politically free from foreign domination, the mere fact gives us freedom from the more subtle influence of the foreign language and foreign thought.
('97', 153, 1, 5, 317808) Is it not wisdom, does not duty to the country dictate, that before we embark on new universities we should stop and fill our own lungs with the ozone of our newly got freedom ?
('97', 153, 1, 6, 317986) A university never needs a pile of majestic buildings and treasures of gold and silver.
('97', 153, 1, 7, 318074) What it does need most of all is the intelligent backing of public opinion.
('97', 153, 1, 8, 318150) It should have a large reservoir of teachers to draw upon.
('97', 153, 1, 9, 318209) Its founders should be farseeing.
('97', 153, 1, 10, 318243) In my opinion it is not for a democratic State to find money for founding universities.
('97', 153, 1, 11, 318331) If the people want them they will supply the funds.
('97', 153, 1, 12, 318383) Universities so founded will adorn the country which they represent.
('97', 153, 1, 13, 318452) Where administration is in foreign hands, whatever comes to the people comes from top and thus they become more and more dependent.
('97', 153, 1, 14, 318584) Where it is broad based on popular will, everything goes from bottom upward and hence it lasts.
('97', 153, 1, 15, 318680) It is good looking and strengthens the people.
('97', 153, 1, 16, 318727) In such a democratic scheme money invested in the promotion of learning gives a tenfold return to the people even as a seed sown in good soil returns a luxuriant crop.
('97', 153, 1, 17, 318895) Universities founded under foreign domination have run in the reverse direction.
('97', 153, 1, 18, 318976) Any other result was perhaps impossible.
('97', 153, 1, 19, 319017) Therefore, there is every reason for being cautious about founding new universities till India has digested the newly acquired freedom.
('97', 153, 1, 20, 319153) Then take the Hindu Muslim question.
('97', 153, 1, 21, 319190) The poison has assumed such dangerous proportions, that it is difficult to forecast where it will land us.
('97', 153, 1, 22, 319297) Assume that the unthinkable has happened and that not a single Muslim can remain in the Union safely and honourably and that neither Hindu nor Sikh can do likewise in Pakistan.
('97', 153, 1, 23, 319474) Our education will then wear a poisonous form.
('97', 153, 1, 24, 319521) If, on the other hand, Hindus, Muslims and all the others who may belong to different faiths can live in either Dominion with perfect safety and honour, then in the nature of things out education will take a shape altogether pleasing.
('97', 153, 1, 25, 319756) Either people of different faiths having lived together in friendship have produced a beautiful blend of cultures, which we shall strive to perpetuate and increasingly strengthen, or we shall cast about for the day when there was only one religion represented in Hindustan and retrace our steps to that exclusive culture.
('97', 153, 1, 26, 320078) It is just possible that we might not be able to find any such historical date and if we do aand
('97', 154, 0, 1, 320175) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 155
('97', 154, 1, 2, 320225) we retrace our steps, we shall throw our culture back to that ugly period and deservedly earn the execration of the universe.
('97', 154, 1, 3, 320351) By way of example, if we make the vain attempt of obliterating the Muslim period, we shall have to forget that there was a mighty Jama Masjid in Delhi second to none in the world, or that there was a Muslim University in Aligarh, or that there was the Taj in Agra, one of the seven wonders of the world, or that there were the great forts of Delhi and Agra built during the Mughal period.
('97', 154, 1, 4, 320740) We shall then have to rewrite our history with that end in view.
('97', 154, 1, 5, 320805) Surely today we have not the atmosphere which will enable us to come to a right conclusion about the conflicting choices.
('97', 154, 1, 6, 320927) Our two months old freedom is struggling to get itself shaped.
('97', 154, 1, 7, 320990) We do not know what shape it will ultimately take.
('97', 154, 1, 8, 321041) Until we know this definitely, it should be enough if we make such changes as are possible in the existing universities and breathe into our existing educational institutions the quickening spirit of freedom.
('97', 154, 1, 9, 321250) The experience we will thus gain will be helpful when the time is ripe for founding new universities.
('97', 154, 1, 10, 321352) Last but not least remains Basic Education.
('97', 154, 1, 11, 321396) It is an infant not more than eight years old.
('97', 154, 1, 12, 321443) Therefore actual experience does not take us beyond what may be termed the matriculation stagte.
('97', 154, 1, 13, 321540) Thus, though it is limited in scope, the mind of those who are engaged in making the experiment has grown far beyond that stage.
('97', 154, 1, 14, 321669) It would be unwise for any educationist to put aside the recommendations of a body which has behind it the solid experience of eight years.
('97', 154, 1, 15, 321809) It should be borne in mind that this Basic Education has grown out of the atmosphere surrounding us in the country and is in response to it.
('97', 154, 1, 16, 321950) It is, therefore, designed to cope with that atmosphere.
('97', 154, 1, 17, 322007) This atmosphere pervades India’s seven hundred thousand villages and its millions of inhabitants.
('97', 154, 1, 18, 322105) Forget them and you forget India.
('97', 154, 1, 19, 322139) India is not to be found in her cities.
('97', 154, 1, 20, 322179) It is in her innumerable villages.
('97', 154, 1, 21, 322214) The cities rose in answer to the requirements of foreign domination.
('97', 154, 1, 22, 322283) They exist as they were two months ago, for though foreign rule has disappeared, its influence has not and cannot quite so suddenly.
('97', 154, 1, 23, 322416) Thus I am writing these lines in New Delhi.
('97', 154, 1, 24, 322460) If I know nothing of the villages of India how can I draw, sitting here, a true picture of the villages ?
('97', 154, 1, 25, 322566) What applies to me applies more forcibly to the ministers.
('97', 154, 1, 26, 322625) Let us now glance at the fundamentals of Basic Education : 1. All education to be true must be self supporting, that is to say, in the end it will pay its expenses excepting the capital which will
('97', 155, 0, 1, 322822) 156 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 155, 1, 2, 322864) remain intact.
('97', 155, 1, 3, 322879) 2. In it the cunning of the hand will be utilized even up to the final stage, that is to say, the hands of the pupils will be skillfully working at some industry for some period during the day.
('97', 155, 1, 4, 323073) 3. All education must be imparted through the medium of the provincial language.
('97', 155, 1, 5, 323154) 4. In this there is no room for giving sectional religious training.
('97', 155, 1, 6, 323223) Fundamental universal ethics will have full scope.
('97', 155, 1, 7, 323274) 5. This education, whether it is confined to children or adults, male or female, will find its way to the homes of the pupils.
('97', 155, 1, 8, 323401) 6. Since millions of students receiving this education will consider themselves as of the whole of India, they must learn an inter provincial language.
('97', 155, 1, 9, 323553) This common inter provincial speech can only be Hindustani written in the Nagari or Urdu script.
('97', 155, 1, 10, 323650) Therefore pupils have to master both the scripts.
('97', 155, 1, 11, 323700) Therefore, it is hoped that all educationists will come to the conclusion that judicious delay is necessary for founding new universities.

('97', 156, 2, 3, 324549) BIRLA HOUSE, NEW DELHI, October 25, 1947
('97', 156, 3, 4, 324590) The communists have got hold of something to keep themselves busy.
('97', 156, 3, 5, 324657) Hardly one man in a thousand can be found who practises communism in everyday life.
('97', 156, 3, 6, 324741) Communists have come to consider it their supreme duty, their supreme service, to create disaffection, to generate discontent and to organize strikes.
('97', 156, 3, 7, 324892) They do not see whom this discontent, these strikes, will ultimately harm.
('97', 156, 3, 8, 324967) Half knowledge is one of the worst evils.
('97', 156, 3, 9, 325009) The best is either full knowledge or ignorance.
('97', 156, 3, 10, 325057) We are thus caught in isms and take pride in them and consider it a fashion to belong to this or that ism.
('97', 156, 3, 11, 325164) People seek knowledge and instruction from Russia.
('97', 156, 3, 12, 325215) Our communists seem to be in this pitiable state.
('97', 156, 3, 13, 325265) I call it a pitiable rather than shameful state, for I feel that they are to be pitied, rather than blamed.
('97', 156, 3, 14, 325373) For, because of our slavery, they have had no opportunity to get full knowledge.
('97', 156, 3, 15, 325454) And now when we have got our freedom everybody has got an opportunity to thrust himself forward to such an extent that a sixteen year old boy or girl can identify himself or herself with some ism and become a leader.
('97', 156, 3, 16, 325671) These people have now been fanning the fire of disunity bequeathed to us by the British.
('97', 156, 3, 17, 325760) Soon they will find that they cannot control the flames.
('97', 156, 3, 18, 325817) What we have to do is to find out what will suit our ignorant masses and act accordingly.
('97', 156, 3, 19, 325907) For instance we need foodgrain.
('97', 156, 3, 20, 325939) If the youth of the country would only learn the techniques of farming and engaged themselves in producing more food they would have no time for quarrelling and the country would become prosperous.

('97', 157, 1, 2, 326220) 142. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 157, 2, 3, 326250) NEW DELHI October 25, 1947
('97', 157, 3, 4, 326277) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 157, 4, 5, 326299) I was very happy when I received the invitation to hold the prayer before the prisoners of this jail and to address them in my usual manner, after the prayer.
('97', 157, 4, 6, 326458) All the prisoners are probably not aware that I am myself an old time prisoner right from my days in South Africa.
('97', 157, 4, 7, 326573) I was not guilty from my point of view; but from the point of view of the Empire I was guilty.
('97', 157, 4, 8, 326668) I have served all kinds of imprisonments and I have seen many jails.
('97', 157, 4, 9, 326737) Jail rules in South Africa are very strict.
('97', 157, 4, 10, 326781) And then the Indians count for nothing there.
('97', 157, 4, 11, 326827) Even if one was a barrister, it made no difference.
('97', 157, 4, 12, 326879) All Indians were considered coolies.
('97', 157, 4, 13, 326916) There were the Indians on the one hand and Negroes on the other, and then the British—all living in their own worlds.
('97', 157, 4, 14, 327034) When the satyagraha started 1, thousands of satyagrahis joined it, for in a satyagraha there would not be just a couple of persons.
('97', 157, 4, 15, 327166) At the time of my first imprisonment 2 150 of us were taken prisoners.
('97', 157, 4, 16, 327237) In the beginning there were not many people.
('97', 157, 4, 17, 327282) I was there and four or five others were with me; but in due course our number grew to 150. We were all packed together in one ward along with the natives.
('97', 157, 4, 18, 327438) We got quite fed up because of such crowding.
('97', 157, 4, 19, 327484) I would like to tell you how strict the jail rules were and how ruthlessly they were observed.
('97', 157, 4, 20, 327579) Here in India we make much fuss by making a distinction between political prisoners and criminals.
('97', 157, 4, 21, 327678) No such distinction is made in South Africa.
('97', 157, 4, 22, 327723) All prisoners are regarded as criminals there.
('97', 157, 4, 23, 327770) I do not believe that among the prisoners political prisoners belong to a higher category and criminal prisoners belong to a lower category.
('97', 157, 4, 24, 327911) In the eyes of the law, all those who have broken it are equally guilty.
('97', 157, 4, 25, 327984) Why then distinguish between the guilty ones?
('97', 157, 4, 26, 328030) But here we were not only political prisoners, but even belonged to A, B and C categories.
('97', 157, 4, 27, 328121) Was it not because ours was a mighty struggle?
('97', 157, 4, 28, 328168) We were millions in the field and among us there were also some big people.
('97', 157, 4, 29, 328244) But who was big among those poor creatures there?
('97', 157, 4, 30, 328294) They were all small business men.
('97', 157, 4, 31, 328328) There were Hindus, Muslims, Parsis and others.
('97', 157, 4, 32, 328375) Nobody made any

('97', 158, 1, 2, 328521) distinction between Hindus, Muslims or Parsis.

('97', 158, 1, 4, 328616) So we could not even pose to be big and insist on being put in A category and those who were lower in B and the lowest in C category.
('97', 158, 1, 5, 328750) I do not even believe in these divisions.
('97', 158, 1, 6, 328792) But here we did all that.
('97', 158, 1, 7, 328818) I believe that anyone who goes to prison is a prisoner.
('97', 158, 1, 8, 328874) I do not believe that a prisoner alone has committed a crime and that those who are outside, well dressed people, are not guilty.
('97', 158, 1, 9, 329004) I have been incarcerated ten times.
('97', 158, 1, 10, 329040) 1 I do not remember exactly, but I have spent quite a few years in prison and so I know about these things.
('97', 158, 1, 11, 329148) The jail superintendents and others had become my friends.
('97', 158, 1, 12, 329207) There used to be a superintendent who was a very good man and a great jailer.
('97', 158, 1, 13, 329285) He once told me that he had been in charge of prisoners but the world had no idea of the crimes he had committed himself.
('97', 158, 1, 14, 329407) He told me that the prisoners under him had come to spend their four or five years of imprisonment or they had come with death sentences which had been later condoned.
('97', 158, 1, 15, 329575) But he woundered how many ever knew the crimes he had committed.
('97', 158, 1, 16, 329640) He said perhaps God alone knew about his crimes.
('97', 158, 1, 17, 329689) So he did not relish the idea that he should be the chief jailer and those others should be prisoners.

('97', 158, 1, 19, 329825) So I wondered with what attitude I should come and meet you.
('97', 158, 1, 20, 329886) The British rule has now ended.
('97', 158, 1, 21, 329918) They have withdrawn themselves.

('97', 158, 1, 23, 329979) But what should we do with our prisons now?
('97', 158, 1, 24, 330023) I have been a witness to the conditions that prevailed in the jails during the British days and I know very well how good or bad they were.
('97', 158, 1, 25, 330163) But now that the Government is in our own hands, our prisons, far from remaining prisons, should become hospitals.
('97', 158, 1, 26, 330278) If somebody has committed a murder or a theft or turned an outlaw, or committed any of the crimes mentioned in law books, I consider all these to be a kind of disease.
('97', 158, 1, 27, 330446) It is a malady.
('97', 158, 1, 28, 330462) No one commits a crime for its own sake.

('97', 159, 1, 4, 331259) The prisoners should be taught how they should live.
('97', 159, 1, 5, 331312) The superintendent and the deputy commissioner take care of the prisoners and order that such and such a prisoner should be flogged or such and such a prisoner should do a particular work by way of punishment.

('97', 159, 1, 22, 332851) When a patient leaves the hospital after recovering from an illness, he feels for ever grateful.
('97', 159, 1, 23, 332948) The same thing should happen in our prisons.
('97', 159, 1, 24, 332993) Let the prisoners have no ground to complain about the harsh treatment and atrocities in prisons or about the wickedness of the superintendents and jailers.
('97', 159, 1, 25, 333150) Let them not get a chance to say that everything was bad.
('97', 159, 1, 26, 333208) Let them say that they were looked after as if in a hospital, were fed properly and taught how to lead a good life.
('97', 159, 1, 27, 333324) I have already said what the people in charge of the prisons should do.
('97', 159, 1, 28, 333396) But ultimately it is not in their hands to do that.
('97', 159, 1, 29, 333448) It is for the Government to decide.

('97', 159, 1, 31, 333589) But the Government must tell the prison authorities that this is how they should behave.

('97', 160, 1, 2, 333809) another matter.
('97', 160, 1, 3, 333825) No criminal should be a jailer or superintendent or a commissioner these days.
('97', 160, 1, 4, 333904) We have at least learnt this and they all work under the Government.

('97', 160, 1, 6, 334077) They willingly obey the orders of their Government.
('97', 160, 1, 7, 334129) Our entire administration would collapse if they did not carry out orders willingly and there would be chaos in the country.

('97', 160, 1, 13, 334566) If they did this much, at least one thing would be accomplished.
('97', 160, 1, 14, 334631) Now I wish to address myself to the prisoners as a prisoner.
('97', 160, 1, 15, 334692) I have also been imprisoned as a satyagrahi.
('97', 160, 1, 16, 334737) A satyagrahi prisoner cannot indulge in a deliberate crime.
('97', 160, 1, 17, 334797) He would never harass the jail superintendent or the jailer, or insult them.
('97', 160, 1, 18, 334874) He has to be an ideal prisoner.
('97', 160, 1, 19, 334906) Then only can he carry on his satyagraha well.

('97', 160, 1, 21, 335055) They should never defy the jail rules.
('97', 160, 1, 22, 335094) They should accept the restrictions of prison life and be content with what they get.
('97', 160, 1, 23, 335180) If the food given to the prisoners is not sufficient or properly cooked or is found to contain extraneous substances like grit and worms, they should complain to the superintendent or the jailer.
('97', 160, 1, 24, 335376) These things do happen.

('97', 160, 1, 26, 335467) But even for these things why should the jail officials be approached?
('97', 160, 1, 27, 335538) These things are in the hands of the prisoners themselves, for there are no professional cooks in prisons.
('97', 160, 1, 28, 335645) The Government cannot manage the prisons if they start keeping cooks.
('97', 160, 1, 29, 335715) The prisoners themselves are made to cook.
('97', 160, 1, 30, 335758) Let them do the job with their hearts in it.
('97', 160, 1, 31, 335803) Let them cook rice after cleaning it well and let them not keep chapatis half baked.
('97', 160, 1, 32, 335888) All that is in your own hands.
('97', 160, 1, 33, 335919) You must do this work as if you were doing it in your own homes.
('97', 160, 1, 34, 335984) You have come here after committing some crimes.
('97', 160, 1, 35, 336033) Anyone can commit a crime.

('97', 161, 1, 2, 336463) Today a kind of poison has spread in our country.

('97', 162, 5, 11, 338829) 145. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING NEW DELHI October 26, 1947
('97', 162, 6, 12, 338886) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 162, 7, 13, 338908) At the outset I would like to reply to a gentleman’s question.
('97', 162, 7, 14, 338971) He says: “You say that it is not good to harbour feeling of revenge.
('97', 162, 7, 15, 339040) But don’t your followers who are devotees of Rama excite the feeling of revenge by burning Ravana’s effigy?” There are two fallacies in this.
('97', 162, 7, 16, 339182) First of all, who are my followers?
('97', 162, 7, 17, 339218) I do not even know about them.
('97', 162, 7, 18, 339249) I should like to be a devotee of Rama.
('97', 162, 7, 19, 339288) But I am not sure that I am.
('97', 162, 7, 20, 339317) After all it is no easy thing to be a devotee or Rama.
('97', 162, 7, 21, 339372) Hence it is wrong to refer to any devotees as my followers.
('97', 162, 7, 22, 339432) I do not have any followers at all.
('97', 162, 7, 23, 339468) But what happens is that people make an effigy of Ravana who is defeated by Rama.
('97', 162, 7, 24, 339550) Thus we saw Rama vanquishing Ravana.
('97', 162, 7, 25, 339587) But who amongst us is Rama and who is Ravana?
('97', 162, 7, 26, 339633) If every man can become Rama, who would become Ravana?
('97', 162, 7, 27, 339688) This is only a story in which Rama is portrayed as God and Ravana as His enemy.
('97', 162, 7, 28, 339768) That is why Ravana has been described as inauspicious—a demon and an evil spirit, because he insisted on disregarding Rama and died without accepting Him.
('97', 162, 7, 29, 339923) Then he had to die at the hands of God.
('97', 162, 7, 30, 339963) This is a story.
('97', 162, 7, 31, 339980) It does not
('97', 162, 8, 32, 339992) 1 Muslims including many old friends, started visiting Gandhiji from early morning on Bakr Id.
('97', 162, 8, 33, 340087) On seeing them Gandhiji muttered to himself, “With what face can I wish them a happy Id?” Vide also the following item.
('97', 163, 0, 1, 340207) 164 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 163, 1, 2, 340249) mean that the effigy of Ravana is made with an idea of taking revenge.
('97', 163, 1, 3, 340320) The lesson I draw from it is that it teaches man not to take revenge.
('97', 163, 1, 4, 340390) Who would be more arrogant and foolish than I if I imagined myself to be Rama and other people sitting around here to be Ravanas?
('97', 163, 1, 5, 340520) How do I know I am Rama?
('97', 163, 1, 6, 340545) Who knows how much wickedness is hidden in me?
('97', 163, 1, 7, 340592) Nobody knows whether I am a mahatma 'or a wicked person in the eyes of God.
('97', 163, 1, 8, 340668) I myself do not quite know how wicked or good I may be.
('97', 163, 1, 9, 340724) God alone knows it.
('97', 163, 1, 10, 340744) He is far above us and sees everything.
('97', 163, 1, 11, 340784) Nothing is hidden from Him.
('97', 163, 1, 12, 340812) Man cannot take revenge on anyone.
('97', 163, 1, 13, 340847) Even if someone has done any harm, what is the point in taking revenge on him?
('97', 163, 1, 14, 340926) Imagine a man as being perfect, though man can never be perfect, for God alone can be perfect, but supposing there is one human being who is perfect while others are imperfect, should he then punish others or slay them?
('97', 163, 1, 15, 341146) According to me, the making of Ravana’s effigy on the Vijaydashami day means that it is not up to human beings to take revenge.
('97', 163, 1, 16, 341274) Even if we do not call it revenge, God alone can harm or kill.
('97', 163, 1, 17, 341337) Does it then mean that it is only for God to employ violence as well as non violence?
('97', 163, 1, 18, 341423) God has no attributes and is beyond all properties.
('97', 163, 1, 19, 341475) To Him all these things mean nothing.
('97', 163, 1, 20, 341513) But this story is an illustration which points out that God alone can destroy all the Ravanas in the world.
('97', 163, 1, 21, 341621) Some people also presume that Vijayadashmi tells them that they are perfect and others are imperfect.
('97', 163, 1, 22, 341723) Hence they take the law into their own hands and become the lords of the world and start injuring and slaughtering people.
('97', 163, 1, 23, 341846) All this is happening in India, too, because we have lost our senses.
('97', 163, 1, 24, 341916) From the reply I have given, you and the gentleman who put the question will have understood that the Rama Ravana story teaches us that we should not become sinful but be virtuous.
('97', 163, 1, 25, 342097) Taking the name of Rama on the one hand and indulging in acts of sin on the other is abusing God.
('97', 163, 1, 26, 342195) Now some of you can ask me whether, while I am taking of these things at such length, I am aware of what is happening in Kashmir.
('97', 163, 1, 27, 342325) 1 Yes, I am quite aware of it.

('97', 172, 7, 13, 357220) 158. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 2
('97', 172, 8, 14, 357252) NEW DELHI October 27, 1947
('97', 172, 9, 15, 357279) Complaints are being repeatedly made that Muslims are being forced to leave their ancestral homes in the Union and migrate to Pakistan.
('97', 172, 9, 16, 357415) Thus it is said that in a variety of ways they are being made to vacate their houses and live in camps to await dispatch by train or even on foot.
('97', 172, 9, 17, 357562) I am quite sure that such is not the policy of the Cabinet.
('97', 172, 9, 18, 357622) When I tell the complainants about this they laugh at it and tell me in reply that either my information is incorrect or the Services do not carry out the policy.
('97', 172, 9, 19, 357785) I know that my information is quite correct.
('97', 172, 9, 20, 357830) Are the Services then disloyal?
('97', 172, 9, 21, 357862) I hope not.
('97', 172, 9, 22, 357874) Yet the complaint is universal.
('97', 172, 9, 23, 357906) Various reasons are given for the alleged disloyalty.
('97', 172, 9, 24, 357960) The most plausible one is that the military and the police are largely divided on a communal basis and that their members are carried away by the prevalent prejudice.
('97', 172, 9, 25, 358127) I have given my opinion that if these members on whom depends the preservation of law and order are affected by the
('97', 172, 10, 26, 358243) 1 Granddaughter of Swami Shraddhanand 2 As Gandhiji was observing silence his written speech was read out after the prayer.
('97', 173, 0, 1, 358367) 174 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 173, 1, 2, 358409) communal taint, orderly Government must give place to disorder and if the latter persists, to disruption of society.
('97', 173, 1, 3, 358526) It is up to the upper ranks of these Services to rise superior to communalism and then to infect the lower ranks with the same healthy spirit.
('97', 173, 1, 4, 358669) It is suggested with much force that the popular Governments established in the country have not the prestige that the ability to overawe the Indian members of the Services gave the foreign bureaucracy.
('97', 173, 1, 5, 358872) This is only partly true.
('97', 173, 1, 6, 358898) For the popular Government wields a moral force which is infinitely superior to the physical force that the foreign Government could summon to its assistance.
('97', 173, 1, 7, 359057) This moral force presupposes the possession of political morale that popular support would give to an indigenous Government.
('97', 173, 1, 8, 359182) It may be lacking today.
('97', 173, 1, 9, 359207) There is no means of checking it save by the resignation of the Ministry at the Centre.
('97', 173, 1, 10, 359295) What we are examining specially this evening is the condition of the Central authority.
('97', 173, 1, 11, 359383) It must never be and, what is perhaps more important, never feel weak.
('97', 173, 1, 12, 359454) It must be conscious of its strength.
('97', 173, 1, 13, 359492) Therefore if it is at all true that there is the slightest insubordination among the Services, the guilty ones must go; or the Ministry or the Minister in charge must resign and give place to the one who would successfully deal with official disorderliness.
('97', 173, 1, 14, 359750) Whilst I voice, not without hesitation, the complaints that persistently come to me, I must cling to the hope that they have no basis and that if they have, the superior authority will satisfactorily deal with them in so far as they have any justification.
('97', 173, 1, 15, 360007) What is the duty of the affected citizens of the Union?
('97', 173, 1, 16, 360063) It is clear that there is no law that can compel a citizen to leave his place of residence.
('97', 173, 1, 17, 360155) The authority will have to arm itself with special powers to issue orders such as are alleged to have been given.
('97', 173, 1, 18, 360269) So far as I am aware there are no written orders issued to anyone.
('97', 173, 1, 19, 360336) In the present case thousands are involved in the alleged verbal orders.
('97', 173, 1, 20, 360409) There is no helping those who will be frightened into submission to any order given by a person in uniform.
('97', 173, 1, 21, 360517) My emphatic advice to all such persons is that they should ask for written orders whose validity in case of doubt should be tested in a court of justice, if appeal to the final executive fails to give satisfaction.
('97', 173, 1, 22, 360732) The public, in this case representing the majority community (that hateful expression), should rigidly refrain from taking the law into their own hands.
('97', 173, 1, 23, 360885) If they do not, they will be cutting the very
('97', 174, 0, 1, 360931) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 175
('97', 174, 1, 2, 360981) branch on which they are sitting.
('97', 174, 1, 3, 361015) It will be a fall from which it will be difficult to rise.
('97', 174, 1, 4, 361074) Let wisdom dawn on them while there is yet time.
('97', 174, 1, 5, 361123) Let them not be swayed by ugly events even when the report thereof happens to be true.
('97', 174, 1, 6, 361210) They must trust the representative Ministers to do the needful for the vindication of justice.

('97', 176, 8, 17, 363472) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 176, 9, 18, 363494) A gentleman from Delhi writes: “I had taken some screens and tents from a Muslim gentleman for the refugees.
('97', 176, 9, 19, 363603) He has now gone away from here.
('97', 176, 9, 20, 363635) Where should I keep them now?’ He is a gentleman and that is why he is asking what he should do with those things.
('97', 176, 9, 21, 363750) He is right.
('97', 176, 9, 22, 363763) Since that man has gone away, should we appropriate those things to ourselves?
('97', 176, 9, 23, 363842) But I do not have any arrangement for keeping them.
('97', 176, 9, 24, 363894) This matter concerns the Home Department.
('97', 176, 9, 25, 363936) The Sardar should have been consulted.
('97', 176, 9, 26, 363975) Or the matter should have been referred to anyone who is handling it.
('97', 176, 9, 27, 364045) Or Neogy Saheb 1 who has been appointed for the purpose should be consulted.
('97', 176, 9, 28, 364122) If he can find the whereabouts of that Muslim gentleman, these things or their worth in money will have to be sent to him.
('97', 176, 9, 29, 364245) A few young men from the Aligarh University came to me.
('97', 176, 10, 30, 364301) 1 K. C. Neogy, Minister for Refugees and Rehabilitation, Government of India
('97', 177, 0, 1, 364378) 178 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 177, 1, 2, 364420) Some students from West Punjab and North West Frontier Province also study in that University.
('97', 177, 1, 3, 364515) They could not reach the University and those who are here cannot leave the place.
('97', 177, 1, 4, 364598) Why should they not be able to move freely?
('97', 177, 1, 5, 364642) Now that Pakistan has been formed, does it mean that the Muslims should go there and the Hindus and the Sikhs should come here?
('97', 177, 1, 6, 364770) The students wish to collect the blankets, etc., from Muslims and distribute them among Hindu and Sikh refugees who are facing hardships in the camps.
('97', 177, 1, 7, 364921) Their intention is good and the refugees need them too.
('97', 177, 1, 8, 364977) If they receive these things, it would also be an expression of love from Muslims.

('97', 177, 1, 10, 365191) I have with me a whole pile of papers full of complaints.
('97', 177, 1, 11, 365249) Those complaints are not unfounded.
('97', 177, 1, 12, 365285) Of course I do feel that some exaggeration is quite possible in them.
('97', 177, 1, 13, 365355) But even if there is exaggeration, there is substantial ground for those complaints.
('97', 177, 1, 14, 365440) Why should the Hindus run away from their places?

('97', 177, 1, 16, 365506) Why should they not come and live in their own places?
('97', 177, 1, 17, 365561) If the students are able to do this we can show to the whole world that we had never indulged in mutual fighting.
('97', 177, 1, 18, 365675) Then we shall regain our honour which is sullied today.
('97', 177, 1, 19, 365731) This is what I have told those boys.
('97', 177, 1, 20, 365768) They have agreed to what I have said.
('97', 177, 1, 21, 365806) God alone knows what they are going to do later on.
('97', 177, 1, 22, 365858) But what I want to tell you today is something very important.
('97', 177, 1, 23, 365921) I think that while I was in Bihar people used to think that since they had won freedom there was no need to buy tickets for travelling by train.
('97', 177, 1, 24, 366066) Not only this.
('97', 177, 1, 25, 366081) They sometimes indulged in acts of high handedness and coercion.
('97', 177, 1, 26, 366146) People did not indulge in mutual fighting in those days, but now they think that having won their freedom they need nothing more.
('97', 177, 1, 27, 366276) I wrote quite a bit on the subject and it did have some effect and such practices were given up.
('97', 177, 1, 28, 366373) But now for the past few days the situation has so developed that all over the country people have started travelling without tickets.
('97', 177, 1, 29, 366508) Even well to do people have started thinking that they have become the owners of the trains.
('97', 177, 1, 30, 366601) The railways certainly belong to us now; but the practice of ticketless travelling has resulted in a loss of Rs. 8 crores.
('97', 177, 1, 31, 366724) And Rs. 8 crores is no small sum.
('97', 177, 1, 32, 366758) Even Rs. 1 crore is no small sum.
('97', 177, 1, 33, 366792) How difficult it was and how many people had to go round when we had to collect Rs. 1 crore for the Congress!
('97', 177, 1, 34, 366902) I too went round from house to house with the others to collect the funds.
('97', 177, 1, 35, 366977) With great difficulty we were able to collect that amount.
('97', 177, 1, 36, 367036) The people of our country are so poor.
('97', 177, 1, 37, 367075) Today we spend a crore of rupees in no
('97', 178, 0, 1, 367114) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 179
('97', 178, 1, 2, 367164) If we get it we don’t even notice how it is spent.
('97', 178, 1, 3, 367215) We still do not know how to spend.
('97', 178, 1, 4, 367250) We spend just because we have been put in charge of the work.
('97', 178, 1, 5, 367312) If people start having free rides in trains or do not buy tickets when travelling in connection with work, it is a kind of violence.
('97', 178, 1, 6, 367445) In my view it is plain robbery.
('97', 178, 1, 7, 367477) At this rate India will be reduced to utter poverty and we shall be left without railways or anything else.
('97', 178, 1, 8, 367585) Then we shall feel sorry wondering how we can travel.
('97', 178, 1, 9, 367639) Eight crore rupees do not make a small sum after all.
('97', 178, 1, 10, 367693) In former days the railways could earn interest on their capital out of their earnings.
('97', 178, 1, 11, 367781) Millions of people travel by trains.
('97', 178, 1, 12, 367818) If everybody pays his fare the railways can earn quite a lot.
('97', 178, 1, 13, 367880) There used to be ticketless travellers even in those days; but not in thousands as today.

('97', 178, 1, 28, 368999) They have to be fed and clothed.
('97', 178, 1, 29, 369032) We have to incur all that expenditure for nothing.

('97', 178, 1, 31, 369170) That is impossible.
('97', 178, 1, 32, 369190) Hence even if there is a single person travelling by train, let him not travel without paying his fare.
('97', 178, 1, 33, 369294) He must pay his fare.
('97', 178, 1, 34, 369316) During the British days, police constables and other officials used to swallow up considerable amount of money.

('97', 178, 1, 37, 369645) In this way, thousands of rupees went by way of bribes.
('97', 178, 1, 38, 369701) Now I feel that everybody

('97', 179, 1, 2, 369894) has become quite honest.
('97', 179, 1, 3, 369919) The station masters, signalmen, inspectors, guards, etc., should take only their legitimate dues and live only by that.
('97', 179, 1, 4, 370039) They should not grab money from people.
('97', 179, 1, 5, 370079) The passengers should consider the railways as their own property.
('97', 179, 1, 6, 370146) They should keep the trains clean.
('97', 179, 1, 7, 370181) They should not spit and smoke in the trains and should not pull the chain without real need.
('97', 179, 1, 8, 370275) And not a single passenger should travel without ticket.
('97', 179, 1, 9, 370332) Then I would be able to say that we have attained true independence.
('97', 179, 1, 10, 370401) Here there are not thousands of people to hear me, and so who would carry my words to those hundreds of thousands of people who travel by trains?
('97', 179, 1, 11, 370547) Had I been a railway manager or a railway minister I would have given orders to people working under me to tell the passengers that though they would not be physically manhandled, the railways belonged to them and the railway officials were their servants, they would not be permitted to travel without paying the fares.
('97', 179, 1, 12, 370868) Even if the train is passing through a forest, the railway authorities would stop the train right there.
('97', 179, 1, 13, 370973) If the passengers still did not come round they would order the driver to detach the engine from the train and drive it away.
('97', 179, 1, 14, 371099) Then there would be no occasion for abusing people or using force against them; the train just would not move till the passengers paid the fare.
('97', 179, 1, 15, 371244) This method should be followed as long as the passengers travel without tickets.
('97', 179, 1, 16, 371325) After all, it is not proper to board the train without tickets, to indulge in violence and stop the train just anywhere one likes.
('97', 179, 1, 17, 371456) What I have told you is happening in India.
('97', 179, 1, 18, 371500) But I have heard that in Pakistan too people travel in trains without tickets just as here.
('97', 179, 1, 19, 371592) And why should they not do so?
('97', 179, 1, 20, 371623) After all we were all born in the same environment, have eaten the same salt, then why should not the same things happen there as here?
('97', 179, 1, 21, 371759) But if things continue in this manner, both the countries will go bankrupt.
('97', 179, 1, 22, 371835) If we travel by train without buying tickets, take bribes wherever we can and go on beating up people, we will end up as robbers.
('97', 179, 1, 23, 371965) The respect we have acquired by becoming independent will be completely lost.
('97', 179, 1, 24, 372043) Hence let as many people as possible and the Minister listen to what I am saying, because I am saying as an experienced man, that if this trend does not stop you will have to stop running the trains.
('97', 179, 1, 25, 372243) The trains will not move and in the trains that move no passenger will be allowed to travel without paying his fare.

('97', 187, 2, 3, 384592) Gandhiji told him that the only way for him to vindicate his good faith was sincerely and boldly to condemn the wrong policies and actions of Pakistan.
('97', 187, 2, 4, 384744) 2 This he himself did not deny.
('97', 187, 2, 5, 384776) There was, for instance, the invasion by tribesmen of Kashmir.
('97', 187, 2, 6, 384839) Either Pakistan was behind it, as all circumstantial evidence went to show , or it was not.
('97', 187, 2, 7, 384931) If Pakistan was involved in it, was it not his duty as an Indian national to proclaim his conviction?
('97', 187, 2, 8, 385033) On the other hand, if even in the face of the organized forces in such strength in Kashmir, Shaheed maintained that Pakistan had no hand in it, was it not up to him to try to find out who was actually responsible for it?
('97', 187, 2, 9, 385254) I suggest to you that it is your duty to ascertain the truth.
('97', 187, 2, 10, 385316) Nothing would please me more than to find that I was wrong and you were right.

('97', 187, 4, 12, 385438) 173. TALK WITH SIND CONGRESSMEN
('97', 187, 5, 13, 385470) October 30, 1947
('97', 187, 6, 14, 385487) If I cannot convince the top leaders of the Congress who have been my co workers for the last thirty years, I ask myself, ‘Where do I stand?’ You are in such a pitiable condition that you have come to me for guidance asking in which city of India you can stay peacefully and your children can have education.
('97', 187, 6, 15, 385796) I pity you but I feel most unhappy with myself and wonder why I was so blind all this while.

('97', 187, 7, 22, 386431) 1 From Dilhiman Gandhi 2 Suhrawardy had complained that nobody trusted him in the Indian Union.
('97', 188, 0, 1, 386527) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 189
('97', 188, 1, 2, 386577) This morning I talked to this girl 1 about faith and hope.
('97', 188, 1, 3, 386636) God is really testing me, and if I am sincere in my effort to live up to my slogan of ‘do or die’ and if I am firm in my faith in Ramanama, I will, if I can do nothing else, cheerfully sacrifice myself in this yajna of unity with the name of the Faultless and Formless Rama on my lips and not run away from its flames however fierce they may be.
('97', 188, 1, 4, 386982) It will be enough if I can prove at least by my example that God does grant one the strength to sacrifice oneself in such a manner.
('97', 188, 1, 5, 387114) You are just like children to me.

('97', 196, 1, 17, 405508) Some people say the war has started and they wonder what is going to happen in Kashmir.
('97', 196, 1, 18, 405596) I say nothing is going to happen.
('97', 196, 1, 19, 405630) The people of Kashmir are brave.
('97', 196, 1, 20, 405663) The Hindus, Muslims and the Sikhs are living there in unity.
('97', 196, 1, 21, 405724) The invaders should be told by the Kashmiris that they should go back to their homes.
('97', 196, 1, 22, 405810) If they are going to attack, they will have to march on their dead bodies.
('97', 196, 1, 23, 405885) They cannot win Srinagar so easily.
('97', 196, 1, 24, 405921) Then nobody will touch our soldiers there.
('97', 196, 1, 25, 405964) If they die, they will become immortal.
('97', 196, 1, 26, 406004) Then we can dance with joy and sing.
('97', 196, 1, 27, 406041) If such a situation arises there, I would ask Shri Dilip Kumar Roy to sing such a bhajan that people would start dancing—because those who would have died would become immortal and those surviving would be as good as dead.
('97', 196, 1, 28, 406264) I would not be pained at all about this.
('97', 196, 1, 29, 406305) Of course, I would be pained if people here lost their senses and Pakistan also went mad.
('97', 196, 1, 30, 406395) The Afridis are like our brothers and the North West Frontier Province is our own.
('97', 196, 1, 31, 406478) Then why should they indulge in such acts?
('97', 196, 1, 32, 406521) We should know who is giving them help.
('97', 196, 1, 33, 406561) I would only pray that God may dwell in their hearts and the temples of their hearts be illumined with the flame of love.
('97', 196, 1, 34, 406683) Then the darkness around us will vanish and we will see light all round.
('97', 196, 1, 35, 406756) This is my prayer.
('97', 196, 1, 36, 406775) May you all
('97', 197, 0, 1, 406787) 198 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 197, 1, 2, 406829) join me in my prayer that such light should pervade both India and Pakistan that people live together in mutual love.
('97', 197, 1, 3, 406947) Then we may concentrate our efforts to produce food and clothing which are scarce in the country today.
('97', 197, 1, 4, 407051) Let us forget that there was ever any animosity among us, and become friends.
('97', 197, 1, 5, 407129) I only wish that we may devote ourselves to this task.

('97', 197, 8, 12, 407345) 179. HINDUSTANI WRITTEN IN NAGARI ONLY 2
('97', 197, 9, 13, 407386) Raihanabehn Tyabjee has written a well argued letter to me favouring Hindustani as the inter provincial language written exclusively in the Nagari.
('97', 197, 9, 14, 407534) She rigidly excludes the Urdu script.
('97', 197, 9, 15, 407572) As all her main arguments have been answered herein, the letter is not being translated.
('97', 197, 9, 16, 407661) 3 Her letter demands full consideration.
('97', 197, 9, 17, 407702) Raihanabehn sees no distinction between a Hindu and a Muslim.
('97', 197, 9, 18, 407764) Both, she holds, come from the same source and she acts accordingly.
('97', 197, 9, 19, 407833) I have always held that there is no distinction between the two.
('97', 197, 9, 20, 407898) Even though their observances differ, these do not separate them.
('97', 197, 9, 21, 407964) They undoubtedly profess different religions but they, like others, come from the same root.
('97', 197, 9, 22, 408057) Nevertheless, I detect certain flaws in her argumets.
('97', 197, 9, 23, 408111) We are not two nations.
('97', 197, 9, 24, 408135) Those who believe the Hindus and the Muslims to be two nations harm both the communities and India.
('97', 197, 10, 25, 408235) 1 The addressee, an 88 year old Sikh leader, had lost his only son, Prithipal Singh, who fell into a ravine while trekking from Kulu to Mandi.
('97', 197, 10, 26, 408378) 2 A Hindi version of this appeared in Harijan Sevak, 9 11 1947, under the title “Why Both Scripts?”.
('97', 197, 10, 27, 408479) 3 The correspondent had argued that insistence on the Urdu script, in pursuance of the policy of appeasement, would only encourage the separatist tendency among the Muslims and they would continue to live like foreigners in India.
('97', 198, 0, 1, 408710) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 199
('97', 198, 1, 2, 408760) should not matter that the Qaid e Azam believes the Hindus and the Muslims of India to be two nations or that there are Hindus too who entertain the same belief.
('97', 198, 1, 3, 408922) Surely, it does not follow that because the whole world is in error, we, who believe otherwise, should follow it.
('97', 198, 1, 4, 409036) This should never happen.
('97', 198, 1, 5, 409062) If Hindustani is taken to be the inter provincial language of India, it follows that both the scripts, Nagari and Urdu, should be equally acceptable.
('97', 198, 1, 6, 409212) If the State recognizes only Nagari as the character in which Hindustani should be written, it would certainly by unjust to our Muslim brethren and when it is remembered that they are a minority the guilt is enhanced.
('97', 198, 1, 7, 409430) I have never contended that all the forty crores of Indians have to learn both the scripts.
('97', 198, 1, 8, 409522) I have, however, held that those who have inter provincial contacts and who want to serve not merely their own province but the whole of India should know both the scripts.
('97', 198, 1, 9, 409695) The reason is obvious.
('97', 198, 1, 10, 409718) They ought to be able to read letters written whether in the Nagari or the Urdu script.
('97', 198, 1, 11, 409806) Hence, it is necessary that both the scripts are accepted as national.
('97', 198, 1, 12, 409877) If Hindi is to be the national language, naturally Nagari alone will be the national script and if Urdu is to take that place, Urdu script alone will be the national script.
('97', 198, 1, 13, 410051) But, if Hindustani, which is a resultant of the junction of Hindi and Urdu, is to be the national language, a knowledge of both the scripts is essential in the manner indicated by me.
('97', 198, 1, 14, 410235) It is worth remembering that in reality neither the Urdu character nor the Urdu form of the same language is the exclusive property of the Muslims of India.
('97', 198, 1, 15, 410392) There is quite a large number of Hindus and others whose mother tongue is Urdu and who know only the Urdu character.
('97', 198, 1, 16, 410509) It is further to be remembered that the necessity of knowing both the scripts was stressed by me on my return from South Africa in 1915. I submitted the same proposition to the Hindi Sahitya Sammelan in Indore as its President.
('97', 198, 1, 17, 410737) 1 So far as I recollect, there was hardly any opposition to the proposition.
('97', 198, 1, 18, 410814) It is true that then I did not suggest any alteration in the name 2. The definition, however, was the same as that of today.
('97', 198, 1, 19, 410939) When perfect anarchy prevails in the thought world and we express different views without regard to facts, it is obligatory that we should have one helm to weather any storm.
('97', 198, 2, 20, 411114) 1 Im March, 1918. 2 Of the national language, viz., Hindustani
('97', 199, 0, 1, 411177) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 199, 1, 2, 411219) In so far as it is believed that the Muslims only are concerned with the retention of the Urdu character, at this juncture it becomes our special duty to emphasize the necessity of Hindustani written in either character.
('97', 199, 1, 3, 411440) This should appear self evident.
('97', 199, 1, 4, 411473) Whatever were the reasons in justification, it must be admitted that within the Union in many places the Muslims have been dealt with harshly.
('97', 199, 1, 5, 411616) It would be beside the point to contend that Pakistan made the beginning with harsh treatment against the Hindus and the Sikhs.
('97', 199, 1, 6, 411744) For the State to ordain that the inter provincial script in the Union shall be only the Nagari, it would be an imposition upon the Muslims.
('97', 199, 1, 7, 411884) If the result of the act of justice is to be that the Muslims are to confine themselves to the Urdu character and gratuitously regard the word Hindustani as synonymous with Urdu, it would amount to cussedness and perhaps a sign that their hearts are not in the Union.
('97', 199, 1, 8, 412152) It would be confusion of thought for Raihanabehn to argue that keeping of the Urdu character side by side with the Nagrai would be construed to be in pursuance of the policy of appeasement.
('97', 199, 1, 9, 412342) Though the word has come to have a bad odour about it, I would submit that appeasement can be a praiseworthy duty, as it can also be at times a blameworthy gesture.
('97', 199, 1, 10, 412507) Thus, for instance, it can conceivably be a duty on the part of a brother to walk with his brother towards the North whilst alone he would have gone to the South.
('97', 199, 1, 11, 412670) But it would certainly be criminal for him, a confirmed teetotaller, to drink spirituous liquors with his drunken brother in order to appease him.
('97', 199, 1, 12, 412817) He would then harm both himself and his brother.
('97', 199, 1, 13, 412866) I must not recite the Klama in order to appease or flatter my Muslim brother, as he must not recite the Gayatri 1 in order to appease or flatter me.
('97', 199, 1, 14, 413015) It would be another matter if both of us recite either at will because we believe the two incantations as one in essence.
('97', 199, 1, 15, 413137) I hold that it is so.
('97', 199, 1, 16, 413159) Hence it is that in the daily recital of the Ashram prayers, among the eleven observances occurs equal respect for all the accepted religions in the world.
('97', 199, 1, 17, 413315) The upshot of all this argument is that the policy of appeasement is not always bad.
('97', 199, 1, 18, 413400) It may even become a duty at times.
('97', 199, 1, 19, 413436) This sister further says that the Nagari script is, comparatively speaking, fairly perfect, whereas the Urdu script is imperfect and difficult to decipher.
('97', 199, 1, 20, 413592) To write Sanskrit words in Urdu script is, she holds, well nigh impossible.
('97', 199, 1, 21, 413668) There is some force in these three statements.
('97', 199, 1, 22, 413715) They amount to this that the Devanagari script though
('97', 199, 2, 23, 413769) 1 The sacred hymn invoking the creative energy of the sun
('97', 200, 0, 1, 413827) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 201
('97', 200, 1, 2, 413877) comparatively perfect admits of improvement and the Urdu script demands it because it is imperfect.
('97', 200, 1, 3, 413977) It will be difficult for Raihanabehn to sustain the charge that it is not possible to write Sanskrit words in the Urdu script.
('97', 200, 1, 4, 414104) I have in my possession the whole of the Gita transcribed in that script.
('97', 200, 1, 5, 414178) Improvement is possible only when fanaticism has died out.
('97', 200, 1, 6, 414237) After all, what is the Sindhi alphabet but an improved edition of the Urdu script?
('97', 200, 1, 7, 414320) Lastly, I suggest to Raihanabehn that her letter under dis cussion is a fine specimen of Hindustani.
('97', 200, 1, 8, 414421) She has woven in that letter Urdu words as freely as Sanskrit words.
('97', 200, 1, 9, 414490) The beauty of Hindustani is that it has no quarrel either with sanskrit or with Arabic words.
('97', 200, 1, 10, 414584) In order to strengthen Hindustani consistently with its genius, if a language can be said to have a ‘genius’, it must borrow from all the languages of the world.
('97', 200, 1, 11, 414746) Its grammar must remain as it always has been in indigenous Hindi.
('97', 200, 1, 12, 414813) Thus the plural of ‘Hindu’ in Hindustani will always be Hindu o ( ) and not Hunud ( ) as it is in highly Arabicized Urdu.
('97', 200, 1, 13, 414935) Raihanabehn is an Urdu scholar.
('97', 200, 1, 14, 414967) Though not a scholar in Hindi , she knows it well.
('97', 200, 1, 15, 415018) She reads and writes both the Nagari and Urdu characters.
('97', 200, 1, 16, 415076) When I was in the Yeravda prison she and Zohra Ansari 1 were my Urdu teachers.
('97', 200, 1, 17, 415155) Naturally, they taught me through correspondence.
('97', 200, 1, 18, 415205) My advice, therefore, to her is that she should devote her energy to the strengthening and spreading of Hindustani and making the teaching of the two characters as easy as possible.
('97', 200, 1, 19, 415387) This work she can only do, if her ignorance, as I call it, is removed.
('97', 200, 1, 20, 415458) If what she has now begun to believe is true, I could have nothing to say to her.
('97', 200, 1, 21, 415540) Then indeed, I shall have to unlearn the past and learn a new lesson and displace the Urdu character from the position which I think it should occupy.
('97', 200, 2, 22, 415691) NEW DELHI, November 1, 1947 Harijan, 9 11 1947
('97', 200, 3, 23, 415738) 1 Adopted daughter of Dr. M. A. Ansari, married to Shaukat Ansari

('97', 205, 11, 27, 423301) Brajkishan tells me that the gentleman who protested yesterday is protesting today also.
('97', 205, 11, 28, 423390) I like his protest and at the same time I do not like it.
('97', 205, 11, 29, 423448) I like it because of its peaceful and dignified nature.
('97', 205, 11, 30, 423504) If he disapproves of something, why should he not express it?

('97', 205, 12, 34, 423790) 1 The addressee, who was working in Noakhali to establish communal harmony, had written to Gandhiji that she felt it was her duty to go and live in Patiala since her brothers had come away from there and hardly a Muslim was left there.
('97', 206, 0, 1, 424026) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 207
('97', 206, 1, 2, 424076) firmness.
('97', 206, 1, 3, 424086) It was not such a difficult matter after all, and could be grasped by people with ordinary intelligence.

('97', 206, 1, 5, 424292) That is why I am happy as well as sad.

('97', 211, 1, 2, 435840) 186. INTERVIEW TO RONALD STEAD 1
('97', 211, 2, 3, 435873) [Before November 2, 1947]
('97', 211, 3, 4, 435899) Ronald Stead discussed with Mahatma Gandhi the crucial issue of how best to combat India’s internecine violence.
('97', 211, 3, 5, 436012) In a single brief sentence Gandhiji defined his long range objective “to replace communal hatred by communal brotherhood”.
('97', 211, 4, 6, 436135) Stead reports:
('97', 211, 5, 7, 436150) Mahatma Gandhi makes it clear that he is reluctant to discuss the recent troubled past.
('97', 211, 6, 8, 436238) He has criticized the misbehaviour of Muslims and non Muslims alike.
('97', 211, 6, 9, 436307) In this connection he observes with a little smile: I used to be represented as an enemy of the Muslims.
('97', 211, 6, 10, 436412) Now, because I castigate the Hindus for misdemeanours which they, like the Muslims, have been guilty of, I am being represented in some quarters as an enemy of the Hindus.
('97', 211, 6, 11, 436584) The fact is, I am an enemy only of wrongdoing.
('97', 211, 7, 12, 436631) Mahatma Gandhi describes the situation in Calcutta as satisfactory but says that Delhi is decidedly otherwise.
('97', 211, 7, 13, 436742) That is why his original plans were altered.
('97', 211, 7, 14, 436787) He asks: How can I go on to the Punjab, when so much remains to be done here?
('97', 211, 8, 15, 436865) Mahatma Gandhi’s longrange plans for supplanting communal animosity by communal tolerance are the same as those he is executing now.
('97', 211, 8, 16, 436998) That is to say, he is going to address the maximum number of persons in public now.
('97', 211, 8, 17, 437082) Evening prayer meetings furnish regular opportunities for doing this.
('97', 211, 8, 18, 437152) He is going to hold counsel with as many responsible leaders as seek to discuss matters with him.
('97', 211, 8, 19, 437250) He is going to visit refugee concentrations and address himself to reassuring the minorities, urging them not to migrate and seeking to foster among the majority the tolerance that will justify such persuasion.

('97', 220, 3, 4, 453498) I saw your letter only now, after listening to the sweet and sad bhajan containing Draupadi’s prayer 1: “O God, guard me against insult.” I am also in a similar predicament today.

('97', 220, 3, 6, 453910) At that hour, she did not lose faith and prayed to God from her heart.

('97', 220, 3, 8, 454013) This bhajan has a deep significance.
('97', 220, 3, 9, 454050) One can go on expatiating on it.

('97', 220, 3, 11, 454159) Still, I am in a sad plight.
('97', 220, 3, 12, 454188) Yet there is God’s help, as I find each day.
('97', 220, 3, 13, 454233) Ultimately Delhi will decide the destiny of the whole country.
('97', 220, 3, 14, 454296) Our hearts have also become filled with much dirt.
('97', 220, 3, 15, 454347) I am striving to remove it.

('97', 220, 3, 17, 454448) I have therefore given up my desire to live for 125 years.
('97', 220, 3, 18, 454507) May God give good sense to all.

('97', 223, 1, 2, 457031) 199. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('97', 223, 2, 3, 457063) NEW DELHI November 3, 1947
('97', 223, 3, 4, 457090) If two quantities of poison mix together, who will decide which was first on the field and if such a decision could be arrived at what end would it serve?
('97', 223, 3, 5, 457245) We know this, however, that the virus has spread throughout the Western Pakistan area and that it has not as yet been recognized as such by the powers that be.
('97', 223, 3, 6, 457405) So far as the Union is concerned, it has been confined to a small part of it.
('97', 223, 3, 7, 457483) Would to God that the virus would remain under isolation and control!
('97', 223, 3, 8, 457553) There would then be cause for every hope that it would be expelled in due time and that soon from both the parts.
('97', 223, 3, 9, 457667) In view of the fact that Dr. Rajendra Prasad has called a meeting of the Premiers or their representatives and others to help and advise him in the matter of food control, I feel that I should devote this evening to that very important question.
('97', 223, 3, 10, 457913) Nothing that I have heard during these days has moved me from the stand I have taken from the beginning that the control should be entirely removed at the earliest moment possible, certainly not later than six months hence.
('97', 223, 3, 11, 458137) Not a day passes but letters and wires come to me, some from important persons, declaring emphatically that both the controls should be removed.
('97', 223, 3, 12, 458282) I propose to omit the other, i.
('97', 223, 3, 13, 458314) e., cloth control for the time being.
('97', 223, 3, 14, 458352) Control gives rise to fraud, suppression of truth, intensification of the black market and to artificial scarcity.
('97', 223, 3, 15, 458467) Above all it unmans the people and deprives them of initiative, it undoes the teaching of self help they have been learning for a generation.
('97', 223, 3, 16, 458609) It makes them spoon fed.
('97', 223, 3, 17, 458634) This is a tragedy next only, if indeed not equal, to the fratricide on a vast scale and the insane exchange of population resulting in unnecessary deaths, starvation and want of proper residence and clothing the more poignant for the coming inclement weather.
('97', 223, 3, 18, 458894) The second is certainly more spectacular.
('97', 223, 3, 19, 458936) We dare not forget the first because it is not spectacular.
('97', 223, 3, 20, 458996) This food control is one of the vicious legacies of the last World War.
('97', 223, 3, 21, 459068) Control then was probably inevitable because a very large
('97', 223, 4, 22, 459126) 1 It being Gandhiji’s silence day, his written speech was read out after the prayers.
('97', 224, 0, 1, 459212) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 225
('97', 224, 1, 2, 459262) quantity of cereals and other food stuff were exported outside.
('97', 224, 1, 3, 459326) This unnatural export was bound to create a man made scarcity and lead to rationing in spite of its many drawbacks.
('97', 224, 1, 4, 459442) Now there need be no export which we can avoid if we wish to.
('97', 224, 1, 5, 459504) We would help the starving parts of the world, if we do not expect outside help for India in the way of food.
('97', 224, 1, 6, 459614) I have seen during my lifetime covering two generations several God sent famines, but have no recollection of an occasion when rationing was even thought of.
('97', 224, 1, 7, 459772) Today, thank God, the monsoons have not failed us.
('97', 224, 1, 8, 459823) There is, therefore, no real scarcity of food.
('97', 224, 1, 9, 459870) There are enough cereals, pulses and oil seeds in the villages of India.
('97', 224, 1, 10, 459943) The artificial control of prices, the growers do not, cannot, understand.
('97', 224, 1, 11, 460017) They, therefore, refuse willingly to part with their stock at a price much lower than they command in the open market.
('97', 224, 1, 12, 460136) This naked fact needs no demonstration.
('97', 224, 1, 13, 460176) It does not require statistics or desk work civilians buried in their red tape files to produce elaborate reports and essays to prove that there is scarcity.
('97', 224, 1, 14, 460334) It is to be hoped that no one will frighten us by trotting out before us the bogey of over population.
('97', 224, 1, 15, 460437) Our ministers are of the people, from the people.
('97', 224, 1, 16, 460487) Let them not arrogate to themselves greater knowledge than those experienced men who do not happen to occupy ministerial chairs—but who hold the view strongly that the sooner the control is removed the better.
('97', 224, 1, 17, 460697) A physician writes to say that the food control has made it impossible for those who depend upon rationed food to procure eatable cereals and pulses and therefore, he says, the people needlessly suffer from ailments caused by rotten stuff.
('97', 224, 1, 18, 460937) In the place of controlled food, the Government can easily run the very stores for selling good grain which they will buy in the open market.
('97', 224, 1, 19, 461079) They will thus bring about automatic regulation of prices and set free the hoarded cereals, pulses and oil seeds.
('97', 224, 1, 20, 461193) Will they not trust the grain dealers and growers?
('97', 224, 1, 21, 461244) Democracy will break under the strain of apron strings.
('97', 224, 1, 22, 461300) It can exist only on trust.
('97', 224, 1, 23, 461328) If the people die because they will not labour or because they will defraud one another, it will be a welcome deliverance.
('97', 224, 1, 24, 461451) The rest will then learn not to repeat the sin of being lazy, idle or cruelly selfish.
('97', 224, 2, 25, 461538) Harijan, 16 11 1947

('97', 226, 4, 24, 464383) Why should he not benefit from the limitless grace of the sun god who rises in his village every morning?

('97', 227, 5, 10, 465388) 204. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 227, 6, 11, 465418) NEW DELHI November 4, 1947 BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 227, 7, 12, 465467) Today only our old courteous friend has objected to the recitation from the Koran.
('97', 227, 7, 13, 465550) Hence, I would discuss a pathetic letter from a Punjabi Hindu refugee.
('97', 227, 7, 14, 465621) He has suffered a great deal in the Punjab.
('97', 227, 7, 15, 465665) And he has objected to the recitation from the Koran.
('97', 227, 7, 16, 465719) I do not know if that gentleman is present here.
('97', 227, 7, 17, 465768) He may or may not be here, but I cannot ignore his letter.
('97', 227, 7, 18, 465827) It is a letter written with deep pain.
('97', 227, 7, 19, 465866) He has put forth fairly good arguments in the letter.
('97', 227, 7, 20, 465920) But then it is full of ignorance born out of his anger.
('97', 227, 7, 21, 465976) Every line he has written expresses his anger.
('97', 227, 7, 22, 466023) These days practically all my time is spent in listening to the tales of woe from the Hindu or Sikh refugees or the Muslims of Delhi who are in distress.
('97', 227, 7, 23, 466177) I also feel the same distress in my heart and am equally hurt.
('97', 227, 7, 24, 466240) But I would not be truly non violent if I started shedding tears or became gloomy.
('97', 227, 7, 25, 466323) If non violence made me so very soft, I would be crying the whole time, and there would be no time left to worship God, and to eat and sleep.
('97', 227, 7, 26, 466465) But right from childhood, being a follower of non violence, I have made it a habit of hardening my heart instead of shedding tears while hearing or seeing any tragedy, so that I would be able to face them.
('97', 227, 7, 27, 466671) Have not our saints and sages taught us that one who is a worshipper of ahimsa should be
('97', 227, 8, 28, 466760) 1 The addressee had sought Gandhiji’s blessings for her new born child, a son, after three daughters.
('97', 228, 0, 1, 466862) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 229
('97', 228, 1, 2, 466912) softer than a flower and harder than a stone?
('97', 228, 1, 3, 466958) I have tried to live according to this teaching.
('97', 228, 1, 4, 467007) That is why when I receive complaints like those in this letter or hear the angry and sorrowful tales from the visitors coming to me, I steel my heart.
('97', 228, 1, 5, 467159) That is the only way I can face the present situation.
('97', 228, 1, 6, 467214) The letter has been written in the Urdu script and hence I asked Brajkishan to write for me the important points of the letter.
('97', 228, 2, 7, 467342) The first charge levelled against me is that I have broken a promise.
('97', 228, 2, 8, 467412) The letter says: “Have you not said that even if there is a single individual in your prayer meeting objecting to the recitation from the Koran, you would respect his wish and cancel the prayer for the evening?” This is a half truth which is more dangerous than a total lie.
('97', 228, 2, 9, 467687) When I had first cancelled the prayer 1 because there was an objection, I had declared that I was cancelling the prayer for fear that the large numbers attending the prayer may start showing their anger against the objector and may even manhandle him.
('97', 228, 2, 10, 467939) This was several months ago.
('97', 228, 2, 11, 467968) Since then people have learnt the art of restraint.
('97', 228, 2, 12, 468020) And, when people assured me that they would not have anger in their hearts nor any ill feeling for the objector I agreed to hold the public prayer.
('97', 228, 2, 13, 468168) And, as far as I know, the result has been good.
('97', 228, 2, 14, 468217) The behaviour of the persons who object is extremely courteous and apart from voicing their objection they create no obstruction in the prayer.
('97', 228, 2, 15, 468361) Thus, I hope the writer of this letter will appreciate that I have not gone back on my word.
('97', 228, 2, 16, 468454) And the result of continuing the prayer despite the protest has so far been good.
('97', 228, 2, 17, 468536) I would like to assure you that as far as I know myself, in this long life of public service I have never been guilty of breaking a promise.
('97', 228, 3, 18, 468677) The second charge the writer of this letter has made against me is that while I have the recitation from the Koran and claim that all religions are equal, I do not have recitations from the japji 2 and the Bible.
('97', 228, 3, 19, 468890) This remark only betrays the ignorance of the writer.
('97', 228, 3, 20, 468944) He is not aware of my statement in which I explained how the entire Bhajanavali was prepared.
('97', 228, 3, 21, 469038) 3 The Ashram Bhajanavali contains quite a few psalms from the Bible and bhajans from the Granthsaheb.
('97', 228, 3, 22, 469140) His third complaint is that many eminent Congress leaders have

('97', 229, 1, 2, 469469) come away from West Punjab and other parts of West Pakistan; but having come to the Indian Union they do not share the trials and tribulations of other refugees.
('97', 229, 1, 3, 469631) These leaders have acquired more spacious buildings than what they had occupied in Pakistan and are living in great comfort and luxury.
('97', 229, 1, 4, 469767) These Congress leaders have completely isolated themselves from the refugees who have no houses to live in nor woollen clothes to protect themselves against winter.

('97', 230, 1, 29, 474282) Why are the cattle of India the most neglected lot in the whole world?

('97', 233, 4, 25, 479050) Because we have oppressed them so far, if anyone talks to them with affection and teaches them something with love, they concentrate and work hard and make good progress.
('97', 233, 4, 26, 479221) The well to do boys are conceited and knowing that their parents have a lot of money, do not concentrate on their work.

('97', 238, 3, 6, 490413) 210. TWO AMERICAN FRIENDS’ CONSOLATION
('97', 238, 4, 7, 490452) Of the many letters that come to me from American friends whom I do not know, the following extracts from two such friends are worth quoting:
('97', 238, 5, 8, 490594) Your great distress due to the unhappy situation in your country demands that I intrude upon your contemplations of the painful events now taking place in India, to remind you that your beautiful words have taken root in all the corners of the earth.
('97', 238, 5, 9, 490845) That you should feel a degree of disillusionment because of these sad happenings is natural.
('97', 238, 5, 10, 490938) That that disillusionment should be measured and certainly not turn into discouragement is the purpose of my letter.
('97', 238, 5, 11, 491055) Never does the seed turn directly into a beautiful fragrant flower without first going through certain phases of growth and development.
('97', 238, 5, 12, 491192) And, if at some stage of its development—or growth— it falters, the presence of the gardener is more than ever required.
('97', 238, 5, 13, 491313) In the complete absorption of the selfless task of nursing the ailing plant, the gardener perhaps cannot fully observe the growth of other plants in his garden, to join with him in his compassion for their stricken brother.
('97', 238, 5, 14, 491537) I plead with you to give consideration to the countless numbers of people in all countries on earth, of all classes, races and creeds, who are now also praying for peace.
('97', 238, 5, 15, 491708) These people, whose hopes you have so well expressed and who took fresh courage from these victories which you did achieve with the Science of Peace, must now join me in prayer that the Master bless you and preserve you to continue your noble work, so much of which is still to be done.
('97', 238, 5, 16, 491995) What they say may prove true and that the senseless bloodbath through which India is still passing, though the original fury seems to have abated, may be nothing unusual as history goes.
('97', 238, 5, 17, 492182) What India is passing through must be regarded as unusual.
('97', 238, 5, 18, 492241) If we grant that such liberty as India has gained was a tribute to non violence as I have repeatedly said, non violence of India’s struggle was only in name, in reality it was passive resistance of the weak.
('97', 238, 5, 19, 492449) The truth of the statement we see demonstrated by the happenings in India.

('97', 248, 6, 11, 511388) Major General Cariappa is reported to have said as follows:
('97', 248, 7, 12, 511448) Non violence is of no use under the present circumstances in India and only a strong army can make India one of the greatest nations in the world.
('97', 248, 7, 13, 511595) I fear, like many experts, General Cariappa has gone beyond his depth and has been unwittingly betrayed into a serious misconception of ahimsa, of whose working in the nature of things, he can only have a very superficial knowledge.
('97', 248, 7, 14, 511828) By reason of lifelong practice of ahimsa, I claim to be an expert in it, though very imperfect.
('97', 248, 7, 15, 511924) Speaking in absolute terms, the more I practise it the clearer I see how far I am from the full expression of ahimsa in my life.
('97', 248, 7, 16, 512053) It is his ignorance of this, the greatest duty of man in the world, which makes him say that in this age non violence has little scope in the face of violence, whereas I make bold to say that in this age of the atom bomb, unadulterated non violence is the only force that can confound all the tricks put together of violence.
('97', 248, 7, 17, 512379) It would have become the General, unaided as he can only now be, by his British teachers of military science and practice not to have gone out of his depth.
('97', 248, 7, 18, 512536) Generals greater than General Cariappa have been wise and humble enough frankly to make the admission that they can have no right to speak of the possibilities of the force of ahimsa.
('97', 248, 7, 19, 512720) We are witnessing the tragic insolvency of military science and practice in its own home.
('97', 248, 7, 20, 512810) Should a bankrupt, who has been by the gamble in the share market, sing the praise of that particular form of gambling?
