('97', 251, 6, 16, 516406) NEW DELHI, November 7, 1947
('97', 251, 7, 17, 516434) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 251, 8, 18, 516456) It pains me to know that the Muslims of Tihar 1 and the neighbouring areas have to suffer unnecessary hardships.
('97', 251, 8, 19, 516569) Many of them are landowners but are unable to till their land for fear of harassment.
('97', 251, 8, 20, 516655) They have sold away their cattle, ploughs and other implements.
('97', 251, 8, 21, 516719) They are being protected by the army.
('97', 251, 8, 22, 516757) 2 More than two thousand of those distressed people had gathered round me.
('97', 251, 8, 23, 516832) Through their leader they conveyed to me their desire to go to Pakistan, because life had become impossible for them here.
('97', 251, 8, 24, 516955) They said that a large number of their friends and relatives had already gone to Pakistan.
('97', 251, 8, 25, 517046) Hence, it would be a mercy if the Government could arrange to send them to Lahore.
('97', 251, 8, 26, 517129) They said they had nothing to complain against the army.
('97', 251, 8, 27, 517186) However, I would not like to devote the whole time in giving an account of that meeting.
('97', 251, 8, 28, 517275) I told those people that I had no power in my hands, but I would gladly convey their message to the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister, who is also the Home Minister.
('97', 251, 9, 29, 517452) 1 Gandhiji had visited Tihar village at 4 p.
('97', 251, 9, 30, 517497) and met the Muslims there.
('97', 251, 9, 31, 517524) 2 While Gandhiji was returning to Delhi, his car was stopped by a number of Indian soldiers who saluted him and assured him that they were providing full protection to those in distress.
('97', 251, 9, 32, 517711) Gandhiji smiled and said that providing protection and kindness without distinction of caste or creed was the attribute of a soldier.
('97', 252, 0, 1, 517845) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 253
('97', 252, 1, 2, 517895) I am told that the refugees have become a problem in Delhi and that because they have suffered atrocities in Pakistan, they think they have special privileges.
('97', 252, 1, 3, 518055) When they go to buy things in the market they expect the shopkeeper to give them what they want without charging them anything or at a considerably reduced rate.
('97', 252, 1, 4, 518217) At times, a single person buys things worth hundreds of rupees.
('97', 252, 1, 5, 518281) Some refugees expect the tongawallahs to give them free rides or charge a very nominal fare.
('97', 252, 1, 6, 518374) If this report is true, it is my duty to say that the refugees have failed to learn the lesson that sufferers generally learn through hardships.
('97', 252, 1, 7, 518519) Thereby they are harming themselves and the country and making the already complicated problem more complicated.
('97', 252, 1, 8, 518632) If they continue to behave like this, they are sure to lose the sympathy of the Delhi traders.
('97', 252, 1, 9, 518727) At the same time, I cannot understand how the refugees who have come from Pakistan after losing everything, can buy things worth hundreds of rupees.
('97', 252, 1, 10, 518876) I would also wish that except on rare and necessary occasions, the refugees should not use anything other than their God given feet for moving about.
('97', 252, 1, 11, 519026) Apart from this, I am also told that ever since lakhs of refugees started coming to Delhi, there has been a steep rise in the revenue derived from spirituous liquor.
('97', 252, 1, 12, 519192) As a matter of fact, those people should realize that when the Central and the Provincial Governments accede to the demands of the Congress, neither hard liquor nor other intoxicants like opium and hemp would be available in the Indian Union.
('97', 252, 1, 13, 519435) The same situation can be created in Pakistan too, because our Muslim friends would not need a Congress resolution to declare total prohibition.
('97', 252, 1, 14, 519580) Can the refugees, who have undergone so many hardships, not restrain themselves from taking intoxicants and indulging in luxuries?
('97', 252, 1, 15, 519711) I hope the refugee men and women will take the advice I have given them through my earlier speeches that wherever they go, the refugees should mix with the people like sugar in milk, and make a firm resolve not to be a burden on them.
('97', 252, 1, 16, 519946) Let the rich and the poor refugees live in the same camps and work in full co operation, so that they can become ideal and self supporting citizens.
('97', 252, 2, 17, 520095) [From Hindi]
('97', 252, 3, 18, 520108) Prarthana Pravachan—I, pp.
('97', 253, 0, 1, 520135) 254 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 253, 1, 2, 520177) 228. ACT AS YOU THINK
('97', 253, 2, 3, 520199) From a letter received by Rajkumari from Dr. Maude Royden and which she has given to me for reading, I have extracted the following relevant passages:
('97', 253, 3, 4, 520350) I marvel that the best Christian in the world should not be a Christian!
('97', 253, 3, 5, 520423) I have been reading these last two or three weeks a new biography of Albert Schweitzer 1 and there again I have this same paradox.
('97', 253, 3, 6, 520554) I don’t know if the name of Schweitzer is known in India but to my mind he is perhaps alone in the world in his greatness.
('97', 253, 3, 7, 520677) And as you may perhaps know, Schweitzer is regarded with suspicion by the “orthodox” because it is held that he has not a sufficiently exalted view of our Saviour.
('97', 253, 3, 8, 520841) And yet there is not a Christian in the entire world who has followed Christ with the same heroic faith and utterly selfless devotion.
('97', 253, 3, 9, 520976) And when I read of his philosophy, his “reverence for life”, and how he constantly refers himself to Jesus of Nazareth, I know that no one has ever exalted Jesus to such a height in the minds of those who read Schweitzer.
('97', 253, 3, 10, 521198) He differs from most philosophers only in the fact that he must live all that he thinks, writes or says.
('97', 253, 3, 11, 521303) I realize now why his thought strikes one as having such stark and terrifying honesty.
('97', 253, 3, 12, 521390) If you are engaged in thinking without thought of action, it is easy to think all sorts of untrue things.
('97', 253, 3, 13, 521496) If you know that you are going to live everything that you think, with what a searching eye and with what profound sincerity you are going to think!
('97', 253, 4, 14, 521645) NEW DELHI, November 8, 1947
('97', 253, 5, 15, 521673) Harijan, 23 11 1947
('97', 253, 6, 16, 521693) 1 (1875 1965); philosopher, theologian, musician and doctor; devoted his life to missionary work in Africa; was awarded Nobel Peace Prize in 1952

('97', 254, 1, 2, 521889) 229. LETTER TO K. C. NEOGY
('97', 254, 2, 3, 521916) BIRLA HOUSE, NEW DELHI, November 8, 1947
('97', 254, 3, 4, 521957) DEAR NEOGY,
('97', 254, 4, 5, 521969) I am sorry that we have not met after your appointment as Minister of Refugees and Rehabilitation.
('97', 254, 4, 6, 522068) You will excuse me if I draw you attention to the complaints that have come under my notice.
('97', 254, 4, 7, 522161) One of them is that people have no ready access to you and when they do succeed in getting an audience of a few moments, they are summarily dismissed with a rebuff.
('97', 254, 4, 8, 522326) What they expect is a patient hearing.
('97', 254, 4, 9, 522365) Not all the refugees belong to the poor class.
('97', 254, 4, 10, 522412) Some of them are professional men.
('97', 254, 4, 11, 522447) But I contend that rich and poor, all alike, are entitled to perfect courtesy and patient hearing from their Ministers.
('97', 254, 4, 12, 522567) These refugees are ill covered, illfed, in some cases wander about aimlessly, even going without food.
('97', 254, 4, 13, 522670) I am not giving you all the numerous complaints that have been daily pouring into my ears.
('97', 254, 4, 14, 522761) I have ventured simply to give you a few samples from which you may infer the rest.
('97', 254, 4, 15, 522845) If there is, in your opinion, nothing whatsoever in these complaints, you will dismiss the letter from your consideration, forgiving me at the same time for intruding upon your valuable time.
('97', 254, 4, 16, 523037) I know you have been called to an office which must occupy all your attention.
('97', 254, 5, 17, 523116) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI
('97', 254, 6, 18, 523146) SHRI K. C. NEOGY NO.
('97', 254, 6, 19, 523167) 5 HASTINGS ROAD NEW DELHI

('97', 255, 11, 18, 524133) 232. A TALK 1
('97', 255, 12, 19, 524147) NEW DELHI, November 8, 1947
('97', 255, 13, 20, 524175) Nature cure means taking advantage of what nature has given us.
('97', 255, 13, 21, 524239) Cures may be brought about through sun bath, fresh air, mud and water therapy and the inclusion of fruit and leafy vegetables in the diet and suitable exercises.
('97', 255, 13, 22, 524401) That is why I was attracted to this.
('97', 255, 13, 23, 524438) Had nature cure experiment been carried on in Uruli under my
('97', 255, 14, 24, 524499) 1 With two visitors who were in favour of using modern electrical appliances in nature cure
('97', 256, 0, 1, 524591) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 257
('97', 256, 1, 2, 524641) supervision I would have ensured its complete success.
('97', 256, 1, 3, 524696) But today I have become ineffective.
('97', 256, 1, 4, 524733) You see what even men like General Cariappa are saying?
('97', 256, 1, 5, 524789) 1 Responsible people have no sense of responsibility left.
('97', 256, 1, 6, 524848) Nevertheless I still persevere in my effort to achieve the state of a sthitaprajna, that is to say, mental equipoise.
('97', 256, 1, 7, 524966) I have made considerable progress in this direction and have already arrived at the conclusion that Ramanama is the cure for all ailments and it is my hope that when I die I shall die with Ramanama in my heart.
('97', 256, 1, 8, 525177) This faith becomes stronger in me each day.
('97', 256, 1, 9, 525221) You see there was a time when even my opponents took my guidance.
('97', 256, 1, 10, 525287) Today, let alone my being assailed by my opponents, even my co workers, friends and close relatives who are like sons to me, do not see eye to eye with me.
('97', 256, 1, 11, 525443) Still, I am mentally in such excellent health that it surprises me that with the flames raging around me I remain untouched by their heat or sparks.
('97', 256, 1, 12, 525592) The reason for this is that God is filling me with strength and I am sustained by Ramanama.
('97', 256, 1, 13, 525684) Just as men derive vigour and vitality from the daily nourishment and sleep I derive my strength from Rama.

('97', 258, 1, 2, 528271) 235. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 258, 2, 3, 528301) NEW DELHI, November 8, 1947
('97', 258, 3, 4, 528329) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 258, 4, 5, 528351) Will you fulfil the primary condition that you will not harbour any feeling of anger or revenge against the persons who are raising the objection and sit in silence and concentration till the end of the prayer?
('97', 258, 5, 6, 528562) I have received a letter from a Sikh friend.
('97', 258, 5, 7, 528607) He has said that he always attends the prayer meeting and likes doing so.
('97', 258, 5, 8, 528681) He appreciates the spirit of tolerance in the prayer, especially my comments about the Granthsaheb, Sukhmani 2, Japji, etc.
('97', 258, 5, 9, 528805) He writes to say that if I select some portions from the Sikh scriptures included in the Bhajanavali and have a daily recitation of them during the prayer, it will have a great effect on the Sikhs.
('97', 258, 5, 10, 529003) He feels that he can say this on behalf of the entire Sikh community.
('97', 258, 5, 11, 529073) He says that he is ready to read out those selected passages to me.
('97', 258, 5, 12, 529141) I agree with his suggestion.
('97', 258, 5, 13, 529170) But I would take a decision only after I have heard some bhajans from that friend.
('97', 258, 5, 14, 529253) He must get an appointment from Brajkishan for that purpose.
('97', 258, 5, 15, 529314) I had once stated that cotton, calico, needles, etc., should be made available to the refugees so that they can make their own quilts.
('97', 258, 6, 16, 529449) Thereby we can save millions of rupees and the refugees can easily have something to cover themselves.
('97', 258, 6, 17, 529552) In response to my appeal the cotton merchants of Bombay have written to me that they are ready to supply these items.
('97', 258, 6, 18, 529670) In this way, the refugees will rise in their own eyes and will learn the first lesson of healthy co operation.
('97', 258, 6, 19, 529781) The number of textile mills in Delhi itself is by no means small.
('97', 258, 6, 20, 529847) There are quite a few mills in the city.
('97', 258, 6, 21, 529888) Still, I welcome this gift from Bombay, because I do not want to place any unnecessary burden on voluntary donors.
('97', 258, 6, 22, 530003) The larger the number of persons willing to give charity, the better will it be for the refugees and the country.
('97', 258, 6, 23, 530117) Hence, I hope that the cotton merchants of Bombay would quickly send as many bales as they can.
('97', 258, 7, 24, 530213) 1 The people, including four objectors, unanimously assured Gandhiji that they would observe silence and the prayer was held without any obstruction.
('97', 258, 7, 25, 530363) 2 A part of the Granthsaheb 3 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 12 10 1947.
('97', 259, 0, 1, 530438) 260 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 259, 1, 2, 530480) Such co operation from the rich would lessen the burden of the Government.
('97', 259, 1, 3, 530555) Now that we are a free nation, every individual can willingly participate in the activities of the Government of the country, provided he fulfils his duties by realizing the full responsibilities of the citizen of an independent country.
('97', 259, 1, 4, 530793) I have no doubt that when the bales of cotton arrive I will be able to persuade the mill owners to supply enough chintz for quilts.
('97', 259, 1, 5, 530925) The talk about bales of cotton reminds me of cloth control.
('97', 259, 1, 6, 530985) In my opinion, it is possible and also easy for the people of India to manufacture enough khadi by hand.
('97', 259, 1, 7, 531090) The only condition is that sufficient cotton should be available in the country.
('97', 259, 1, 8, 531171) I do not know if there ever was a famine of cotton in the country.
('97', 259, 1, 9, 531238) We can never have scarcity of cotton, because we always produce more cotton than the country needs.
('97', 259, 1, 10, 531338) Tens of thousands of bales of cotton are being exported from the country.
('97', 259, 1, 11, 531412) Still, there is never a shortage of cotton for the textile mills of the country.
('97', 259, 1, 12, 531493) I have already drawn your attention to the fact that it is possible to have within the country all the implements necessary for carding, spinning and weaving by hand.
('97', 259, 1, 13, 531660) At the same time, there are also people in large numbers wanting to work.
('97', 259, 1, 14, 531734) Hence, I can only say that it is nothing but inertia which makes people think that there is scarcity of cloth in the country.
('97', 259, 1, 15, 531860) Today nobody in the country wants cloth control—neither the mills, nor the mill hands nor the buying public.
('97', 259, 1, 16, 531969) Controls are increasing the band of lazy people and thus ruining the country.
('97', 259, 1, 17, 532047) Such people, for want of any work, are a constant source of mischief.
('97', 259, 1, 18, 532117) If the refugees are determined to occupy themselves in useful work, they would first make their own quilts, and then all—women and men—would spend their time in ginning, carding, spinning, weaving, etc.
('97', 259, 1, 19, 532320) The energy generated by the co operative effort of so many lakhs of refugees would electrify the country.
('97', 259, 1, 20, 532426) They would inspire the people to spend all their spare time in growing more food and producing khadi in their own homes.
('97', 259, 1, 21, 532547) Let it be remembered that if the cotton, instead of being packed into bales, is directly made available to the spinners one process would be saved.
('97', 259, 1, 22, 532695) The cotton would not be damaged, carding would become easy and the seeds would be saved for the villages.
('97', 259, 1, 23, 532801) Lady Mountbatten had come to meet me.
('97', 259, 1, 24, 532839) She has become an
('97', 260, 0, 1, 532857) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 261
('97', 260, 1, 2, 532907) angel of mercy.
('97', 260, 1, 3, 532923) She keeps visiting both the Dominions, 1 meets the refugees in different camps, looks up the sick and distressed people and tries to console them as much as she can.
('97', 260, 1, 4, 533089) When she paid a visit to the Kurukshetra camp, people asked her when I was expected to go there.
('97', 260, 1, 5, 533186) All of them were so keen to see me that Lady Mountbatten was convinced that I should undoubtedly go there.
('97', 260, 1, 6, 533293) I assured her that she was justified in anticipating my visit.
('97', 260, 1, 7, 533356) To tell you the truth, I have made arrangements to visit Panipat, where both the Hindus and the Muslims are anxious to see me.
('97', 260, 1, 8, 533483) I had decided to combine the visits to Kurukshetra and Panipat.
('97', 260, 1, 9, 533547) But now I have come to know that I cannot combine the two.
('97', 260, 1, 10, 533606) Hence, it has become necessary to postpone my visit to Kurukshetra until after the forthcoming meeting of the A. I. C. C. 2

('97', 261, 1, 2, 534357) 236. HARIJANS IN RATLAM
('97', 261, 2, 3, 534381) The following is the text 1 of the Ratlam Proclamation to which I referred in one of my postprayer speeches.
('97', 261, 2, 4, 534490) 2 It was issued on Vijayadashami day, i.e., the 2nd September, 3 1947.
('97', 261, 3, 5, 534561) 1. All State temples be thrown open to Harijans for darshan and pooja just as they are open to any one of my caste Hindu subjects.
('97', 261, 4, 6, 534692) 2. All existing public wells and wells constructed by the State here inafter, tanks, water taps, etc., shall be invariably open to Harijans.
('97', 261, 5, 7, 534833) 3. All public places such as dharmashalas, hotels, restaurants, shops, theatres, cinema houses which have not been for the exclusive use of any one section of the community before the passing of this Order shall be thrown open to Harijans and they shall be given the same facility or service as any other caste Hindu is given.
('97', 261, 5, 8, 535160) They are hereby allowed to make use of public conveyances licensed by Government or the Municipality.
('97', 261, 6, 9, 535262) 4. Harijans shall have unrestricted admission to State educational institutions and no tuition fees shall be charged from them.
('97', 261, 7, 10, 535390) 5. There shall be no restriction in the matter of recruitment of Harijans to State services.
('97', 261, 8, 11, 535483) 6. All State public offices, courts, hospitals and other State buildings are open to Harijans for entry.
('97', 261, 9, 12, 535588) 7. There shall be no restriction on the wearing of ornaments and good clothes, the taking out of processions and performance of ceremonies by Harijans.
('97', 261, 10, 13, 535740) 8. There shall be no restriction on Harijans owning lands and houses in any part of towns and villages of the State.
('97', 261, 11, 14, 535857) Harijan, 9 11 1947

('97', 261, 12, 16, 535988) Vijayadashami fell on October 24.

('97', 262, 1, 2, 536072) 237. FUTILITY OF ARMS
('97', 262, 2, 3, 536094) Advocate [T. R.] Venkatarama Shastri of Madras sends me some relevant verses from the Mahabharata with his brief comment.
('97', 262, 2, 4, 536216) They are reproduced below with his comment and English translation.
('97', 262, 2, 5, 536284) I have omitted from the comment what was meant only for me.
('97', 262, 3, 6, 536344) Having won the great Mahabharata War and attained his supreme end, Yudhishthira ( ), deeply affected by the death of those near and dear and
('97', 262, 4, 7, 536485) by the general havoc and destruction wrought by force of arms, reflected thus:
('97', 262, 5, 8, 536564) “Having destroyed ourselves by our own hands, what righteous result can we obtain?
('97', 262, 6, 9, 536647) Fie upon military practice,
('97', 262, 7, 10, 536675) Fie upon physical force,
('97', 262, 8, 11, 536700) Fie upon the purpose in pursuit of which we have been led into this calamity.
('97', 262, 9, 12, 536778) Good is forgiveness, self restraint, clean life, no enmity, no quarrel, ahimsa and true speech—virtues obligatory to forest dwellers (retired from life’s conflicts).
('97', 262, 10, 13, 536944) But we in our greed and folly inspired by vanity and pride, have landed ourselves in this situation, in our desire to enjoy a kingdom’s sorrowful burden.”
('97', 262, 11, 14, 537099) Thus wailed Yudhishthira (firm in battle) who was also Dharmaputra (son of righteousness).
('97', 262, 12, 15, 537190) The ideal of realizing both freedom and justice under equal laws is the ideal for countries like India—and that is, or should be, the ideal of the world.
('97', 262, 13, 16, 537344) NEW DELHI, November 9, 1947 Harijan, 9 11 1947

('97', 263, 1, 2, 537433) 238. LETTER TO DEVPRAKASH NAYYAR
('97', 263, 2, 3, 537466) NEW DELHI, November 5/9, 1947
('97', 263, 4, 4, 537496) I have your letter.
('97', 263, 4, 5, 537516) I have sent the letter for Sushila to Wardha.
('97', 263, 4, 6, 537562) She will return from there after the 10th instant.
('97', 263, 4, 7, 537613) She might come even earlier.
('97', 263, 4, 8, 537642) Chand 1 will accompany her.
('97', 263, 4, 9, 537670) It will be only good if you turn into the type of soldier you write about.
('97', 263, 4, 10, 537745) Then all your anguish will vanish.
('97', 263, 4, 11, 537780) You did well in not going to Wardha.
('97', 263, 4, 12, 537817) Now even Dr. Gilder and Dr. Jivaraj Mehta.
('97', 263, 4, 13, 537860) I had to leave the letter unfinished as some work had cropped up.
('97', 263, 4, 14, 537926) I am now completing it on the 9th.
('97', 263, 4, 15, 537961) I have seen the X ray too.
('97', 263, 4, 16, 537988) All say that there is nothing the matter with the heart.
('97', 263, 4, 17, 538045) There is a telegram now from Sushila to send over Chand’s mother.
('97', 263, 4, 18, 538111) Nobody here knows where her mother has gone.
('97', 263, 4, 19, 538156) She did not leave any address with me while leaving.
('97', 263, 4, 20, 538209) Chand stayed on because Sushila has stayed on.
('97', 263, 4, 21, 538256) I do not know the reason behind it.

('97', 266, 6, 20, 542674) Still, how strange it is that I learn from a leader of Kathiawar, who is a votary of non violence and can be counted among its ardent followers, that it is not possible to do without arms in a small State like Junagadh.

('97', 269, 5, 12, 546243) 248. NOTE TO MANU GANDHI November 9, 1947
('97', 269, 6, 13, 546285) We will be saved a lot of botheration if we cease to think of how we appear to others and concentrate on what is beneficial to us.
('97', 269, 6, 14, 546416) Knowingly or unknowingly, we resort to many artificial aids to please or appear good to others.
('97', 269, 6, 15, 546512) As a result, we become miserable.
('97', 269, 6, 16, 546546) The same thing applies to this hat.
('97', 269, 6, 17, 546582) 3 If I care for appearances, I will have to face the sun and damage my health for no reason.
('97', 269, 6, 18, 546675) Do you understand this?
('97', 269, 6, 19, 546699) Well, I have taught you a good lesson after many days.
('97', 269, 6, 20, 546754) If we analyse it minutely, our barbaric behaviour and Hindu Muslim tension are also due to our preoccupation with how we appear to others.
('97', 269, 6, 21, 546893) A man’s thoughts play a major role in his life.
('97', 269, 6, 22, 546941) That is why, as you also know, the proverb says: “As one’s food, so one’s belching; as one’s thoughts, so one’s deeds.

('97', 270, 5, 8, 547718) NEW DELHI, November 9, 1947
('97', 270, 6, 9, 547746) I regret that as I have to go to Panipat tomorrow, I had to take silence early today so as to be able to speak to the Hindus and the Muslims of Panipat on reaching there.
('97', 270, 6, 10, 547917) I hope to return to Delhi in time for the prayer tomorrow evening when I shall be able to speak.
('97', 270, 6, 11, 548014) The newspapers wrongly report that I am going to Kurukshetra tomorrow.
('97', 270, 6, 12, 548085) I said definitely that I did intend to go to the Kurukshetra camp though not before the conclusion of the forthcoming A. I. C. C. meeting.
('97', 270, 6, 13, 548224) I expect to speak to them through the radio probably on Wednesday at a time to be announced in due course.
('97', 270, 6, 14, 548331) Diwali will be on us in a few days.
('97', 270, 6, 15, 548367) A sister who is herself a refugee writes: 3
('97', 270, 7, 16, 548411) Whilst I admire this sister and others like her, I cannot help saying that she and those who think like her are wrong.
('97', 270, 7, 17, 548530) It is well known that a family which is overtaken by sorrow abstains from participation in festivities according to capacity.
('97', 270, 7, 18, 548656) It is an illustration of the doctrine of oneness on a very limited scale.
('97', 270, 7, 19, 548730) Break through the crust of limitation and India becomes one family.
('97', 270, 7, 20, 548798) If all limitations vanish, the whole world becomes one family, which it really is.
('97', 270, 7, 21, 548881) Not to cross these bars is to become callous to all fine feelings which make a man.
('97', 270, 7, 22, 548965) We must not be self centred or being falsely sentimental ignore
('97', 270, 8, 23, 549029) 1 The note is written on the back of a telegram dated November 8, 1947. Gandhiji observed silence on November 9. 2 Since Gandhiji was observing silence, his written speech was read out after the prayers.
('97', 270, 8, 24, 549233) 3 The letter is not reproduced here.
('97', 270, 8, 25, 549270) The correspondent had suggested that forgetting the sorrows of the past, the coming Diwali, being the first in independent India, should be celebrated by all.
('97', 271, 0, 1, 549429) 272 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 271, 1, 2, 549471) My advice to abstain from the rejoicings 1 is broadbased on many solid considerations.
('97', 271, 1, 3, 549558) The refugee problem is there, affecting lakhs of Hindus, Muslims and Sikhs.
('97', 271, 1, 4, 549634) There is as well want (albeit man made) of food and clothing.
('97', 271, 1, 5, 549696) The deeper cause is dishonesty of the many who can mould public opinion, obstinate refusal of sufferers to learn from their sufferings and extensive inhumanity of man to man.
('97', 271, 1, 6, 549871) I can see in this misery no cause for joy.
('97', 271, 1, 7, 549914) A resolute and wise refusal to take part in festivities will be an incentive to introspection and self purification.
('97', 271, 1, 8, 550031) Let us not do anything which will throw away a blessing which has been won after hard toil and tribulation.
('97', 271, 1, 9, 550139) I must now refer to a visit of friends from French India 2 during the week.
('97', 271, 1, 10, 550215) They complained that what I had said regarding what was claimed to be a satyagraha in Chandranagore, 3 was misused to suppress the aspirations of the people in French India for the fullest measure of autonomy under the Indian Union, whilst retaining at the same time, the wholesome influence of French culture.
('97', 271, 1, 11, 550526) They also told me that, as under the British Government, there were, in French India, those who might be likened to fifth columnists, who, in order to serve their selfish purpose, co operated with the French authorities who, in their turn, were aiming at suppressing the natural aspirations of the inhabitants of French India.
('97', 271, 1, 12, 550853) I would be very sorry indeed if the account given by the visitors from French India were accurate.
('97', 271, 1, 13, 550952) Anyway, my opinion is quite emphatic.
('97', 271, 1, 14, 550990) It is not possible for the inhabitants of these small foreign settlements 4 to remain under servility in the face of the millions of their countrymen who have become free from the British rule.
('97', 271, 1, 15, 551184) I am surprised that my friendly act towards Chandranagore could be distorted by anyone to suggest that I could ever countenance an inferior status in the little foreign settlements in India.
('97', 271, 1, 16, 551375) I hope, therefore, that the information given to me has no foundation in fact, and that the great French nation would never identify itself with the suppression of people, whether black or brown, in India or elsewhere.
('97', 271, 2, 17, 551594) Harijan, 16 11 1947
('97', 271, 3, 18, 551614) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 9 8 1947. 2 Vide “Message for Citizens of Chandranagore”, 8 11 1947. 3 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 17 8 1947. 4 Viz., Goa, Daman, Diu, Mahe, Pondicherry and Chandranagore

('97', 273, 1, 2, 553016) 253. A LETTER November 10, 1947 While each province develops and its regional language becomes the medium of instruction, each province will still remain an indivisible part of India.
('97', 273, 1, 3, 553200) Since there will be crores of students to derive the benefit of education and as they look upon the whole of India as their motherland, they will need a language commonly understood by students from all provinces.
('97', 273, 1, 4, 553414) In addition to the regional language, there will be the need for a language which has wide currency.
('97', 273, 1, 5, 553515) Hindi or Hindustani alone can play this role.
('97', 273, 1, 6, 553561) Hence all students should learn it in both the scripts as a compulsory second language.

('97', 273, 3, 9, 553689) 254. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING NEW DELHI, November 10, 1947 BROTHERS AND SISTERS, If we too become servants of God alone like Mirabai, all our troubles would be over.
('97', 273, 3, 10, 553855) 1 You would realize the significance of this after you have heard what I am going to say.
('97', 273, 3, 11, 553945) You must have read about Junagadh in the newspapers.
('97', 273, 3, 12, 553998) 2 I am satisfied after receiving two telegrams from Rajkot that the news published in the Press is absolutely correct.
('97', 273, 3, 13, 554117) The Prime Minister of Junagadh, Shah Nawaz Bhutto, and the Nawab are in Karachi.
('97', 273, 3, 14, 554198) The Deputy Prime Minister, Major Harvey Jones, is in Junagadh.
('97', 273, 3, 15, 554261) They are all responsible for Junagadh acceding to the Indian Union.
('97', 273, 3, 16, 554329) From this you have a right to infer that Qaid e Azam Jinnah also has given his sanction in this
('97', 273, 4, 17, 554425) 1 Gandhiji was referring to the bhajan by Mirabai, Mhane chakar rakhoji, sung during the prayer.
('97', 273, 4, 18, 554522) 2 According to a Press communique issued by the Government of India “the Regional Commissioner of Rajkot was approached .
('97', 273, 4, 19, 554644) by Major Harvey Jones.
('97', 273, 4, 20, 554667) with a letter from the Junagadh Dewan, appealing to the Government of India to take over the Junagadh administration.
('97', 273, 4, 21, 554785) This request was made in order to save the State from complete administrative break down.
('97', 273, 4, 22, 554875) The Government of India took over the administration of the Junagadh State on November 9. The Indian troops entered Junagadh city at 6 p.
('97', 274, 0, 1, 555013) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 275
('97', 274, 1, 2, 555063) matter.
('97', 274, 1, 3, 555071) If that is so, you can come to the conclusion that the troubles in Kashmir and Hyderabad 1 would also be over.
('97', 274, 1, 4, 555182) And I would even say that the trend now would be towards peace.
('97', 274, 1, 5, 555246) Both the Dominions would develop friendly relations and would work in mutual co operation.
('97', 274, 1, 6, 555337) I do not think about the Qaid e Azam as the Governor General.
('97', 274, 1, 7, 555399) As the Governor General the Qaid e Azam has no legal right at all to interfere in the affairs of Pakistan.
('97', 274, 1, 8, 555506) In that capacity he is in the same position as that of Lord Mountbatten in India who is only the constitutional Governor General.
('97', 274, 1, 9, 555636) Lord Mountbatten has gone for the wedding of a person who is more than a son to him and who is getting married to the future queen of England.
('97', 274, 1, 10, 555779) He could go there only after taking permission from his Cabinet and would be coming back by November 24, 1947. Hence in my opinion Jinnah is the maker of the present Muslim League and nothing can be done in Pakistan without his knowledge and sanction.
('97', 274, 1, 11, 556031) That is why I feel that if Jinnah has a hand in Junagadh’s accession to the Indian Union, it is a happy augury.
('97', 274, 1, 12, 556143) I wish to tell you something about my visit to Panipat.
('97', 274, 1, 13, 556199) Maulana Abul Kalam Azad accompanied me during my visit.
('97', 274, 1, 14, 556255) Rajkumari was also expected to accompany me, but she was at the Government House and I could not wait beyond 10.30 according to my watch.
('97', 274, 1, 15, 556393) I am glad I went to Panipat.
('97', 274, 1, 16, 556422) I saw the Muslim patients in the hospital there.
('97', 274, 2, 17, 556471) Some of them have been badly wounded.
('97', 274, 2, 18, 556509) But they are being given the best possible attention, because Rajkumari has sent there four doctors, nurses and medical assistants.
('97', 274, 2, 19, 556641) After that we met the represen tatives of the Muslims, local Hindus and the refugees.

('97', 276, 1, 2, 560278) 255. WHEN A BLESSING BECOMES A CURSE
('97', 276, 2, 3, 560315) In declining to give a blessing I said the following to a friend: No one who wants to start a worthy enterprise should ever wish to have anybody’s blessings, not even of the highest in the land.
('97', 276, 2, 4, 560510) A worthy enterprise carries its own blessing.
('97', 276, 2, 5, 560556) On the other hand, if an unworthy project receives any blessing from outside, it becomes, as it should become, a curse.
('97', 276, 2, 6, 560676) Indeed, I have come to the conclusion that a blessing from outside interferes with the even progress of one’s enterprise, because it very often induces a false hope and turns one away from the industry and watchfulness required for the success of a cause.
('97', 276, 2, 7, 560932) Though I have often said some such thing to many persons, it is best that this considered opinion is reproduced for the benefit of those who continue to ask for blessings for their enterprise.
('97', 276, 2, 8, 561125) Thus, I have been asked to bless memorials about great men and I have felt compelled to give much the same answer as the above.

('97', 276, 5, 11, 561302) 256. A PSYCHOLOGICAL EXPLANATION
('97', 276, 6, 12, 561335) The following is from Mr. Richard B. Gregg, whom many readers of the Harijan know as an American friend who used to live in Shantiniketan as also with me in Sabarmati years ago:
('97', 276, 7, 13, 561513) Though because of my ignorance I am hesitant, yet I venture to send you an idea that seems to me not only to explain with perhaps less moral blame a part of the recent communal violence in India but also to offer hope for the future.
('97', 276, 8, 14, 561747) It seems to me probable that much of this violence is an expression not so much of inter communal suspicion and hatred, but rather, and more deeply and originally, of the long pent up resentments of the masses because of their oppression.
('97', 276, 8, 15, 561986) The oppression was not only by foreign political rule but by foreign modern social, economic and financial ways which are contrary to the ancient habits of dharma which were a very part of the nature of the masses.
('97', 277, 0, 1, 562201) 278 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 277, 1, 2, 562243) foreign ways I mean such things as the English land holding system, usurious money lending, heavy taxes payable not in kind but in money, and other interferences with long established village life common to all Indian communities.
('97', 277, 2, 3, 562474) Psychological studies have shown clearly that severe frustrations suffered during the childhood of an individual generate resentments which are suppressed and remain suppressed long after the person who caused the original frustration had died, but later some occasion pulls a trigger, as it were, and releases the pent up energy of the old resentment which then pours forth in violence upon some perfectly innocent person.
('97', 277, 2, 4, 562898) This explains many crimes of violence, and perhaps some of the cruelties against the Jews in Europe.
('97', 277, 2, 5, 562999) In India the establishment of religious electorates created a channel into which it was easy for this energy to flow, but I believe the fearful energy of the explosion of wrath comes from the older cause I have mentioned.
('97', 277, 2, 6, 563221) Such an idea as this would help explain why in all countries all through history a major change of political power results in more or less violence and disorder.
('97', 277, 2, 7, 563383) The masses always suffer some oppression and, therefore, have resentments which flare up upon a shift of control or may be exploited by selfish leaders.
('97', 277, 3, 8, 563536) If this surmise is true, it suggests that the suspicion and hatred of one community towards another is not so deep as now appears.
('97', 277, 3, 9, 563667) It also means that as soon as the masses can be guided back into their ancient ways of life with the chief emphasis on religion and small organizations—village panchayats and communal family systems—the energy of the people will be turned from violence into creative channels.
('97', 277, 3, 10, 563944) I would expect that khadi work among the refugees might help start such a diversion of energy into sound channels.
('97', 277, 3, 11, 564059) In such a development I see hope.
('97', 277, 4, 12, 564093) Forgive me if this seems to be presumptuous.
('97', 277, 4, 13, 564138) I write it only in the hope that an humble outsider, just because he is outside, may see a gleam of encouragement that is not so easy to see in the dust and distraction of the struggle.
('97', 277, 4, 14, 564324) Anyhow, I love you and India.
('97', 277, 4, 15, 564354) Though many psychologists have recommended a study of psychology, I am sorry I have not been able, for want of time, to study the subject.
('97', 277, 4, 16, 564493) Mr. Gregg’s letter does not mend matters for me.
('97', 277, 4, 17, 564542) It does not fill me with any impelling enthusiasm for undertaking the study.
('97', 277, 4, 18, 564619) Mr. Gregg gives an explanation which mystifies the mind instead of clearing it.
('97', 277, 4, 19, 564699) “Hope for the future” I have never lost and never will, because it is embedded in my undying faith in non violence.
('97', 277, 4, 20, 564815) What has, however, clearly happened in my case is the discovery that in all probability there is a vital defect in my technique of the working of
('97', 278, 0, 1, 564961) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 279
('97', 278, 1, 2, 565011) non violence.
('97', 278, 1, 3, 565025) There was no real appreciation of non violence in the thirty years’ struggle against British Raj.
('97', 278, 1, 4, 565123) Therefore, the peace the masses maintained during that struggle of a generation with exemplary patience, had not come from within.
('97', 278, 1, 5, 565254) The pent up fury found an outlet when British Raj was gone.
('97', 278, 1, 6, 565314) It naturally vented itself in communal violence which was never fully absent and which was kept under suppression by the British bayonet.
('97', 278, 1, 7, 565452) This explanation seems to me to be all sufficing and convincing.
('97', 278, 1, 8, 565517) In it there is no room for failure of any hope.
('97', 278, 1, 9, 565565) Failure of my technique of non violence causes no loss of faith in non violence itself.
('97', 278, 1, 10, 565653) On the contrary, that faith is, if possible, strengthened by the discovery of a possible flaw in the technique.
('97', 278, 2, 11, 565765) NEW DELHI, November 11, 1947

('97', 279, 1, 2, 566838) You have yourself written ‘Radhabehn’ instead of mere ‘Radha’.
('97', 279, 1, 3, 566901) According to Indian custom, between friends ‘Radha behn’ is mere ‘Radha’.
('97', 279, 1, 4, 566975) The omission of the suffix behn, meaning sister, is a mark of great endearment and intimacy.
('97', 279, 1, 5, 567068) If you were writing to a casual acquaintance or an utter stranger, then you will naturally mention ‘Radha’ by her full name ‘Radhabehn’.
('97', 279, 1, 6, 567205) Therefore, I dare not call you ‘Govindbhai’ and ‘Radha’ as ‘Radhabehn’.
('97', 279, 1, 7, 567277) Bhai meansbrother,but when behn and bhai are used as suffixes to a name, they have merely an honorific value.

('97', 279, 1, 10, 567491) Also tell me, when you write, what you are doing for earning.
('97', 279, 1, 11, 567553) Or, are you living on past savings when you were practising as a lawyer?

I was surprised as well as happy to tell you this because I had not expected that the struggle which was being carried on behalf of the people of Junagadh would have such a happy ending.
('97', 283, 4, 6, 571992) 3 I had also expressed the fear that if the requestof the officials of Junagadh did not have the sanction from the Qaid e Azam Jinnah 4, it would not be proper to feel happy about it right now.
('97', 283, 4, 7, 572186) Hence, you would be amazed and distressed to know that the officials of Pakistan have protested against the Provisional Government assuming power on behalf of the people of Junagadh.
('97', 283, 4, 8, 572369) They have demanded “withdrawal of Indian troops from the State territory and relinquishment of the administration to the rightful Government and stoppage of violence and invasion of the State by people from the Indian Union”.
('97', 283, 4, 9, 572595) They also say that neither the Nawab nor the Dewan of Junagadh has any legal authority to negotiate permanent or provisional settlement with the Indian Union.
('97', 283, 4, 10, 572754) According to Pakistan the action of the Government of India is “a clear violation of the Pakistan territory and a breach of international law”.
('97', 283, 4, 11, 572898) Looking at the Press reports that have appeared yesterday, I find that there was neither a breach of international law in this matter, nor any operation by the Union Government to establish control over the

('97', 284, 1, 14, 575216) But that does not diminish the value of the principle I have laid down.
('97', 284, 1, 15, 575288) Hence, only the people of a particular State have a legal right to accede to one of the Unions.

('97', 284, 1, 17, 575607) If any ruler joins any of the Unions in his personal capacity, the Dominion cannot stand before the world to justify his action.

('97', 290, 4, 23, 586747) This is not correct.
('97', 290, 4, 24, 586768) If my suggestion is accepted, even if I stay in the house donated by you, I shall still be your guest because, if you wish, arrangements for goat’s milk, etc., will be made by you.
('97', 290, 4, 25, 586949) Goats, etc., cannot be kept on the premises I expect from you.
('97', 290, 4, 26, 587012) I may say one more thing, namely, that you are going to lose nothing by your donation to the Trust.

('97', 292, 2, 3, 588524) November 12, 1947
('97', 292, 3, 4, 588542) MY SUFFERING BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 292, 4, 5, 588577) I do not know if it is only you or whether others too are listening in to me today.
('97', 292, 4, 6, 588661) 2 This is only my second experience at the radio.
('97', 292, 4, 7, 588711) My first was many years ago 3 when I was in London for the Round Table Conference.
('97', 292, 4, 8, 588794) Though I am speaking from the Broadcasting House, I am not interested in such talks.
('97', 292, 4, 9, 588879) To suffer with the afflicted and try to relieve their suffering has been my life’s work.
('97', 292, 4, 10, 588968) I hope, therefore, that you will accept this talk in that light.
('97', 292, 4, 11, 589033) I was distressed when I heard that over two lakhs of refugees had arrived at Kurukshetra and more were pouring in.
('97', 292, 4, 12, 589148) The moment the news came to me, I longed to be with you but I could not get away at once from Delhi because the Congress Working Committee meetings were being held and my presence was required.
('97', 292, 4, 13, 589342) Seth Ghanshyamdas Birla suggested that I should broadcast a message to you and hence this talk.
('97', 292, 4, 14, 589438) Quite by accident, Gen.
('97', 292, 4, 15, 589462) Nathusingh who has organized the Kurukshetra Camp came to see me two days ago and told me about your sufferings.
('97', 292, 4, 16, 589575) The Central Government asked the military to take over the organization of your Camp, not because they wanted to coerce you in any way, but simply because the military are used to doing such organization and know how to do so efficiently.
('97', 292, 4, 17, 589814) Those who suffer know their sufferings best of all.
('97', 292, 4, 18, 589866) Yours is not an ordinary camp where it is possible for everyone to know each other.
('97', 292, 4, 19, 589950) Yours is really a city and your only bond with your co refugees is your suffering.
('97', 292, 4, 20, 590033) I was sorry to learn that there is not that co operation with authority or with your neighbours that there ought to be in order to make the Camp a success.

('97', 296, 1, 2, 596415) 272. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 296, 2, 3, 596445) November 12, 1947
('97', 296, 3, 4, 596463) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 296, 4, 5, 596485) Today is Diwali and I congratulate all of you on the occasion.
('97', 296, 4, 6, 596548) It is a great day in the Hindu calendar.
('97', 296, 4, 7, 596589) According to the Vikram Samvat, New Year begins tomorrow on Thursday 1. You must understand why Diwali is celebrated every year with illuminations.
('97', 296, 4, 8, 596737) In the great battle between Rama and Ravana, Rama symbolized the forces of good and Ravana the forces of evil.

('97', 298, 2, 3, 599895) NEW DELHI, November 12, 1947
('97', 298, 3, 4, 599924) MANIBHAI,
('97', 298, 4, 5, 599934) I have your letter of the 5th.
('97', 298, 4, 6, 599965) I had a long discussion with Dr. Dinshaw and Jehangir Patel.
('97', 298, 4, 7, 600026) I am glad that the inauguration is to be done by Kakasaheb 1. Tell all the friends at Uruli that I am both happy and sorry that I shall not be able to attend the function.
('97', 298, 4, 8, 600198) I am happy because the work I am doing here is also, according to me, part of the work that is being done at Uruli; for, the nature cure of my conception includes treatment of both body and mind.
('97', 298, 4, 9, 600394) If we look at the matter from that point of view, curing the people here of their psychological perversion is bound to have an effect in Uruli also and would serve as a fine illustration of nature cure.
('97', 298, 4, 10, 600597) I am not sorry that Gokhale and Paramanand have left.
('97', 298, 4, 11, 600651) It will be enough if Dr. Bhagwat 2 stays on.
('97', 298, 4, 12, 600696) I should be glad if Dhiru clings to the institution till the end and observes all the rules, too.
('97', 298, 4, 13, 600794) But I will be satisfied if at least Balkoba 3 and you 4 remain.
('97', 298, 4, 14, 600858) That is, I should be very pleased even if you alone decide to dedicate your life to Uruli.
('97', 298, 4, 15, 600949) By and by you will find other workers from the local population.
('97', 298, 4, 16, 601014) I should think it a disgrace to have to import workers from outside.
('97', 298, 4, 17, 601083) It would mean failure of nature cure.
('97', 298, 4, 18, 601121) The present heavy burden on you will not last.
('97', 298, 4, 19, 601168) You should admit only as many patients as you can easily look after.
('97', 298, 4, 20, 601237) If you can persuade some young men there to volunteer their services, you can train them.
('97', 298, 4, 21, 601327) You will need a woman worker from outside.
('97', 298, 4, 22, 601370) By yourself, you will not be able to attract any woman worker from among the local people.
('97', 298, 4, 23, 601461) Let us see what the future brings.
('97', 298, 4, 24, 601496) The division into nature cure, village uplift work and Ashram

('97', 300, 1, 2, 603892) 274. NO INCONSISTENCY
('97', 300, 2, 3, 603914) A subscriber to the Harijan presents as follows what appears to him to be a conundrum to which I have sent the following reply:
('97', 300, 3, 4, 604042) The other day you admitted 1 that you had not seen God face to face.
('97', 300, 3, 5, 604111) In the Prefaceto My Experiments with Truth you have stated that you have seen God in the embodiment of Truth from a far distance.
('97', 300, 3, 6, 604241) The two statements appear to be incompatible.
('97', 300, 3, 7, 604287) Kindly elucidate for proper understanding.
('97', 300, 4, 8, 604330) There is a big gulf between ‘seeing God face to face’ and ‘seeing Him in the embodiment of Truth from a far distance’.
('97', 300, 4, 9, 604449) In my opinion the two statements are not only not incompatible but each explains the other.
('97', 300, 4, 10, 604541) We see the Himalayas from a very great distance and when we are on the top we have seen the Himalayas face to face.
('97', 300, 4, 11, 604657) Millions can see them from hundreds of miles away if they are within the range of that seeing distance, but few having arrived at the top after years of travel see them face to face.
('97', 300, 4, 12, 604840) This does not seem to need elucidation in the columns of the Harijan.
('97', 300, 4, 13, 604910) Nevertheless, I send your letter and my reply for publication in the Harijan, lest there may be some like you who think that there is any inconsistency between the two statements quoted by you.
('97', 300, 5, 14, 605104) November 13, 1947 Harijan, 23 11 1947
('97', 300, 6, 15, 605142) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 23 7 1947.

('97', 304, 1, 2, 609862) 279. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 304, 2, 3, 609892) November 13, 1947
('97', 304, 3, 4, 609910) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 304, 4, 5, 609932) Yesterday was Diwali and today is the New Year.
('97', 304, 4, 6, 609980) I have heard and I heard it all the more yesterday that Delhi has great illuminations on Diwali day which perhaps beat even the illuminations in Bombay.
('97', 304, 4, 7, 610133) There are magnificent illuminations in Bombay every year.
('97', 304, 4, 8, 610191) I was pleased to hear that people had realized that this is not the time to celebrate Diwali.
('97', 304, 4, 9, 610285) But the superstition still persists that there should be at least some lights on Diwali day.
('97', 304, 4, 10, 610378) Hence, oil lamps were seen at some places.
('97', 304, 4, 11, 610421) There were some electric lights, too, though very few.
('97', 304, 4, 12, 610476) I do not go out but I get all the information.
('97', 304, 4, 13, 610523) The new year begins today.
('97', 304, 4, 14, 610550) I had already mentioned it yesterday, but I may as well refer to it again.
('97', 304, 4, 15, 610625) On New Year day we make some pious resolutions and by the grace of God try to follow them all through the year.
('97', 304, 4, 16, 610737) If we do this, and if the atmosphere prevailing today changes and the Hindus and Muslims live together in amity, we shall have a right to celebrate the next Diwali with illuminations.
('97', 304, 4, 17, 610921) We can accomplish nothing by regarding one another as enemies.
('97', 304, 4, 18, 610984) That is why I stressed that this is no occasion for an outward celebration of Diwali.
('97', 304, 4, 19, 611070) We should try to illumine our hearts.
('97', 304, 4, 20, 611108) Rama resides in our hearts and there is a continuous battle between Rama and Ravana raging inside us.
('97', 304, 4, 21, 611210) If, in our hearts and not outside, Ravana triumphs over Rama, it means that there is no light but darkness in our hearts.
('97', 304, 4, 22, 611332) If, instead, it is Rama who triumphs over Ravana, then there is indeed light in our hearts and this entitles us to have illuminations outside as well.
('97', 304, 4, 23, 611483) Hence, all is well if the light outside is the symbol of the light within.
('97', 304, 4, 24, 611558) Instead, if there is darkness in our hearts and we have illuminations outside and try to convince ourselves that everything is fine, we are hypocrites and liars.
('97', 304, 4, 25, 611720) I only hope that we are never untruthful.
('97', 304, 4, 26, 611762) I told you yesterday that I would say something about the meetings of Congress Working Committee.
('97', 304, 4, 27, 611860) There was no time yesterday because I did not want to take more than fifteen minutes.
('97', 304, 4, 28, 611946) Today is the third day of the Congress Working Committee meeting.
('97', 304, 4, 29, 612012) It is still in session.
('97', 304, 4, 30, 612036) One important thing that I am entitled to tell you is
('97', 305, 0, 1, 612090) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 305, 1, 2, 612132) that the members of the Working Committee and others 1 who have been specially invited by Acharya Kripalani 2 have been sitting together in the meetings for the last three days.
('97', 305, 1, 3, 612310) It is a good thing that they are unanimously of the opinion that it has been the policy of the Congress since its inception, that is, for the last sixty years, that Congress is not an institution that propagates any particular religion.
('97', 305, 1, 4, 612547) There are people of all religions in the Congress or, say, because it belongs to people of different religions, it does not belong to any one particular religion.
('97', 305, 1, 5, 612710) It is an organization of the masses and it has to function only for political goals.
('97', 305, 1, 6, 612795) It does not remain a religious body if it functions that way.
('97', 305, 1, 7, 612857) Supposing one of the policies of the Congress is to provide food to all the people, to be true to its name it must provide food for everybody.
('97', 305, 1, 8, 613000) If the Congress provides food only to those who are with it or, say, only to the Hindus and the Sikhs because they are in a majority and allows others to starve and says that it is not bothered about them, it would be a religious body superficially but in fact it would become an irreligious organization.
('97', 305, 1, 9, 613306) If it advocates service of only those who are its followers and wants others to be killed, it would not be dharma, but adharma 3 in the name of dharma.
('97', 305, 1, 10, 613458) If I am a worshipper of Rama and do not worship any god, the law cannot force me to do so.
('97', 305, 1, 11, 613549) It is another matter if I act against my faith or become a coward and say that a particular man is carrying a sword and that if I do not obey him he would kill me.
('97', 305, 1, 12, 613713) But, if I am not a coward, when I am forced to worship Allah instead of Rama, I should have, and I have, a right to insist that I would worship only Rama and not Allah.
('97', 305, 1, 13, 613882) All that the other person can do is to cut my throat.
('97', 305, 1, 14, 613936) Let him do so.
('97', 305, 1, 15, 613951) Then it is a matter of faith, which we call personal or individual dharma.
('97', 305, 1, 16, 614026) There is no power on earth which can destroy one’s personal dharma.
('97', 305, 1, 17, 614094) Of course, it can be destroyed when the individual himself wants to do it, or when, instead of light, there is only darkness in one’s heart.
('97', 305, 1, 18, 614235) In such circumstances, when he cannot make up his mind he takes help from someone or just follows the
('97', 305, 2, 19, 614337) 1 The special invitees to the Congress Working Committee meeting were: B. G. Kher, Pattabhi Sitaramayya, S. K. Patil, Jayaprakash Narayan, Kamaraj Nadar, Dr. Saifuddin Kitchlew and Prof.
('97', 305, 2, 20, 614524) N. G. Ranga.
('97', 305, 2, 21, 614537) 2 J. B. Kripalani (1888 1982); Principal, Gujarat Vidyapith, 1920 27, General Secretary of the Indian National Congress, 1934 45; its President, 1946 47, Member, Constituent Assembly; started the Krishak Mazdoor Praja Party which later merged into the Praja Socialist Party; resigned from the Praja Socialist Party in 1954 3 Contrary to dharma
('97', 306, 0, 1, 614881) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 307
('97', 306, 1, 2, 614931) bidding of some other person because he is surrounded by darkness.
('97', 306, 1, 3, 614998) But the person who is steadfast in his faith would listen to the command only of God and none else.
('97', 306, 1, 4, 615098) Likewise, when an organization functions for the welfare of the people, only the things which are consistent with dharma apply to everybody and nothing else.
('97', 306, 1, 5, 615256) And in this way it embodies dharma and not adharma.
('97', 306, 1, 6, 615308) That, in my view, is the true meaning of politics and the Congress has followed this from the time of its inception.
('97', 306, 1, 7, 615425) You should be happy that it is so, whether you belong to the Congress or not.
('97', 306, 1, 8, 615503) Even I do not belong to the Congress.
('97', 306, 1, 9, 615541) But so what?
('97', 306, 1, 10, 615554) After all, I have been a Congress worker and have served it.
('97', 306, 1, 11, 615615) What does it matter if I do not pay four annas for membership?
('97', 306, 1, 12, 615678) I must pay the membership fee of four annas if I want to be its President.
('97', 306, 1, 13, 615753) But that is not the question.
('97', 306, 1, 14, 615783) If all of you think like me, it is really remarkable.
('97', 306, 1, 15, 615837) It is good if you have registered yourselves as Congress members.
('97', 306, 1, 16, 615903) It is well, too, if you are serving the Congress from outside.
('97', 306, 1, 17, 615966) I have been sitting with the Congress Working Committee for the past three days.
('97', 306, 1, 18, 616047) There are many differences of opinion in the Working Committee.
('97', 306, 1, 19, 616111) The members are human beings after all, they are not stones.
('97', 306, 1, 20, 616172) One member says one thing and another member says something else.
('97', 306, 1, 21, 616238) There may be differences of opinion, but there should be no contradiction in behaviour.
('97', 306, 1, 22, 616326) That is why they spent three days in discussing these differences.
('97', 306, 1, 23, 616393) But they are all united about one thing, that is, that the Congress should continue to be what it has been so far.
('97', 306, 1, 24, 616508) If in the process it has to perish, let it perish.
('97', 306, 1, 25, 616559) Of course it cannot be completely wiped out, though it can remain in minority.
('97', 306, 1, 26, 616638) And I doubt if it is in majority at present.
('97', 306, 1, 27, 616683) For there should have been no Pakistan if the Congress were in majority.
('97', 306, 1, 28, 616756) I can quote many instances to show how much the Muslims have been oppressed in India.
('97', 306, 1, 29, 616842) But what should I say?
('97', 306, 1, 30, 616865) You know more than I do.
('97', 306, 1, 31, 616890) Have the Hindus and the Sikhs in Pakistan been oppressed less?
('97', 306, 1, 32, 616953) But let us not talk about it.
('97', 306, 1, 33, 616983) It is not for us to think of those things.
('97', 306, 1, 34, 617026) Should I stop following my religion because others in the world do not adhere to theirs?
('97', 306, 1, 35, 617115) That is why the Congress, whether it is in majority or minority, must adhere to its original objective.
('97', 306, 1, 36, 617219) It is framing its resolutions from that point of view.
('97', 306, 1, 37, 617274) It wants to present its views in a straightforward, sincere manner.
('97', 306, 1, 38, 617342) What can be more straightforward than that we do not wish to compel a single Muslim to go away from here?
('97', 306, 1, 39, 617448) The point is not whether the Muslims are good or bad.
('97', 306, 1, 40, 617502) Can we claim that only angels have a right to live in India, and, if not angels, only good people can remain here?
('97', 306, 1, 41, 617617) And, if only the good people can live here,
('97', 307, 0, 1, 617661) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 307, 1, 2, 617703) are there no bad or wicked people among the Hindus and the Sikhs?
('97', 307, 1, 3, 617769) And if there are wicked people among them, what would you say to them?
('97', 307, 1, 4, 617840) Would you order them to leave and threaten to cut their throats with a sword if they refused to oblige?
('97', 307, 1, 5, 617944) You have no right to consider anybody wicked or to kill him.
('97', 307, 1, 6, 618005) We have committed excesses against the Muslims.
('97', 307, 1, 7, 618053) There may be some exaggeration in the reports I receive every day.
('97', 307, 1, 8, 618120) But ultimately I find that there is truth in those reports.
('97', 307, 1, 9, 618180) When anything is done in the name of the Congress, the A. I. C. C. has to be summoned.
('97', 307, 1, 10, 618267) The plenary session of the Congress is held once a year.
('97', 307, 1, 11, 618324) It is like a big show and because there is such a big crowd nobody can even think clearly.
('97', 307, 1, 12, 618415) But they know that the A. I. C. C. carries on its work with due deliberation and so they put their seal on what it does.
('97', 307, 1, 13, 618536) Thus the A.I.C.C.is always on the alert.
('97', 307, 1, 14, 618577) It is going to meet the day after tomorrow.
('97', 307, 1, 15, 618621) It is the Working Committee which has to place the agenda before the A I. C. C. It is subservient to the A. I. C. C. If the Working Committee does not place the agenda before it, then the A. I. C. C. can say that they have not functioned well and the members of the Working Committee have to resign.
('97', 307, 1, 16, 618921) The A. I. C. C. can form the Working Committee or terminate it.
('97', 307, 1, 17, 618985) If the A. I. C. C. does not accept its proposals or makes great amendments to those proposals, then also it should resign.
('97', 307, 1, 18, 619108) That is why the Working Committee says that it wants to do everything in the name of the A. I. C. C. If it does anything in its own name, it does not have the same effect.
('97', 307, 1, 19, 619280) For, what is the use of 15 individuals proclaiming that not a single Muslim should be killed?
('97', 307, 1, 20, 619374) If the same thing is done in the name of the A. I. C. C., its effect is much greater.
('97', 307, 1, 21, 619460) That is why I have been advising the Congress Working Committee for the past three days that it should categorically state that this is the only thing it wishes to carry out.
('97', 307, 1, 22, 619635) Let us not worry if this pleases the people or displeases them.
('97', 307, 1, 23, 619699) If we are true servants of the Congress, then this is the only thing we have to do.
('97', 307, 1, 24, 619783) Let the A. I. C. C. brush it aside if it so wishes.
('97', 307, 1, 25, 619835) After all we, and also Pakistan, have to stand before the world.
('97', 307, 1, 26, 619900) We do many things because we are worried about what the world may say.
('97', 307, 1, 27, 619971) I would say that you should do only what you think is correct.
('97', 307, 1, 28, 620034) Then the world too would regard it as correct.
('97', 307, 1, 29, 620081) It is said that the word of the Panch 1 is like the word of God.
('97', 307, 1, 30, 620146) The world is like the Panch.
('97', 307, 1, 31, 620175) That is why what the world says is divine justice in the true sense.
('97', 307, 1, 32, 620244) The Working Committee is in session today.
('97', 307, 1, 33, 620287) It would be meeting
('97', 307, 2, 34, 620307) 1 Elected members of a village panchayat; also, an arbitrator
('97', 308, 0, 1, 620369) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 309
('97', 308, 1, 2, 620419) again tomorrow.
('97', 308, 1, 3, 620435) It is my prayer that it should place before the A. I. C. C. such a resolution which would bring victory to India and everybody would be able to live in peace here.
('97', 308, 1, 4, 620599) It does not mean that we should let the traitors do as they please.
('97', 308, 1, 5, 620667) But we should not take it for granted that a particular person is a traitor.
('97', 308, 1, 6, 620744) If someone is proved to be a traitor, you may kill him, hang him, shoot him.
('97', 308, 1, 7, 620821) But if you say that no Muslim can ever be loyal or that only the Hindus and the Sikhs have a monopoly of loyalty, then I would say that it would be a grave thing.
('97', 308, 1, 8, 620984) I am confident that the Congress would never do such a thing.
('97', 308, 1, 9, 621046) You must also pray that through the advice of the Congress we and the whole country as well as other parts of the world rise high.
('97', 308, 1, 10, 621177) The Congress is meant only to raise the country high.
('97', 308, 1, 11, 621231) But the Congress does not wish to raise itself by depriving anybody of his wealth or other property.
('97', 308, 1, 12, 621332) The Congress would die for the sake of the whole world, but would not kill anyone.
('97', 308, 1, 13, 621415) This has been the objective of the Congress, not since I entered it, but for many years.
('97', 308, 1, 14, 621504) The Congress has tried to prevent the Europeans who come here from looting the country, so that people of Asia and Africa could live in peace.
('97', 308, 1, 15, 621647) India has to remain alive for this purpose.
('97', 308, 1, 16, 621691) It is for this that India has attained her independence and for no other purpose.

('97', 309, 3, 6, 622042) How far they will be put into practice God only knows.

('97', 309, 3, 8, 622403) In this way we shall be able to do a great deal.

('97', 311, 1, 2, 624594) 283. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 311, 2, 3, 624624) November 14, 1947
('97', 311, 3, 4, 624642) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 311, 4, 5, 624664) When I was on fast 1 in the Aga Khan Palace which was turned into a jail to imprison me, Sarojini Devi 2, Mirabehn 3 and Mahadev bhai 4, this bhajan 5 had captured me.
('97', 311, 4, 6, 624832) Here I do not wish to go into the causes of the fast.
('97', 311, 4, 7, 624886) I would like to mention only one thing in that connection, and it is that I survived for 21 days not because of the amount of water I used to drink, or the orange juice which I took for some days, or the extraordinary medical care, but because I had installed in my heart God whom I call Rama.
('97', 311, 4, 8, 625180) I was so much attracted by the lines of this bhajan that I instructed the persons concerned to send me the correct words by telegram, as I had forgotten those words at the time.
('97', 311, 4, 9, 625358) I was very happy when I received the whole bhajan by reply telegram.
('97', 311, 4, 10, 625427) The essence of the bhajan is that Ramanama is everything and other gods count for nothing compared to Him.
('97', 311, 4, 11, 625534) I am mentioning this instructive episode in my life because I want the A. I. C. C. members to think and deliberate with God in their hearts when they meet for the important session on Saturday.
('97', 311, 4, 12, 625728) They will have to do so because they are representatives of all Congressmen.
('97', 311, 4, 13, 625805) Hence, if the leading Congressmen have Satan instead of God in their hearts they are not true to their salt.
('97', 311, 4, 14, 625914) The Working Committee discussed for full three hours the resolutions to be placed before the A. I. C. C. During the discussion the question arose as to how the Hindu and the Sikh refugees could be honourably and safely sent back to their homes in West Punjab.
('97', 311, 4, 15, 626174) They came to the conclusion that the trouble started from the Pakistan side,
('97', 311, 5, 16, 626251) 1 From February 10 to March 3, 1943. 2 Sarojini Naidu (1879 1949); poetess and orator; President of the Indian National Congress in 1925; Governor of U. P., 1947 49 3 Nee Madeleine Slade; joined Gandhiji in 1925
('97', 311, 6, 17, 626463) 4 Mahadev Desai (1892 1942);Gandhiji’s private secretary from 1917 till his death on August 15, 1942 5 “I depend solely on my Rama, all others are of no avail,” a bhajan by Tulsidas
('97', 312, 0, 1, 626645) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 313
('97', 312, 1, 2, 626695) but they also realized that when the wrong was copied on such a large scale and when the Hindus and the Sikhs resorted to acts of retaliation in East Punjab and the adjoining areas of the Union, the question of where the trouble started became insignificant.
('97', 312, 1, 3, 626954) If the A. I. C. C. could claim with confidence that so far as the Indian Union was concerned, the days of madness were over and sanity reigned from one end of the Union to the other, the Committee could also say that the Dominion of Pakistan would be obliged to call back the Hindu and Sikh refugees with honour and safety.
('97', 312, 1, 4, 627278) Such a situation can be created only when all Hindus and Sikhs install Rama in their hearts instead of Ravana.
('97', 312, 1, 5, 627389) For, when you drive Satan out of your hearts and give up the present madness, every Muslim child will be able to move about with as much freedom as a Hindu or a Sikh child.
('97', 312, 1, 6, 627562) Then, I have no doubt, the Muslim refugees who have left their homes under duress will gladly come over and the way will be cleared for the honourable and safe return of the Hindu and Sikh refugees to Pakistan.
('97', 312, 1, 7, 627773) Will my words have an echo in your hearts and will the A.I.C.C. be able to come to a wise and just conclusion?

('97', 313, 0, 1, 628156) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 313, 1, 2, 628198) 285. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI
('97', 313, 2, 3, 628233) NEW DELHI, November 15, 1947
('97', 313, 3, 4, 628262) MATHURADAS,
('97', 313, 4, 5, 628274) It is with great difficulty that I am dictating this letter when it is time for my afternoon sleep.
('97', 313, 4, 6, 628374) I am lying in the sun with a mud pack.
('97', 313, 4, 7, 628413) It feels very nice to be in the sun.
('97', 313, 4, 8, 628450) I cannot be convinced that no improvement in your health is possible now.
('97', 313, 4, 9, 628524) I have no faith in the prognosis of doctors.
('97', 313, 4, 10, 628569) I would rather that regardless of what they say you had faith in God and let things happen as they would.
('97', 313, 4, 11, 628675) In your condition, instead of reading newspapers, should you not read books?
('97', 313, 4, 12, 628752) Read Sanskrit or Gujarati.
('97', 313, 4, 13, 628779) There are beautiful translations of Sanskrit books in Gujarati.
('97', 313, 4, 14, 628843) Whatever occurs to you while reading, you can dictate.
('97', 313, 4, 15, 628898) Why don’t you engage a person who would take dictation and read out what you wish to hear?
('97', 313, 4, 16, 628989) Waccha had almost gone blind but till the last moment he had his favourite books read out to him.
('97', 313, 4, 17, 629087) Several such instances can be cited.
('97', 313, 4, 18, 629124) I am aware that I cannot see truth if I am impatient.
('97', 313, 4, 19, 629178) It means nothing that I am free of pride in the eyes of the world.
('97', 313, 4, 20, 629245) If it should be untrue, ahimsa would still be a long way off.
('97', 313, 4, 21, 629307) The same about truth.
('97', 313, 4, 22, 629329) In that case the very idea of the success of non violence cancels itself out.
('97', 313, 4, 23, 629407) Where there is non violence, failure is impossible.
('97', 313, 4, 24, 629459) So, wherever there is failure, all that can be said is that there had been no non violence.
('97', 313, 4, 25, 629551) It is another question as to who can distinguish between success and failure.
('97', 313, 4, 26, 629629) I cannot be a witness to faults like pride, impatience, etc., I may be having.
('97', 313, 4, 27, 629708) To a certain extent, only outsiders can be witness.
('97', 313, 4, 28, 629760) The true witness is only God.
('97', 313, 4, 29, 629790) It should not even be imagined that the Hindus are being chided too much.
('97', 313, 5, 30, 629864) Blessings from BAPU
('97', 313, 6, 31, 629884) From the Gujarati original: Pyarelal Papers.

('97', 316, 6, 12, 633201) 290. SPEECH AT A. I. C. C. MEETING
('97', 316, 7, 13, 633236) November 15, 1947
('97', 316, 8, 14, 633254) I have come in your midst today.

('97', 337, 1, 2, 675558) 307. A LETTER
('97', 337, 2, 3, 675572) November 17, 1947
('97', 337, 3, 4, 675590) You will find in Harijanbandhu my recent article 1 on controls.
('97', 337, 3, 5, 675654) I have no doubt in my mind that controls will mean controls over our minds too, and we shall not be able to taste the sweet fruit of freedom.
('97', 337, 3, 6, 675796) Many people argue the case before me; but when I start asking questions they cannot answer them.
('97', 337, 3, 7, 675893) I agree that it would be good if we could provide jobs for the staff that will be retrenched when controls are removed.
('97', 337, 3, 8, 676013) I feel like laughing when these people, motivated by their self interest for the time being, argue that a revolt would erupt in India if there were no controls.
('97', 337, 3, 9, 676174) But at the same time I also feel depressed.
('97', 337, 3, 10, 676218) I would remove controls even at the cost of a revolt.
('97', 337, 3, 11, 676272) That has always been my way.
('97', 337, 3, 12, 676301) I have travelled thus far through fiery ordeals.
('97', 337, 3, 13, 676350) And I have limitless faith in God.
('97', 337, 3, 14, 676385) Don’t we have a proverb, “He who has provided the teeth will also provide the food?” There is an element of truth in it.
('97', 337, 3, 15, 676506) But there must also be full effort.
('97', 337, 3, 16, 676542) I am pulling on somehow.
('97', 337, 3, 17, 676567) These days we are busy with the A.I.C.C. meeting.
('97', 337, 3, 18, 676617) There is great pressure of work.
('97', 337, 3, 19, 676650) I hardly have time to breathe.
('97', 337, 3, 20, 676681) Letters have heaped up.
('97', 337, 3, 21, 676705) I am all right.
('97', 337, 3, 22, 676721) Everything here is quite uncertain at the moment.
('97', 337, 3, 23, 676771) But God will certainly show a way out.
('97', 337, 3, 24, 676810) I hope all of you are quite well.
('97', 337, 3, 25, 676844) Blessings to all.

('97', 339, 1, 2, 678354) 310. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING 1
('97', 339, 2, 3, 678386) November 17, 1947
('97', 339, 3, 4, 678404) Yesterday I spoke about Rampur and our countrymen in South Africa.
('97', 339, 3, 5, 678471) Today I feel I must deal more fully with the latter subject.
('97', 339, 3, 6, 678532) I have lived in South Africa for twenty years from 1893 to 1914 with a break probably of one year.
('97', 339, 3, 7, 678631) During that long and formative period of my life I came naturally in closest contact with all kinds of Indians as also with the white settlers of that sub continent almost as big as ours.
('97', 339, 3, 8, 678819) Between then and now if South Africa has risen, India has made giant strides.
('97', 339, 3, 9, 678897) What seemed to be impossible only the other day has happened.
('97', 339, 3, 10, 678959) We need not go into the causes.
('97', 339, 3, 11, 678991) The fact is that India has come into the British Commonwealth, i.e., she has exactly the same status as the Union of South Africa.
('97', 339, 3, 12, 679122) Should members of one Dominion be helots in another Dominion?
('97', 339, 3, 13, 679184) An Asiatic nation enters the Commonwealth for the first time in its history with the willing consent of all the members of the Commonwealth.
('97', 339, 3, 14, 679325) Mark now the following message that the Administrator Dr. S. P. Barnard of Orangia sent to the Natal Indian Congress of Durban five days after the entry of India in the Commonwealth:
('97', 339, 4, 15, 679508) As you are celebrating Independence of the new Dominions which you can consider a great day in the annals of Indian history, I hope all Indians in South Africa will now emigrate voluntarily to the new Dominions to act as missionaries of the gospel they have been taught in South Africa, namely, to live in peace and order and not to fight in communal riots in which hundreds are being killed in India.
('97', 339, 4, 16, 679910) It is worthy of note that Dr Barnard evidently doubts whether the entry was a great event.
('97', 339, 4, 17, 680001) And then he treats the Natal Indian Congress with the gratuitous advice that the Indians of South Africa should emigrate to India and become “missionaries of the gospel they have been taught in South Africa, namely, to live in peace and order and not to fight in communal riots”.
('97', 339, 4, 18, 680281) I very much fear that this message is typical of the average white man’s mind in the South African Dominion.
('97', 339, 4, 19, 680390) Hence the series of disabilities on our countrymen
('97', 339, 5, 20, 680441) 1 As Gandhiji was observing silence, his written message in Hindustani was read out.
('97', 340, 0, 1, 680526) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 341
('97', 340, 1, 2, 680576) for the crime of being Asiatics and having a coloured pigment.
('97', 340, 1, 3, 680639) I appeal to the best western mind of South Africa to revise this anti Asiatic and anti colour prejudice.
('97', 340, 1, 4, 680744) They have an overwhelming African population in their midst.
('97', 340, 1, 5, 680805) They are worse treated in some respects than the Asiatics.
('97', 340, 1, 6, 680864) I urge the European settlers to read the signs of the times.
('97', 340, 1, 7, 680925) Either this prejudice is wrong from every point of view or the British people and their fellow members of the great Commonwealth have made an unpardonable mistake in admitting Asiatic countries as members.
('97', 340, 1, 8, 681131) Burma is about to get her independence, 1 Ceylon will presently become a member of the Commonwealth.
('97', 340, 1, 9, 681232) 2 What does it mean?
('97', 340, 1, 10, 681253) Membership of the Commonwealth is, I am taught, as good as independence, if not superior to it.
('97', 340, 1, 11, 681349) Responsible men and women of these independent States need to ponder well as to what they will do with their independence.
('97', 340, 1, 12, 681472) Is all this movement towards multiplying independent States, though proper and healthy in itself, to result in another war more deadly, if possible, than the last two, or is it to end, as it should, in the promotion of universal brotherhood?
('97', 340, 1, 13, 681714) “A man becomes what he thinks”, says an Upanishad mantra 3. Experience of wise men testifies to the truth of the aphorism.
('97', 340, 1, 14, 681837) The world will thus become what its wise men think.
('97', 340, 1, 15, 681889) An idle thought is no thought.

('97', 340, 1, 17, 682022) They will not think.
('97', 340, 1, 18, 682043) Like a mob they will follow.
('97', 340, 1, 19, 682072) 4 Independence should mean democracy.

('97', 340, 1, 21, 682241) South Africa has many wise men and women as it has also

('97', 340, 3, 23, 682603) —Brihadaranyadopanishad, 4. 4.5 According as one acts, according as one behaves, so does he become.
('97', 340, 3, 24, 682703) The doer of good becomes good, the doer of evil becomes evil.
('97', 340, 3, 25, 682765) One becomes virtuous by virtuous action, bad by bad action.
