('97', 342, 1, 2, 685095) 311. A LETTER
('97', 342, 2, 3, 685109) November 18, 1947
('97', 342, 4, 4, 685127) Manudi took, or it would be equally true to say, I gave her, about ten minutes before writing this letter to you.
('97', 342, 4, 5, 685241) She read out your letter to me and asked a question.
('97', 342, 4, 6, 685294) In answer to that I gave her a long lecture.
('97', 342, 4, 7, 685339) Has it not become my profession to lecture people?
('97', 342, 4, 8, 685390) I would not be surprised if it only justified the ancient Sanskrit saying “wise in advising others”.
('97', 342, 4, 9, 685491) Because today unforeseen events are overtaking us from all sides, I am fumbling in the dark in search of a way out.
('97', 342, 4, 10, 685607) Your letter is certainly inspiring; but I have to do or die here.
('97', 342, 4, 11, 685673) If heart unity is not restored in Delhi, I can see flames raging all over India.
('97', 342, 4, 12, 685754) And I have no strength, nor the courage to reach that far.
('97', 342, 4, 13, 685813) I would much rather spend myself in Delhi.
('97', 342, 4, 14, 685856) I must admit that only the intellectuals and political leaders are responsible for the present distressing atmosphere.
('97', 342, 4, 15, 685975) The poor peasants in the villages do not even know that India has become free.
('97', 342, 4, 16, 686054) Hence I have not the least hesitation in saying that we are grossly abusing the intelligence and energy which God has bestowed upon us.
('97', 342, 4, 17, 686190) Now you will understand what it is I am trying to put across or what pain fills my heart.
('97', 342, 4, 18, 686280) My prayer today is “one step enough for me” 2. I am keeping well in spite of all that is happening and I hope you are also well.
('97', 342, 4, 19, 686409) The fact that one can keep fit physically and mentally, whatever the circumstances be, is a sign of one’s nearness to God.
('97', 342, 4, 20, 686532) My Rama is not a man with two hands and two feet.
('97', 342, 4, 21, 686582) But if I am perfectly fit it is due to Rama’s grace.
('97', 342, 4, 22, 686635) Manudi is well trained.
('97', 342, 4, 23, 686659) But after all she is only a girl, in the playful age of 16 or 17—she is almost a child.
('97', 342, 4, 24, 686747) When I discuss with her or dictate to her such spiritual subjects, it occurs to me how dense I was at the age of 18. As compared to that, this girl has developed quite well.
('97', 342, 4, 25, 686921) At the same time I am also conscious that I may be putting too heavy a burden on her tender mind with my discussions or dictations of such highly pedantic matters.
('97', 342, 4, 26, 687085) But she is always very happy and keeps cheerful.
('97', 342, 4, 27, 687134) Only she does not take care of herself, because of which I have to scold her

('97', 352, 6, 23, 706091) 321. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 352, 7, 24, 706121) November 19, 1947
('97', 352, 8, 25, 706139) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 352, 9, 26, 706161) Last evening I referred to the main Resolution on Hindu Muslim relations passed by the A.I.C.C. But unfortunately today itself I have to cite an instance to show how that Resolution is being rendered futile in Delhi.
('97', 352, 9, 27, 706378) I had never imagined that on the very evening when I was expressing my doubt about the behaviour of the public, that doubt would be proved right in the heart of old Delhi.
('97', 352, 9, 28, 706550) I was told last night that a large crowd of Hindus and Sikhs had
('97', 353, 0, 1, 706615) 354 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 353, 1, 2, 706657) gathered in front of a Muslim’s shop in Chandni Chowk.
('97', 353, 1, 3, 706712) Though the shop belonged to a Muslim, the owner had abandoned it and gone away.
('97', 353, 1, 4, 706792) The shop had been given to a refugee on condition that he would give it up when the owner returned.

('97', 361, 2, 23, 725019) When Alexander the Great invaded India, the people living in the region east of the river Sindhu, which is called the Indus by the English speaking Indians, were described as the Hindus.
('97', 361, 2, 24, 725206) The letter ‘S’ of the Sindhu became ‘H. in Greek.

('97', 364, 2, 3, 730392) Although there is from all sides so much debris of hope, now and then one sees a few rays of hope penetrating through this debris.
('97', 364, 2, 4, 730523) The reflection is due to a study of my correspondence file for the Harijan which has been carefully kept for reading during moments of leisure.
('97', 364, 2, 5, 730667) One such letter is from Shri Shivabhai Patel of Bochasan Residential School.
('97', 364, 2, 6, 730744) He has sent me a few unvarnished facts and figures of the work done during the annual celebrations.
('97', 364, 2, 7, 730844) He is ably assisted by Gangabehn 1 of the late Satyagraha Ashram of Sabarmati’ now known as the Harijan Ashram and the ever indefatigable Ravishankar Maharaj 2, with his two sons who have not deserted him.
('97', 364, 2, 8, 731050) A speciality of the recent celebration was that instead of the usual mechanical contrivance for carding, they resorted exclusively to the tunai process.
('97', 364, 2, 9, 731203) This time the management was induced to begin a boarding house for the children of those who, in that part of India, are considered to be a backward race.
('97', 364, 2, 10, 731358) The beginning has been made with only ten inmates.
('97', 364, 2, 11, 731409) After seven years of suspension, they have recommenced the day school for boys who have finished four years’ course in ordinary schools.
('97', 364, 2, 12, 731546) They expect to have a further six years, bringing the boys up to the matriculation standard minus English and plus a good grounding in khadi work, carpentry or agriculture.
('97', 364, 2, 13, 731719) Unlike past years, during the year under observation, the parents have become interested in the upright conduct of their children.
('97', 364, 2, 14, 731850) The result is that during the four months preceding the celebration of October last, the boys who were given to hard smoking and drinking strong tanning tea, have shed the habit which was ruining them.
('97', 364, 2, 15, 732052) The earnestness of the boys has affected their parents who have also given up these evil habits that make chimneys of their mouths and ruin their digestive apparatus.
('97', 364, 2, 16, 732219) When the boys were admitted, they could not sit still or hold their tongues for five minutes.
('97', 364, 2, 17, 732313) They have now learnt to enjoy hand spinning in perfect silence for one hour.
('97', 364, 2, 18, 732390) Gangabehn who is in complete charge of the dairy of the institution takes good care to provide pure cow’s milk.
('97', 364, 3, 19, 732502) 1 Gangabehn Vaidya 2 Ravishankar Vyas, who devoted his life to the uplift of the Baria tribe in Gujarat

('97', 365, 1, 3, 732761) They had also an unpretentious exhibition of all the processes that cotton undergoes before it comes out as khadi.
('97', 365, 1, 4, 732876) Twenty three students took part in a competition—for neat calligraphy, a subject about which there is so much indifference as if neatness of handwriting was no part of good training.

('97', 370, 7, 18, 744386) 332. DEATH—COURAGEOUS OR COWARDLY
('97', 370, 8, 19, 744420) A Bengali friend writes a long letter in Bengali on the exodus from East Pakistan.
('97', 370, 8, 20, 744503) Its purport is that though workers like him understand and appreciate my argument and distinction between death—courageous and cowardly—the common man detects in my statement a not too hidden advice in favour of migration.
('97', 370, 8, 21, 744726) He says: “If death is to be the lot in any case, courage becomes of no count; for man lives but to escape death.” This argument seems to beg the question.
('97', 370, 8, 22, 744881) Man does not live but to escape death.
('97', 370, 8, 23, 744920) If he does so, he is advised not to do so.
('97', 370, 8, 24, 744963) He is advised to learn to love death as well as life, if not more so.

('97', 373, 3, 5, 749043) ARNOLD HEIM,
('97', 373, 4, 6, 749056) I was delighted to receive your letter of 18th ultimo.
('97', 373, 4, 7, 749111) You unnecessarily fear that service for the good of humanity might, in my opinion, be less than prayer.
('97', 373, 4, 8, 749215) Laborare est prate, if that labour is in the service of humanity.
('97', 373, 4, 9, 749281) Though, therefore, there may be no fear of clash of ideals between us, I warn you against taking the trouble of coming to India for the mere satisfaction of meeting me.
('97', 373, 4, 10, 749450) Much as I should love to see you and to hear from you how you could exist in the Himalayas without alcohol and meat, I must not yield to the temptation.
('97', 373, 4, 11, 749603) Very often I have found the saying “Distance lends enchantment to the view” verified.
('97', 373, 4, 12, 749689) Moreover at the present moment, we in India have been overtaken by unexpected insanity, which has turned many of us into cut throats.
('97', 373, 4, 13, 749823) If, however, you feel that you must come to India even apart from your desire to see me, you would be most welcome.
('97', 373, 4, 14, 749939) I have shown your letter to my friend Prof.
('97', 373, 4, 15, 749983) Horace Alexander who may write to you.

('97', 389, 1, 2, 777908) 353. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 389, 2, 3, 777938) NEW DELHI, November 25, 1947 BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Today I want to tell you something about the refugees from Pakistan.
('97', 389, 2, 4, 778058) But the difficulty is whether they should be called refugees.
('97', 389, 2, 5, 778120) Some persons met me yesterday and asked me why I was referring to them as refugees.
('97', 389, 2, 6, 778204) In a way they are right because those who seek shelter are known as sharanarthi—refugees.
('97', 389, 2, 7, 778294) They said they had been driven here by their troubles, but why should they seek anybody’s protection here, especially since they have come to India and India belongs to everyone?
('97', 389, 2, 8, 778473) I think of Pakistan as also included in India.
('97', 389, 2, 9, 778520) But if it is not part of India today and India is divided into two parts, the Indian Union belongs and should belong to everybody.
('97', 389, 2, 10, 778651) So, when they come over here, they do so as a matter of right.
('97', 389, 2, 11, 778714) From this point of view those persons’ remark appeared right to me.
('97', 389, 2, 12, 778782) When a person is facing hardships in a place and escapes from that place and comes and takes shelter on the lap of his mother, shall we call him a refugee or a person who has come as a matter of right?
('97', 389, 2, 13, 778984) I told them that they must admit that I had no ill feeling in my heart which would make me use harsh words.
('97', 389, 2, 14, 779092) In fact, we have been such slaves of the English language that we cannot free ourselves from that slavish mentality.
('97', 389, 2, 15, 779209) Hence the word refugee, and it could mean only one thing, as popularized by the Press, namely, sharanarthi or nirashrit.
('97', 389, 2, 16, 779330) Then those people remarked that there were many other words in English.
('97', 389, 2, 17, 779402) Why should they not be called ‘sufferers’.
('97', 389, 2, 18, 779445) I know English sufficiently well.
('97', 389, 2, 19, 779479) So, how could I call them sufferers?
('97', 389, 2, 20, 779516) Then, what should I call them?
('97', 389, 2, 21, 779547) I thought they may be called dukhi because they are disconsolate.
('97', 389, 2, 22, 779613) But in a way, we are all full of sorrow in this life.
('97', 389, 2, 23, 779667) As a matter of fact those who have come here in millions leaving their homes and property are in great misery.
('97', 389, 2, 24, 779778) I would therefore like to talk about them today.
('97', 389, 2, 25, 779827) Three types of people came to see me today.
('97', 389, 2, 26, 779871) One type I would leave out altogether.
('97', 389, 2, 27, 779910) The person had a big joint family in Lahore.
('97', 389, 2, 28, 779955) He used to run some hotels, etc., and all his houses and property were left behind and he came here with his wife and children.
('97', 389, 2, 29, 780083) He did not bring all the family members here.
('97', 389, 2, 30, 780129) He narrated everything to me and requested me to find some accommodation for him.
('97', 389, 2, 31, 780211) I told him that I had no authority, and even if I had, I would not fix any
('97', 390, 0, 1, 780286) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 391
('97', 390, 1, 2, 780336) accommodation for him.

('97', 405, 0, 1, 814051) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 405, 1, 2, 814093) 365. NO COMPARISON POSSIBLE
('97', 405, 2, 3, 814121) A friend asked me the other day whether I shared the opinion often expressed that as between nationalism and religion, the former was superior to the latter.
('97', 405, 2, 4, 814279) I said that the two were dissimilars and that there could be no comparison between dissimilars.
('97', 405, 2, 5, 814375) Each was equal to the other in its own place.
('97', 405, 2, 6, 814421) No man who values his religion as also his nationalism can barter away the one for the other.
('97', 405, 2, 7, 814515) Both are equally dear to him.
('97', 405, 2, 8, 814545) He renders unto Caesar that which is Caesar’s and unto God that which is God’s.
('97', 405, 2, 9, 814625) And if Caesar, forgetting his limits, oversteps them, a man of God does not transfer his loyalty to another Caesar, but knows how to deal with the usurpation.
('97', 405, 2, 10, 814784) A rehearsal of this difficulty gave rise to satyagraha.
('97', 405, 2, 11, 814840) Take a homely illustration.
('97', 405, 2, 12, 814868) Suppose I have mother, wife and daughter.
('97', 405, 2, 13, 814910) All the three must be equally dear to me in their own places.
('97', 405, 2, 14, 814972) It is a vulgar error to think that a man is entitled to forsake his mother and his daughter for the sake of his wife.
('97', 405, 2, 15, 815090) He dare not do the converse.
('97', 405, 2, 16, 815119) And if any of the three oversteps her limits, the law of satyagraha comes to his assistance for the restoration of the equilibrium of the three forces.
('97', 405, 3, 17, 815271) NEW DELHI, November 28, 1947 Harijan, 7 12 1947

('97', 414, 1, 6, 834260) I would not give a single cowrie to the Government.
('97', 414, 1, 7, 834312) How could it demand money as a reward for such abominable deeds?
('97', 414, 1, 8, 834377) The Government should admit its mistake, make a solemn promise never to repeat it and return the girl along with a compensation.
('97', 414, 1, 9, 834506) We are not going to achieve anything if we ourselves do not become pure and brave.
('97', 414, 1, 10, 834589) I had discussed Kathiawar yesterday.
('97', 414, 1, 11, 834626) I told you whatever I had read in the Pakistani newspapers and subsequently heard from some Hindus.
('97', 414, 1, 12, 834726) But today I consulted the Sardar when he came to me.
('97', 414, 1, 13, 834779) I told him that when he went there he had made big speeches assuring that no one would touch a single Muslim boy or girl there, but then I heard that Muslims were being looted and beaten up, their property was burnt and their young girls kidnapped.
('97', 414, 1, 14, 835028) He said that as far as he was aware, certainly not a single Muslim was killed nor a single Muslim house looted or burnt.
('97', 414, 1, 15, 835149) All these things happened there in the chaos prevailing before he visited the place.
('97', 414, 1, 16, 835234) There were some cases of looting and probably one house was burnt.
('97', 414, 1, 17, 835301) But as for killing and abducting, these two things did not take place there even then.
('97', 414, 1, 18, 835388) An agent of the central Government or some Commissioner was always present there.
('97', 414, 1, 19, 835470) He had been ordered to see that such things were not allowed.
('97', 414, 1, 20, 835532) He had been instructed to have perfect bandobast so that nobody even touched any Muslim, let alone robbing or killing.
('97', 414, 1, 21, 835651) Subsequently, no such thing happened.
('97', 414, 1, 22, 835689) I asked the Sardar if I could mention the thing in the prayer meeting in the evening.
('97', 414, 1, 23, 835775) He said I could certainly do so.
('97', 414, 1, 24, 835808) He said that if something had happened there, he would have pursued the matter.
('97', 414, 1, 25, 835888) He also said that the Hindu Congressmen there at great risk to their lives saved the Muslims and their property.
('97', 414, 1, 26, 836001) No hooliganism could persist there.
('97', 414, 1, 27, 836037) The Sardar said that as long as he was there and was in charge of the Home Department, he would not allow such a thing to happen.
('97', 414, 1, 28, 836167) I was very happy to hear all that and asked his permission to refer to it in public.
('97', 414, 1, 29, 836252) He said that I could gladly do so and also mention his name.
('97', 414, 1, 30, 836313) I was so happy that yesterday I had talked about it and today itself I got this information.
('97', 414, 2, 31, 836406) [From Hindi] Prarthana Pravachan—II, pp.
('97', 415, 0, 1, 836447) 416 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 415, 1, 2, 836489) 373. LETTER TO YVONNE PRIVAT 1
('97', 415, 2, 3, 836520) BIRLA HOUSE, NEW DELHI, November 29, 1947
('97', 415, 3, 4, 836562) DEAR BHAKTI 2,
('97', 415, 4, 5, 836577) I was so glad to receive your argued letter of 27th August.
('97', 415, 4, 6, 836637) I see that you have grasped the fundamental difference between passive resistance and non violent resistance.
('97', 415, 4, 7, 836747) Resistance both forms are, but you have to pay a very heavy price when your resistance is passive, in the sense of the weakness of the resister.
('97', 415, 4, 8, 836892) Europe mistook the bold and brave resistance full of wisdom by Jesus of Nazareth for passive resistance, as if it was of the weak.
('97', 415, 4, 9, 837023) As I read the New Testament for the first time I detected no passivity, no weakness about Jesus as depicted in the four gospels and the meaning became clearer to me when I read Tolstoy’s Harmony of the Gospels and his other kindred writings.
('97', 415, 4, 10, 837265) Has not the West paid heavily in regarding Jesus as a passive resister?
('97', 415, 4, 11, 837337) Christendom has been responsible for the wars which put to shame even those described in the Old Testament and other records, historical or semi historical.
('97', 415, 4, 12, 837494) I know that I speak under correction for I can but claim very superficial knowledge of history— modern or ancient.
('97', 415, 4, 13, 837609) Coming to my own personal experience, whilst we undoubtedly got through passive resistance our political freedom, over which lovers of peace like you and your good husband 3 of the West are enthusiastic, we are daily paying the heavy price for the unconscious mistake we made or, better still, I made in mistaking passive resistance for non violent resistance.
('97', 415, 4, 14, 837970) Had I not made the mistake, we would have been spared the humiliating spectacle of a weak brother killing his weak brother thoughtlessly and inhumanly.
('97', 415, 4, 15, 838122) I am only hoping and praying and I want all the friends here and in other parts of the world to hope and pray with me that this blood bath will soon end and out of that, perhaps, inevitable butchery,
('97', 415, 5, 16, 838322) 1 Extracts from this and the addressee’s letter to Gandhiji appeared in Harijan, 7 12 1947, under the title “Do Not Lose Heart”.
('97', 415, 5, 17, 838451) 2 The name given by Gandhiji to the addressee 3 Edmond Privat, whom Gandhiji addressed as “Anand”
('97', 416, 0, 1, 838549) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 417
('97', 416, 1, 2, 838599) will rise a new and robust India—not warlike, basely imitating the West in all its hideousness, but a new India learning the best that the West has to give and becoming the hope not only of Asia and Africa, but of the whole of the aching world.
('97', 416, 1, 3, 838844) I must confess that this is hoping against hope, for we are today swearing by the military and all that naked physical force implies.
('97', 416, 1, 4, 838978) Our statesmen have for over two generations declaimed against the heavy expenditure on armaments under the British regime, but now that freedom from political serfdom has come, our military expenditure has increased and still threatens to increase and of this we are proud!
('97', 416, 1, 5, 839252) There is not a voice raised against it in our legislative chambers.
('97', 416, 1, 6, 839320) In spite, however, of the madness and the vain imitation of the tinsel of the West, the hope lingers in me and many others that India shall survive this death dance and occupy the moral height that should belong to her after the training, however imperfect, in non violence, for an unbroken period of 32 years since 1915. As to the last paragraph of your letter, I must confess my ignorance of psycho analysis.
('97', 416, 1, 7, 839731) Richard Gregg of U. S. A. has put the problem in a more concrete form than you have.
('97', 416, 1, 8, 839816) You must have seen his letter and my reply 1 in the columns of Harijan.
('97', 416, 1, 9, 839888) I hope this will find you both in the same vigour in which you used to be during those happy days that you passed with me in India.
('97', 416, 1, 10, 840020) I wonder if you will ever again come to India and see it, not in her madness, but wisdom, inspiring every department of life.
('97', 416, 1, 11, 840146) Love to you both.
('97', 416, 3, 12, 840164) MADAME EDMOND PRIVAT 1 AVENUE DE LA GARE NEUCHATEL, SWITZERLAND

('97', 418, 1, 2, 841634) 376. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 418, 2, 3, 841664) NEW DELHI, November 29, 1947
('97', 418, 3, 4, 841693) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 418, 4, 5, 841715) I told you yesterday that it was a day of momentous importance for the Sikhs.
('97', 418, 4, 6, 841793) It should hold the same importance for us too.
('97', 418, 4, 7, 841840) If they have truly started a new life and desire to follow the principles laid down by Guru Nanak for all of us, then Delhi should not be in the grip of the things that it is in at present.
('97', 418, 4, 8, 842030) I have read in the newspapers and also heard otherwise that a large number of people in Delhi are given to drinking.
('97', 418, 4, 9, 842147) We already know the things people can do under the influence of alcohol.
('97', 418, 4, 10, 842220) Now I am told that drinking has become a difficult problem and has spread over the entire city, so much so that it has become extremely difficult to control it.
('97', 418, 4, 11, 842381) If a new chapter has started from yesterday liquor consumption should become even less than before.
('97', 418, 4, 12, 842481) Alcohol can only make us mad.
('97', 418, 4, 13, 842511) Why then be a slave to it?
('97', 418, 4, 14, 842538) How can I tell you every thing?
('97', 418, 4, 15, 842570) All kinds of things are brought to my notice.
('97', 418, 4, 16, 842616) This is one thing.
('97', 418, 4, 17, 842635) As for the other, I am told that the mosques which we had damaged are still in that state, and the mosques which were turned into temples are closed since the police or the military guards them.
('97', 418, 4, 18, 842830) But even this hurts me.
('97', 418, 4, 19, 842854) For how can such a thing be allowed if we have opened a new chapter from yesterday?
('97', 418, 4, 20, 842938) The Sikhs could not have converted the mosques into temples.
('97', 418, 4, 21, 842999) The Sikhs are a great community, and, if they decide to remain pure from today and do only pure deeds I have no doubt that it is bound to influence the Hindus.
('97', 418, 4, 22, 843159) Then the Sikhs would become propagators of truth and justice.
('97', 418, 4, 23, 843221) This would become their profession, i.
('97', 418, 4, 24, 843260) e., to stand for peace and nothing but peace everywhere.
('97', 418, 4, 25, 843317) If this happens, the very face of the country would change.
('97', 418, 4, 26, 843377) Hence, those who have converted the mosques into temples should promptly remove the idols from there, and restore the mosques.
('97', 418, 4, 27, 843504) In that event, what need would there be for the police or the military guarding those places?
('97', 418, 4, 28, 843598) When all people become good, there need be no police.
('97', 418, 4, 29, 843652) The third thing is that a large number of our girls have been carried away to Pakistan.
('97', 418, 4, 30, 843740) We do not know where they have been
('97', 419, 0, 1, 843776) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 419, 1, 2, 843818) I had said yesterday that we should not give even a cowrie to get back the abducted girls.
('97', 419, 1, 3, 843909) Those who have committed the crime of abducting our girls should restore them to us, and also do penance at the same time.
('97', 419, 1, 4, 844032) It would not do to give any money to claim the girls back.
('97', 419, 1, 5, 844091) But there is a very alarming report.
('97', 419, 1, 6, 844128) It is reported that in the East Punjab we are ill treating the Muslim girls, whom we have forcibly kept.
('97', 419, 1, 7, 844233) I just cannot understand how we could have stooped so low.
('97', 419, 1, 8, 844292) I must admit that I cannot bear to see this.
('97', 419, 1, 9, 844337) We should regard those girls as our mothers or daughters.
('97', 419, 1, 10, 844395) Those Muslim girls are like my own daughters.
('97', 419, 1, 11, 844441) How can I indulge in pleasures, be alive and eat and drink while somebody ill treats my daughters?
('97', 419, 1, 12, 844540) I have a feeling that there is some exaggeration in this report.
('97', 419, 1, 13, 844605) But on that ground it should not be disregarded.
('97', 419, 1, 14, 844654) And, if there is some exaggeration it is only for good, because it would then make us think how low a man could stoop.
('97', 419, 1, 15, 844773) This is something which we would shudder to think.
('97', 419, 1, 16, 844824) We have opened a new chapter from yesterday, for, if the Sikhs have done so, the Hindus and the Muslims have done it too.
('97', 419, 1, 17, 844946) Let us forget about the Muslims as we have made them helpless in the Indian Union.
('97', 419, 1, 18, 845029) But the Hindus and the Sikhs are not helpless.
('97', 419, 1, 19, 845076) And so, they must think what they should do.
('97', 419, 1, 20, 845121) True, we are not indulging in such acts here.
('97', 419, 1, 21, 845167) But when someone commits a crime anywhere I feel I am the culprit.
('97', 419, 1, 22, 845234) You too should feel the same.
('97', 419, 1, 23, 845264) If I were to commit any crime you should also think that you too were guilty of it.
('97', 419, 1, 24, 845348) Let us all merge in each other like drops of ocean.
('97', 419, 1, 25, 845400) If the drops of ocean remain apart they would dry up.
('97', 419, 1, 26, 845454) But when they mingle together in the ocean they can carry huge ships across their expanse.
('97', 419, 1, 27, 845545) As with the ocean so with us.
('97', 419, 1, 28, 845575) After all we also are an ocean of human beings.
('97', 419, 1, 29, 845623) If one person commits a crime, it amounts to all of us committing it.
('97', 419, 1, 30, 845693) Then it ceases to be a crime.
('97', 419, 1, 31, 845723) We must all become alert.
('97', 419, 1, 32, 845749) That is why I talked about these things.
('97', 419, 1, 33, 845790) But now I would like to come to the subject of controls.
('97', 419, 1, 34, 845847) Control on sugar has been removed.
('97', 419, 1, 35, 845882) I hope and wish that controls on cloth and food would also be removed.
('97', 419, 1, 36, 845953) But how would those controls go and what would be our duty after that?
('97', 419, 1, 37, 846024) Since control on sugar has been removed, I would first talk about it.
('97', 419, 1, 38, 846094) Now there are big sugar factories.
('97', 419, 1, 39, 846129) But the owners of the factories should not consider themselves free to squeeze as much money from the people as they fancy.
('97', 419, 1, 40, 846253) If they raise the price of sugar, people would be reduced to poverty.
('97', 419, 1, 41, 846323) Fortunately the entire population of India does
('97', 420, 0, 1, 846371) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 421
('97', 420, 1, 2, 846421) not consume sugar.
('97', 420, 1, 3, 846440) People should consume gur 1 for there is no control on it.
('97', 420, 1, 4, 846499) The villagers can easily make gur in their own homes, but they cannot make sugar.
('97', 420, 1, 5, 846581) There are huge factories in India where millionaires employ workers to produce sugar.
('97', 420, 1, 6, 846667) But gur can be produced wherever sugar cane is grown.
('97', 420, 1, 7, 846721) Moreover, gur is a very healthy thing to eat if it is clean.
('97', 420, 1, 8, 846782) When I was a child my father used to take me or I used to go with his attendants to the villages where sugar cane was grown.
('97', 420, 1, 9, 846907) People of those villages used to give us fresh and clean gur to eat.
('97', 420, 1, 10, 846976) Gur is a sort of food which sugar can never be.
('97', 420, 1, 11, 847024) So, the poor people should only eat gur.
('97', 420, 1, 12, 847065) But today, some of them have started taking tea and in their tea they put sugar rather than gur.
('97', 420, 1, 13, 847162) I would like to tell them that they should put gur in their tea; but would they listen to met?
('97', 420, 1, 14, 847257) And when the price of sugar goes up, they think it would be better to have control on sugar so that they could have it cheaper.
('97', 420, 1, 15, 847385) Under these circumstances, it is the supreme duty of the sugar merchants and factory owners to have a mutual arrangement so that the entire country knows that with the freedom we have won we would earn only clean money.
('97', 420, 1, 16, 847605) We would not cheat or deceive people and would root out all unclean and corrupt practices.
('97', 420, 1, 17, 847696) If that does not happen, I would be blamed because I have worked quite a bit for the removal of controls, and am still working for it.
('97', 420, 1, 18, 847831) If the sugar merchants and factory owners increase their margin of profit, the price of sugar is bound to rise.
('97', 420, 1, 19, 847943) If they take five per cent profit, it can be called honest earning.
('97', 420, 1, 20, 848011) But it cannot be called honest earning if they pocket 10 or 20 per cent profit.
('97', 420, 1, 21, 848091) Five per cent is more than sufficient and they should not take more than that.
('97', 420, 1, 22, 848170) And, then, other controls would automatically go.
('97', 420, 1, 23, 848220) Let not the Government get a chance to say that controls were removed because we wanted them to be removed and ask how the poor are now going to survive when they do not get sugar at all.
('97', 420, 1, 24, 848408) That should not be the case.
('97', 420, 1, 25, 848437) The factory owners should become honest and form a committee to fix a uniform price of sugar.
('97', 420, 1, 26, 848531) No factory owner should charge more than that price.
('97', 420, 1, 27, 848584) At the same time, the farmers who grow sugar cane should not get less than their due.
('97', 420, 1, 28, 848670) If the price rises because the cultivators are given more, then it becomes a matter of honest earning.
('97', 420, 1, 29, 848773) They should maintain proper accounts and make a public announcement of what they pay to the farmers now as against what they were paid earlier, that the amount goes straight into the pockets of the cultivators and no middleman could
('97', 420, 2, 30, 849006) 1 Jaggery
('97', 421, 0, 1, 849016) 422 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 421, 1, 2, 849058) swallow it and that as against the ten or twenty per cent they used to take, they are not taking even five and a quarter per cent now.
('97', 421, 1, 3, 849193) Supposing the factory owners do not take more than five per cent but if the middlemen charge higher prices, consumers of sugar will be really doomed.
('97', 421, 1, 4, 849343) In that case, the factory owners should sell sugar directly to the consumers.
('97', 421, 1, 5, 849421) I have no doubt that things would run smoothly under such an arrangement.
('97', 421, 1, 6, 849495) A gentleman writes to say that the train fares for third class travellers have been increased, though the increase is less compared to that of the first and second classes, but he asks, and rightly, why the third class fares had to be raised even by this much.
('97', 421, 1, 7, 849756) Granted that our aims of progress are high and we require more funds to achieve them.
('97', 421, 1, 8, 849842) Then, if need be, we can increase the levy on tobacco and many other imported as well as indigenously produced non essential items.
('97', 421, 1, 9, 849974) It may serve our purpose to some extent.
('97', 421, 1, 10, 850015) The men in power in the Government ought to consider and examine the feasibility of this proposition.
('97', 421, 1, 11, 850117) But the point certainly needs to be understood, and the Government should also know that I have got people who give such useful suggestions.
('97', 421, 1, 12, 850258) They are not unintelligent people.
('97', 421, 1, 13, 850293) Rather, they are very sensible.
('97', 421, 1, 14, 850325) If today we have millions of rupees with us, it does not mean that we should squander away everything.
('97', 421, 1, 15, 850428) We should spend even small amounts, out of those millions, after careful consideration.
('97', 421, 1, 16, 850516) And it is enough for me if these small amounts thus spent benefit the poor villagers of India.
('97', 421, 1, 17, 850611) Out of the crores of rupees drawn from our villages, how much are we able to return to them?
('97', 421, 1, 18, 850704) A true Panchayati Raj or democracy has got to draw its resources from the people but, in return, they should benefit the people tenfold.
('97', 421, 1, 19, 850841) For instance, if I take money from the people for education, I should give such education to their children and have such an estimate of expenditure that they should get back their money tenfold.
('97', 421, 1, 20, 851037) For example, if I start sanitation work in the villages and build roads for the village people, they would know that the money they give is being used for their own benefit.
('97', 421, 1, 21, 851211) As a result, we would not be as crazy about our military as we are now.
('97', 421, 1, 22, 851283) Then we would decide to spend as little as possible on the army and as much as possible on the general public.
('97', 421, 1, 23, 851394) In such a situation, people themselves become the army and start acquiring knowledge of military affairs.
('97', 421, 1, 24, 851500) When they are thus able to defend themselves and their neighbours, the defence of India is automatically ensured.
('97', 421, 1, 25, 851614) As it is no one can have designs on India.
('97', 422, 0, 1, 851657) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 423
('97', 422, 1, 2, 851707) But right now, even though the British have gone, the atmosphere of the British rule has not yet gone.
('97', 422, 1, 3, 851810) Let us change that atmosphere.
('97', 422, 1, 4, 851841) The British used to spend extravagantly and the people did not get any return from such expenditure.
('97', 422, 1, 5, 851942) But now the people should get back everything they give.
('97', 422, 1, 6, 851999) Then it would be well for the country.
('97', 422, 1, 7, 852038) This is all I would like to say today.

('97', 422, 4, 10, 852118) 377. ITS WISE USE
('97', 422, 5, 11, 852136) This letter 1 is from a correspondent who knows everything about this tragedy.
('97', 422, 5, 12, 852215) I have not the least doubt that this tragedy can be turned to good account by the correct behaviour of the sufferers, as also that of the people amongst whom their lot is cast for the time being.
('97', 422, 5, 13, 852411) In this consummation, I have no doubt that all specially qualified men and women such as doctors, lawyers, vaids, hakims, nurses, traders and bankers should make common cause with the others and lead a co ordinated camp life in perfect co operation, feeling not like helpless dependents on charity, but resourceful, independent men and women making light of their sufferings and looking forward to a life enriched by their sufferings, a life full of promise for the future and worthy of imitation by the people amongst whom the camp life is lived.
('97', 422, 5, 14, 852959) Then when the professional people have been inured to corporate unselfish life and when they can be spared from these camps, they would branch out into villages or otherwise, shedding the fragrance of their presence wherever they may happen to be.
('97', 422, 6, 15, 853207) NEW DELHI, November 30, 1947 Harijan, 7 12 1947

('97', 422, 7, 17, 853292) The correspondent, a refugee belonging to the medical profession, had suggested that “all members of the medical and teaching professions” should be absorbed in Government service to help the Provincial Governments “to carry out their rural uplift programmes”.

('97', 423, 10, 15, 854100) SATISH 3,

('97', 426, 3, 6, 858706) 383. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 426, 4, 7, 858736) November 30, 1947
('97', 426, 5, 8, 858754) BROTHERS AND SISTERS, Yesterday I wanted to mention one point; but since I had to talk about many other things, it was left out.
('97', 426, 5, 9, 858883) You must have seen that the girls sit on the floor and they feel cold.
('97', 426, 5, 10, 858954) I had told them that we have plenty of papers and newspapers which we have read already and these could be used for sitting on.
('97', 426, 5, 11, 859082) But it is good that a friend has spread a sheet today.
('97', 426, 5, 12, 859137) In a way it is good to be unconcerned.
('97', 426, 5, 13, 859176) Why should we be so delicate that we feel cold by sitting on the floor?
('97', 426, 5, 14, 859248) Even if we have to sit on grass, if we can have a piece of paper and if it does not get wet, then we would not feel cold.
('97', 426, 5, 15, 859370) If this does not serve the purpose, then we have our age old custom of carrying our own asana 1
('97', 426, 6, 16, 859466) wherever we go and spreading it whenever we have to sit.
('97', 426, 6, 17, 859523) Today we have forgotten that practice and given ourselves to comfortable living.
('97', 426, 6, 18, 859604) I suggest that we should forget about a piece of paper or newspaper, take one if you want and if it is thick, but the best thing would be an asana of wool or jute or even cloth or hay.
('97', 426, 6, 19, 859789) All you have to do is to spread it wherever you want to sit and tuck it under your arm when you have to go.
('97', 426, 6, 20, 859897) Since I am feeling cold, everybody must be feeling the same.
('97', 426, 6, 21, 859958) Moreover, doctors also say that we should not sit on wet ground or where it is cold.
('97', 426, 6, 22, 860043) If men wearing dhotis and women wearing salwars or skirts use thick cloth as undergarments, they can serve as asans.
('97', 426, 6, 23, 860160) But the women too have become very delicate and so their clothes must be soft.
('97', 426, 6, 24, 860239) How can they wear thick clothes?
('97', 426, 6, 25, 860272) Their undergarments have to be soft.
('97', 426, 6, 26, 860309) Hence, they cannot protect them against this cold.
('97', 426, 6, 27, 860360) I have received many telegrams from Kathiawar.
('97', 426, 6, 28, 860407) I have already told you 2 about what I heard and what subsequently appeared in the Pakistani newspapers.
('97', 426, 6, 29, 860512) Those papers are read by thousands of people
('97', 426, 7, 30, 860557) 1 A small mat 2 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 27 11 1947 and “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 28 11 1947.

('97', 427, 1, 2, 860703) May be some ten thousand or so.
('97', 427, 1, 3, 860735) I do not know how many people must be reading them.
('97', 427, 1, 4, 860787) But nothing would be achieved if I started thinking whether those things had really happened.
('97', 427, 1, 5, 860881) Hence it was good that I placed before you what I had read in those newspapers.

('97', 427, 1, 15, 861519) After all, I know the Muslims of Kathiawar.

('97', 427, 1, 17, 861683) After all, I was born there and lived there for almost 17 years.

('97', 427, 1, 19, 861833) My father never sent me anywhere.

('97', 427, 1, 21, 861962) Even for the examination I could not go beyond Ahmedabad.

('97', 427, 1, 25, 862271) He says it is true that some Hindus in Kathiawar had lost their balance, but is there any place where this has not happened.
('97', 427, 1, 26, 862396) They resorted to violence and even harmed some Muslims.
('97', 427, 1, 27, 862452) They destroyed their houses and even burnt them down.

('97', 435, 0, 1, 876773) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 435, 1, 2, 876815) have repeated those allegations with the conditional ‘if ’ no harm has been done to truth.
('97', 435, 1, 3, 876906) The Congress and the administrators of Kathiawar will gain to the extant that they take their stand on truth.
('97', 435, 1, 4, 877016) Friends assert that though truth comes out in the end the harm is already done, for people who have no scruples about truth or falsehood dishonestly use my statements for their own purposes.
('97', 435, 1, 5, 877207) I should therefore guard myself against untruth being propagated.
('97', 435, 1, 6, 877273) But whenever people have resorted to such tactics they have failed and they were exposed as dishonest and false.
('97', 435, 1, 7, 877386) If I mention the allegations subject to ‘if ’s it should not perturb anyone.
('97', 435, 1, 8, 877463) The only thing required is that those against whom the allegations are levelled should be wholly innocent.
('97', 435, 1, 9, 877570) Let us consider the other side of the matter.
('97', 435, 1, 10, 877616) Take Kathiawar again for example.
('97', 435, 1, 11, 877650) If I had not paid attention to the allegations contained in some major newspapers of Pakistan which even the Prime Minister of Pakistan had declared were true in substance, the Muslims would have taken them as gospel truth.
('97', 435, 1, 12, 877874) But now the Muslims have come to doubt their veracity.
('97', 435, 1, 13, 877929) I would like friends in Kathiawar and elsewhere to learn from this the lesson that we will not let any trouble occur in our own house; we will welcome criticism even if that criticism should be bitter; we will become truthful and we will rectify any error we discover in ourselves.
('97', 435, 1, 14, 878211) We must not delude ourselves with the belief that we can never make a mistake.
('97', 435, 1, 15, 878290) Our bitterest critic is one who has some grudge, fancied or real, against us.
('97', 435, 1, 16, 878368) We shall correct him if we are patient with him and, whenever the occasion arises, show him his error, or correct our own when we are found to be in error.
('97', 435, 1, 17, 878524) By doing so we shall never go wrong.
('97', 435, 1, 18, 878561) No doubt a balance must be preserved.
('97', 435, 1, 19, 878599) Discrimination is always required.
('97', 435, 1, 20, 878634) One must never take notice of statements of a mischievous nature.
('97', 435, 1, 21, 878700) I feel that after long experience I have learnt the art of discrimination.
('97', 435, 1, 22, 878775) Today the atmosphere is poisoned.
('97', 435, 1, 23, 878809) Allegations are being hurled at each other by parties.
('97', 435, 1, 24, 878864) To imagine in such a situation that we can make no mistakes would be folly.
('97', 435, 1, 25, 878940) We have not the good fortune today to be able to make such a claim.
('97', 435, 1, 26, 879008) It will be enough if with necessary effort we succeed in eradicating the mischief and root it out.
('97', 435, 1, 27, 879107) We can do so only if our eyes and ears are open to see and hear about our own shortcomings.
('97', 435, 1, 28, 879199) Nature has so made us that we cannot see our own shortcomings.
('97', 435, 1, 29, 879262) We can see only those of others.
('97', 435, 1, 30, 879295) Wisdom requires that
('97', 436, 0, 1, 879316) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 437
('97', 436, 1, 2, 879366) we should benefit from others seeing our shortcomings.
('97', 436, 1, 3, 879421) Yesterday, I was not able to deal fully with the long telegram from Junagadh, which I had received as I was about to leave for the prayer meeting, for I had only cursorily glanced through it.
('97', 436, 1, 4, 879613) Today I have studied it fully.
('97', 436, 1, 5, 879644) Those who had sent the wire state that the allegations to which had referred the other day were founded in truth.
('97', 436, 1, 6, 879758) If this is so it is very bad for Kathiawar.
('97', 436, 1, 7, 879802) If attempts have been made to exaggerate the allegations that our workers have admitted as true and which I have published, then those behind this wire have done harm to Pakistan.
('97', 436, 1, 8, 879982) They invite me to go to Kathiawar and see things for myself.
('97', 436, 1, 9, 880043) They ought to know that today I am not in a position to do that.

('97', 436, 1, 13, 880393) They know, as everyone knows, that newspaper propaganda especially when it is not wholly based on truth can protect neither life nor property nor honour.
('97', 436, 1, 14, 880547) To protect all these three things those sending the wire should adhere to truth and they should go and meet their Hindu friends.
('97', 436, 1, 15, 880676) They know their friends amongst Hindus.
('97', 436, 1, 16, 880716) They know also that though I am at some distance away from Kathiawar I am doing their work even from here.
('97', 436, 1, 17, 880823) I have said this after full deliberation and now I am collecting all the facts.
('97', 436, 1, 18, 880903) I have seen Sardar Patel.
('97', 436, 1, 19, 880929) He says that to the extent that it lies within his power no communal riot will be permitted and anyone misbehaving with our Muslim brothers and sisters will be severely punished.
('97', 436, 1, 20, 881108) The Kathiawar workers, who are quite impartial, are trying to find out the truth for themselves and trying to alleviate the sufferings of the Kathiawar Muslims.
('97', 436, 1, 21, 881269) They love Muslims as much as they love their own selves.
('97', 436, 1, 22, 881326) Will the Muslims help them?

('97', 441, 2, 3, 886912) PANIPAT, December 2, 1947
('97', 441, 3, 4, 886938) You want to go to Pakistan of your own free will, don’t you?
('97', 441, 3, 5, 886999) When your leaders came to me and pleaded that I should visit Panipat, they told me that people were leaving for Pakistan against their will.

('97', 443, 4, 12, 891838) 400. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING 1
('97', 443, 5, 13, 891870) PANIPAT, December 2, 1947
('97', 443, 6, 14, 891896) Gandhiji told a mass meeting mostly of refugees from West Punjab that he was not very happy on his second visit to Panipat.
('97', 443, 6, 15, 892020) During his last visit 2 he was assured by the non Muslims of the locality that they would not let the Muslims go from Panipat.
('97', 443, 6, 16, 892147) He was hurt to hear from Mr. Gopalaswami Ayyangar 3 that arrangements were now complete for sending the Muslims to Pakistan.
('97', 443, 6, 17, 892272) He hoped that he would hear about the Hindus persuading the Muslims not to go to Pakistan.
('97', 443, 6, 18, 892363) Why did the Muslims of Panipat, who were previously not eager to go to Pakistan, now want to leave?
('97', 443, 6, 19, 892463) All the Muslims in the camp here want to go.
('97', 443, 6, 20, 892508) I told them that they would get all the protection here.
('97', 443, 6, 21, 892565) But one should depend on God’s protection rather than on the protection of the army and the police.
('97', 443, 6, 22, 892665) Supposing you are eating and death comes while food is in your mouth, no army or police, no doctors or drugs, will be of any use.
('97', 443, 6, 23, 892795) If we could only stop to think how God holds in his own hand the string of death, the prevailing conflict between trust and distrust would end.
('97', 443, 6, 24, 892939) If my brother has become mad and wants to kill me, does it mean

('97', 464, 1, 29, 939703) Not that we have learnt the lesson of non violence fully.
('97', 464, 1, 30, 939761) We are weak.
('97', 464, 1, 31, 939774) We took to non violence because we had not the weapons for a violent fight.
('97', 464, 1, 32, 939850) Non violence is the best weapon.
('97', 464, 1, 33, 939883) Only the pure of heart can use it.
('97', 464, 1, 34, 939918) I therefore told the Burmese Prime Minister that if he wished to take anything from India it should be this non violence.
('97', 464, 1, 35, 940040) He must not think that if India lapsed into barbarity, how could Burma which took its religion from India advance?
('97', 464, 1, 36, 940155) I told him that if he wanted to copy India he must copy the good qualities that India once had and still retained.
('97', 464, 1, 37, 940270) He must not take anything barbarous.
('97', 464, 1, 38, 940307) We must export only what is good so that the world may learn from us.
('97', 464, 1, 39, 940377) Had India not attained its freedom, Burma and Ceylon also would not have attained theirs.
('97', 464, 1, 40, 940467) And India did not become free by resorting to the sword.
('97', 464, 1, 41, 940524) And if we did not need the sword for securing freedom, we will not need it
('97', 465, 0, 1, 940599) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 465, 1, 2, 940641) for sustaining it.
('97', 465, 1, 3, 940660) If we cannot keep our freedom without the sword, then I shall think that India has done nothing for the world.
('97', 465, 1, 4, 940771) Today we have an army.Attempts are being made to strengthen it.
('97', 465, 1, 5, 940835) Attempts are also being made to further enlarge the Navy and the Air Force.
('97', 465, 1, 6, 940911) I declare that in this way we are not really strengthening ourselves.
('97', 465, 1, 7, 940981) We shall be doing no good to the world in this way.
('97', 465, 1, 8, 941033) And if the world learns this kind of thing from us it is not going to gain anything, rather it will be doomed.

('97', 466, 7, 18, 942694) 415. TALK WITH GHANSHYAMSINGH GUPTA
('97', 466, 8, 19, 942730) NEW DELHI, December 5, 1947
('97', 466, 9, 20, 942758) Now that the English have left the country the national language for inter provincial communication can only be Hindustani.
('97', 466, 9, 21, 942882) I have great respect for the English language.
('97', 466, 9, 22, 942929) But it can never be the national language of India.
('97', 466, 9, 23, 942981) We do not persevere in learning our two ancient scripts, which only means that we do not have enough patriotism.

('97', 467, 1, 2, 943461) 416. SPEECH AT PRAYER MEETING
('97', 467, 2, 3, 943491) NEW DELHI, December 5, 1947
('97', 467, 3, 4, 943519) BROTHERS AND SISTERS,
('97', 467, 4, 5, 943541) The letters given to me here are sometimes too long.
('97', 467, 4, 6, 943594) You cannot expect me to go through them and answer them, because it takes time even to read them.
('97', 467, 4, 7, 943692) I cannot read them here for it would be wasting my time and yours.
('97', 467, 4, 8, 943759) I have a note which mentions my meeting Liaquat Ali Khan.
('97', 467, 4, 9, 943817) The writer asks if I am still not satisfied that nothing untoward has happened in Kathiawar.
('97', 467, 4, 10, 943910) If the writer of the note is present I may tell him that nothing has happened in Kathiawar.
('97', 467, 4, 11, 944002) Shamaldas Gandhi says that nothing has happened to justify the reports that I have received.
('97', 467, 4, 12, 944095) There had been incidents but minor ones.
('97', 467, 4, 13, 944136) They were given publicity by the Pakistan newspapers and telegrams were dispatched.
('97', 467, 4, 14, 944220) The reports were terrible but such terrible things did not happen.
('97', 467, 4, 15, 944287) Today I have another wire from Shamaldas.
('97', 467, 4, 16, 944329) He says he has made investigations and found that such things had not taken place.
('97', 467, 4, 17, 944412) Certainly after the Sardar’s visit to Kathiawar nothing untoward has happened.
('97', 467, 4, 18, 944491) The reports I had earlier received appeared to suggest it was the Sardar who incited the people to rowdyism.
('97', 467, 4, 19, 944600) But after he went to Kathiawar no incidents took place.
('97', 467, 4, 20, 944656) This changes the complexion of things.
('97', 467, 4, 21, 944695) Shamaldas Gandhi says that he will tell Muslims not to send such telegrams.
('97', 467, 4, 22, 944771) I have received further telegrams from the very Muslims who had earlier made the allegations, admitting that they were exaggerated and that they had made a mistake.
('97', 467, 4, 23, 944936) They have also written to say that the reports carried by the Pakistan newspapers were incorrect, that the extent of the damage reported was also wrong and it could not be said that the Muslims were scared and nervous.
('97', 467, 4, 24, 945155) I am happy to hear it.
('97', 467, 4, 25, 945178) I have said that I shall do whatever I can for our Muslim brethren.
('97', 467, 4, 26, 945246) We must never kick one who is already down.
('97', 467, 4, 27, 945290) We must raise him up.
('97', 467, 4, 28, 945312) This is the demand of humanity, of love, this is civilized behaviour.
('97', 467, 4, 29, 945382) I shall never throw anyone down even if he be my enemy—though of course I have no enemy.
('97', 467, 4, 30, 945471) It was a mere dream that the Muslims would get everything once Pakistan came into being.
('97', 467, 4, 31, 945560) After all it is not as if only those who are in Pakistan would be left alive and those outside Pakistan would be killed.
('97', 467, 4, 32, 945681) Pakistan is a veritable
('97', 468, 0, 1, 945705) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 469
('97', 468, 1, 2, 945755) sea of Hindus and Muslims.
('97', 468, 1, 3, 945782) Will they drive out all the Hindus and Sikhs from there?
('97', 468, 1, 4, 945839) Those that have come out did not really want to leave their homes.
('97', 468, 1, 5, 945906) But it has happened.
('97', 468, 1, 6, 945927) I have received letters from Sikhs saying that they will know no rest till they are able to go back.
('97', 468, 1, 7, 946028) For instance a person may have a thousand acre farm near Lyallpur where he had been growing wheat, bananas, cotton and fruits.
('97', 468, 1, 8, 946155) How can he leave it for good?
('97', 468, 1, 9, 946185) He will not rest till he can go back.
('97', 468, 1, 10, 946223) And what happened in India?
('97', 468, 1, 11, 946251) The displaced Sikhs were furious and wanted revenge.
('97', 468, 1, 12, 946304) I said it was not humanity.
('97', 468, 1, 13, 946332) It was barbarism.
('97', 468, 1, 14, 946350) They should not indulge in it, that good should be returned for evil.
('97', 468, 1, 15, 946420) We must not copy the wrong doer, we must emulate the man who does good.
('97', 468, 1, 16, 946492) It, therefore, gave me satisfaction when I received that wire from Kathiawar.
('97', 468, 1, 17, 946570) I shall tell my Muslim brethren: if something had happened they should have toned it down to a half or even a quarter; they should not have exaggerated it and given it publicity in foreign countries.
('97', 468, 1, 18, 946770) After all if Hindus and Sikhs—though there are no Sikhs there—go wild, can the world save the Muslims?
('97', 468, 1, 19, 946873) Yes, they can say that we have not made the right use of our freedom.
('97', 468, 1, 20, 946943) They can threaten to take it away.
('97', 468, 1, 21, 946978) All that is possible.
('97', 468, 1, 22, 947000) But the dead will not return to life thereby.
('97', 468, 1, 23, 947046) We should therefore never exaggerate.
('97', 468, 1, 24, 947084) Our agony is our own and no outsider can take it on himself.
('97', 468, 1, 25, 947145) We should try to make light of it.
('97', 468, 1, 26, 947180) We impress the world only when we exaggerate the good work done by another, not his folly.
('97', 468, 2, 27, 947271) There is another thing I must tell you.
('97', 468, 2, 28, 947311) It does not concern you but I can convey it through you.
('97', 468, 2, 29, 947368) I have told Brijkrishna not to give anyone any appointment to see me from the 6th to the 13th.
('97', 468, 2, 30, 947463) That I do not want to see people does not mean that I am ill or that I want to enjoy myself.
('97', 468, 2, 31, 947556) For many months now this matter has been under consideration.
('97', 468, 2, 32, 947618) I cannot go to Sevagram.
('97', 468, 2, 33, 947643) So people from Sevagram are coming here.
('97', 468, 2, 34, 947684) The Kasturba Trust will be sitting from tomorrow.
('97', 468, 2, 35, 947734) Then there will be meetings of the Spinners’ Association, Nayee Talim, and Village Industries Association.
('97', 468, 2, 36, 947841) The four associations are going to meet during this time.
('97', 468, 2, 37, 947899) If they are properly conducted they will certainly consume some time.
('97', 468, 2, 38, 947969) How am I to give my time to these meetings and to visitors?
('97', 468, 2, 39, 948029) I have therefore requested people not to try to see me during this time.
('97', 468, 2, 40, 948102) Not that I shall not be doing my own work.
('97', 468, 2, 41, 948145) But people coming from outside want to see me out of curiosity.
('97', 468, 3, 42, 948209) As I have already said there have been talks going on about lifting the control on cloth, also on food.
('97', 468, 3, 43, 948313) Not that it is going to
('97', 469, 0, 1, 948337) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 469, 1, 2, 948379) happen tomorrow, but a process has started and everybody says I have done a good thing by suggesting it.
('97', 469, 1, 3, 948484) I have received letters from all quarters saying that it would be good if the controls were lifted.
('97', 469, 1, 4, 948584) Of course if the controls are lifted it will not mean that we shall be relieved of our obligations.
('97', 469, 1, 5, 948684) Once decontrol comes into effect certain obligations devolve on the traders.
('97', 469, 1, 6, 948761) I must tell Ghanshyamdas also to produce more cloth.
('97', 469, 1, 7, 948814) He may say that he only carries out orders.
('97', 469, 1, 8, 948858) He produces what cloth he is asked to produce and he takes the price.
('97', 469, 1, 9, 948928) But once the cloth is decontrolled, what will Ghanshyamdas and other friends do?
('97', 469, 1, 10, 949009) Does it mean they will be free to loot the people?
('97', 469, 1, 11, 949060) In that case I shall be having a very bad time.
('97', 469, 1, 12, 949108) People will hold me responsible for it.
('97', 469, 1, 13, 949148) I am a servant of India irrespective of my status.
('97', 469, 1, 14, 949199) If what I say does not appeal to the Government, that is, to those running the Government, it will have no effect however much I may shout.
('97', 469, 1, 15, 949339) I am not God so that whatever I may say will prevail.
('97', 469, 1, 16, 949393) I discuss and decide and then say that the control on cloth and other articles should be lifted.
('97', 469, 1, 17, 949490) It means that if five maunds of foodgrain is available today, we shall have ten maunds tomorrow because I feel that some of it has been hoarded.
('97', 469, 1, 18, 949635) But if the peasants do not have any foodgrain and I say that the control should be lifted, will the people not then starve?
('97', 469, 1, 19, 949759) I am not a fool who will let the people starve.
('97', 469, 1, 20, 949807) I myself do not starve because Ghanshyamdas makes available to me goat’s milk and fruit and vegetables.
('97', 469, 1, 21, 949911) I believe that the farmers have enough foodgrain but that the price offered is so low that they cannot even feed themselves on it.
('97', 469, 1, 22, 950042) They part with whatever the Government forces out of them.
('97', 469, 1, 23, 950101) For the rest they say they will declare their stocks after the control is lifted.
('97', 469, 1, 24, 950183) I feel that if the farmers can clear their stocks at a good price they will not starve.
('97', 469, 1, 25, 950271) Admitting that we do not have as much foodgrain as we need, does it mean that a person should eat all that he can lay his hands on, while his neighbours starve?
('97', 469, 1, 26, 950432) If we have sunk so low, then there is no cure.
('97', 469, 1, 27, 950479) Control certainly is not the cure.
('97', 469, 1, 28, 950514) If that happens the Government which is run by our Ministers must abdicate.
('97', 469, 1, 29, 950590) People indulge in deceit.
('97', 469, 1, 30, 950616) They are not truthful.
('97', 469, 1, 31, 950639) The traders who should carry on trade for the benefit of the people are interested in filling their own coffers and in amassing wealth for their sons and daughters.
('97', 469, 1, 32, 950804) What should the Government do?
('97', 469, 1, 33, 950835) Should it use force or should it shoot people down?
('97', 469, 1, 34, 950887) We do not have such power nor do we want such power.
('97', 470, 0, 1, 950940) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 471
('97', 470, 1, 2, 950990) We may have a police force but not for shooting down people.
('97', 470, 1, 3, 951051) If we start shooting down people who will be left alive?
('97', 470, 1, 4, 951108) Where is our thirty year old training?
('97', 470, 1, 5, 951147) Where is our humanity?
('97', 470, 1, 6, 951170) This cannot go on.
('97', 470, 1, 7, 951189) In this way we shall only lose our newly gained freedom.
('97', 470, 1, 8, 951246) I, therefore, say that controls must go.
('97', 470, 1, 9, 951287) If the Government says that decontrol will lead to starvation, then I shall say that Panchayat Raj has not been established, democracy has not come to us, that Ramarajya has not been established and it is for Ramarajya that I want to keep myself alive.
('97', 470, 1, 10, 951540) I shall say that those who are made free from controls should have self imposed controls on themselves and make others happy.
('97', 470, 1, 11, 951666) The civil servants in the Government may call me names.
('97', 470, 1, 12, 951722) They may say I have no right to interfere, that I have no experience of running a government, that afterwards it would be difficult to reimpose the controls and feed the people.
('97', 470, 1, 13, 951900) I shall say they are right.
('97', 470, 1, 14, 951928) I have never been in the civil service, I have never run a government, but I have moved among the millions.
('97', 470, 1, 15, 952036) I know their hearts.
('97', 470, 1, 16, 952057) I understand them.
('97', 470, 1, 17, 952076) Now about cloth.
('97', 470, 1, 18, 952093) About food you may say that we have not enough stock of it.
('97', 470, 1, 19, 952153) But nobody has yet said that we do not have enough cotton.
('97', 470, 1, 20, 952212) We have so much of it that we export it.
('97', 470, 1, 21, 952253) You will say we do not have enough mills.
('97', 470, 1, 22, 952295) I shall say the mills are in our homes.
('97', 470, 1, 23, 952335) They are in the homes of all the women sitting here.
('97', 470, 1, 24, 952388) Every one of you has been blessed with two hands.
('97', 470, 1, 25, 952438) If you want clothes on your back you should spin.
('97', 470, 1, 26, 952488) If you cannot, you may go naked.
('97', 470, 1, 27, 952521) We have a number of mills but if the production does not come up to the requirement we must resort to hand spinning and hand weaving.
('97', 470, 1, 28, 952655) Weaving is not difficult.
('97', 470, 1, 29, 952681) We have so many weavers in our country that we can have any amount of cloth woven, but some people have a delicate taste.
('97', 470, 1, 30, 952803) They will weave only mill yarn.
('97', 470, 1, 31, 952835) They cannot weave hand spun yarn.
('97', 470, 1, 32, 952869) If they start weaving hand spun yarn there is no need to go naked.
('97', 470, 1, 33, 952936) Then our beautiful country—the home of so many hundreds of millions who know their trade, who know how to produce cloth—cannot go naked.
('97', 470, 1, 34, 953073) Therefore control on cloth is the limit of ignorance and the sooner it is lifted the better.
('97', 470, 1, 35, 953166) So far as foodgrain is concerned the farmers and traders must declare that they produce and sell to meet the people’s needs, and they will not indulge in dishonest practices.
('97', 470, 1, 36, 953341) The farmers should understand that they have to grow crops not merely to feed themselves but to feed all.
('97', 470, 1, 37, 953447) We must produce one seer where we produced only a half.
('97', 470, 1, 38, 953503) But let us guide the people; let us
('97', 471, 0, 1, 953539) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 471, 1, 2, 953581) provide them incentive.
('97', 471, 1, 3, 953605) There is no need for anyone to go hungry or naked in India.
('97', 471, 1, 4, 953665) We have been denuded of our cloth because of our ignorance.
('97', 471, 1, 5, 953725) We do not produce as much food or as much milk as we need even though we have a large number of cattle.
('97', 471, 1, 6, 953829) What is this if not folly?

('97', 471, 4, 10, 953929) 417. A TALK 1
('97', 471, 5, 11, 953943) NEW DELHI, December 5, 1947
('97', 471, 6, 12, 953971) When someone has fever the doctor first seeks to rid him of the fever by giving a mixture.
('97', 471, 6, 13, 954062) The fever goes down.
('97', 471, 6, 14, 954083) But it will come back, for the disease has not been diagnosed and the cause of the fever has not been traced.
('97', 471, 6, 15, 954193) Similarly most people in the world today want an end to war, but wars continue.
('97', 471, 6, 16, 954273) If the causes of wars were discovered and justice done where justice was demanded, there would be no wars.
('97', 471, 6, 17, 954380) Today various groups of people have been pleading with the Government to ban cow slaughter.
('97', 471, 6, 18, 954472) I know that even beef eaters have asked for such a ban, but as soon as a cow goes dry people stop looking after her.
('97', 471, 6, 19, 954589) They do not ask that cows should be cared for.
('97', 471, 6, 20, 954636) They simply ask that cow slaughter should be stopped.
('97', 471, 6, 21, 954690) But if everyone looked after cows well and insisted that no one should eat beef, cow slaughter would stop by itself.
('97', 471, 6, 22, 954807) But beef eating goes on, the cows are neglected and yet the Government is asked to stop cow slaughter.
('97', 471, 6, 23, 954910) That would be making fun of the Government.
('97', 471, 6, 24, 954954) In the same way one must first look deeply into the causes of wars and seek ways to remove those causes.
('97', 471, 6, 25, 955059) Wars in a large measure are fought over economic issues.
('97', 471, 6, 26, 955116) If we give up selfishness and resolve to take the barest minimum for the satisfaction of our wants, there will be no occasion for wars.
('97', 471, 6, 27, 955252) Unless there is a complete transformation in our economy and our style of life, peace will elude us, however hard we may strive for it.
('97', 471, 6, 28, 955388) Europe and America want peace and yet they use their intellectual, technical and scientific resources for production of
('97', 471, 7, 29, 955508) 1 A friend accompanying Jawaharlal Nehru had asked Gandhiji how peace in the world was to be established.
('97', 472, 0, 1, 955614) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 473
('97', 472, 1, 2, 955664) nuclear weapons.
('97', 472, 1, 3, 955681) Therefore, while they express the wish that peace should reign in the world, they are busy inventing ways to disturb the peace and to destroy the world.
('97', 472, 1, 4, 955834) It does not occur to them to seek ways to restore peace and stop the possibility of wars.
('97', 472, 2, 5, 955924) [From Gujarati]
('97', 472, 3, 6, 955940) Dilhiman Gandhiji—II, pp.

('97', 473, 2, 3, 957077) APPENDIX I
('97', 473, 3, 4, 957088) NOTE ON GANDHIJI’S 78TH BIRTHDAY 1
('97', 473, 4, 5, 957123) The second of October 1947, was Gandhiji’s birthday—the last to be celebrated in his lifetime.
('97', 473, 4, 6, 957218) Members of his party came in the early morning to offer him their obeisances.
('97', 473, 4, 7, 957296) “Bapuji”, one of them remarked, “on our birthdays, it is we who touch the feet of other people and take their blessings but in your case it is other way about.
('97', 473, 4, 8, 957456) Is this fair?”
('97', 473, 5, 9, 957471) Gandhiji laughed : “The ways of Mahatmas are different!
('97', 473, 5, 10, 957527) It is not my fault.
('97', 473, 5, 11, 957547) You made me Mahatma, maybe a bogus one; so you must pay the penalty!”
('97', 473, 6, 12, 957617) He observed this birthday, as usual, by fasting, prayer and extra spinning.
('97', 473, 6, 13, 957693) The fast, he explained was for self purification, and the spinning a token of the renewal of his covenant to dedicate his being to the service of the lowliest and the least in God’s creation.
('97', 473, 6, 14, 957885) He had turned his birthday celebration into celebration of the rebirth of the spinning wheel.
('97', 473, 6, 15, 957979) It stood for non violence.
('97', 473, 6, 16, 958006) The symbol appeared to have been lost.
('97', 473, 6, 17, 958045) But he had not stopped the observance hoping that there might be at least a few scattered individuals true to the message of the wheel.
('97', 473, 6, 18, 958181) It was for their sake that he allowed the celebration to continue.
('97', 473, 7, 19, 958248) A small party of intimate friends was waiting for him when he entered his room after his bath at half past eight.
('97', 473, 7, 20, 958362) They included Pandit Nehru and the Sardar, G. D. Birla — his host — and all the members of the Birla family in Delhi.
('97', 473, 7, 21, 958480) Mirabehn had gaily decorated his seat by improvising in front of it an artistic cross, He Rama and the sacred syllable Om from flowers of variegated colours.
('97', 473, 7, 22, 958638) A short prayer was
('97', 473, 8, 23, 958657) held in which all joined.
('97', 473, 8, 24, 958683) It was followed by the singing of his favourite hymn “When I survey the wondrous Cross” and another devotional hymn of his choice in Hindi— He Govinda rakho sharan.
('97', 473, 9, 25, 958848) Visitors and friends continued to come all day to offer homage to the Father of the Nation.
('97', 473, 9, 26, 958940) So also came the members of the Diplomatic Corps, some of them with greetings from their respective Governments.
('97', 473, 9, 27, 959053) Lastly Lady Mountbatten arrived with a sheaf of letters and telegrams addressed to him.
('97', 473, 10, 28, 959141) His request to all was to pray that “either the present conflagration should end
('97', 473, 11, 29, 959222) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 2 10 1947.
('97', 474, 0, 1, 959268) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 475
('97', 474, 1, 2, 959318) or He should take me away.
('97', 474, 1, 3, 959345) I do not wish another birthday to overtake me in an India still in flames.”
('97', 474, 2, 4, 959421) “What sin must I have committed,” he remarked to the Sardar, “that He should have kept me alive to witness all these horrors?”
('97', 474, 3, 5, 959548) He seemed to be consumed by the feeling of helplessness in the face of the surrounding conflagration.
('97', 474, 3, 6, 959650) Recorded the Sardar’s daughter, Manibehn, mournfully that day in her journal : “His anguish was unbearable.
('97', 474, 3, 7, 959758) We had gone to him in elation; we returned home with a heavy heart.”
('97', 474, 4, 8, 959827) After the visitors had left, he had another spasm of coughing.
('97', 474, 4, 9, 959890) “I would prefer to quit this frame unless the all healing efficacy of His name fills me,” he murmured.
('97', 474, 4, 10, 959993) “The desire to live for 125 years has completely vanished as a result of this continued fratricide.
('97', 474, 4, 11, 960093) I do not want to be a helpless witness of it.”
('97', 474, 5, 12, 960140) “So from 125 years you have come down to zero,” someone put in.
('97', 474, 6, 13, 960204) “Yes, unless the conflagration ceases.” .
('97', 474, 7, 14, 960246) The All India Radio had arranged a special broadcast programme in observance of his birthday.
('97', 474, 7, 15, 960340) Would he not, for that once, listen to the special programme?
('97', 474, 7, 16, 960402) —he was asked.
('97', 474, 7, 17, 960417) “No,” he replied; he preferred rentio (spinningwheel) to radio.
('97', 474, 7, 18, 960481) The hum
('97', 474, 8, 19, 960489) of the spinning wheel was sweeter.
('97', 474, 8, 20, 960524) He heard in it the “still sad music of humanity”.
('97', 474, 9, 21, 960574) Gandhiji refused to release for publication any of the birthday messages — telegrams or letters—which had come from all parts of the world.
('97', 474, 9, 22, 960714) He had many beautiful messages from Muslim friends, too, but he felt that it was no time for their publication when the general public seemed to have ceased, for the time being at least, to believe in non violence and truth.
