('97', 475, 0, 1, 960983) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 475, 1, 2, 961025) APPENDIX II
('97', 475, 2, 3, 961037) A. I. C. C. RESOLUTION 1
('97', 475, 3, 4, 961062) (1) RIGHTS OF MINORITIES 2
('97', 475, 4, 5, 961089) 15 11 1947
('97', 475, 5, 6, 961100) The All India Congress Committee welcomes the elimination of foreign rule in India and the establishment of a free and independent State and a Government responsible to the people of the country.
('97', 475, 5, 7, 961296) The achievement of freedom is the culmination of the long struggle of the Indian National Congress and outcome of the sufferings and tribulations of the Indian people.
('97', 475, 5, 8, 961464) Freedom brings responsibility and new burdens and problems.
('97', 475, 6, 9, 961524) The freedom achieved was not the kind that the Congress had envisaged during its long history.
('97', 475, 6, 10, 961619) It has been accompanied by secession of parts of the country and disasters of unparalleled magnitude.
('97', 475, 6, 11, 961721) Hardly was free India born when grave crisis overtook it and events happened which have besmirched her fair name and brought death and desolation to vast numbers of innocent people in circumstances too tragic for words.
('97', 475, 6, 12, 961941) There have been arson and loot and murder on a mass scale in West Punjab, N. W. F. Province, Baluchistan, East Punjab and adjoining areas.
('97', 475, 6, 13, 962080) The Committee cannot find words strong enough to condemn these inhuman acts by whatever community perpetrated.
('97', 475, 6, 14, 962191) It extends its sympathy to all those who have been the innocent victims of this colossal tragedy.
('97', 475, 7, 15, 962289) At this moment of crisis, it is necessary that the Congress should declare its faith and policy in clear terms and that the people as well as the Government should follow that policy unswervingly.
('97', 475, 7, 16, 962486) Even though the Congress agreed to a division of the country in the hope, which has thus far proved vain, that thereby internal conflicts might cease, it has never accepted the theory that there are two or more nations in India.
('97', 475, 7, 17, 962715) It has firmly believed in the whole of India as a nation bound together by indissoluble cultural and historical links which had been further strengthened in the course of the national struggle for freedom.
('97', 475, 7, 18, 962921) It was on the basis of this faith that the Congress grew up as a national institution open to all Indians without difference of creed or religion.
('97', 475, 7, 19, 963068) India is a land of many religions and many races, and must remain so.
('97', 475, 7, 20, 963138) Nevertheless India has been and is a country with afundamental unity and the aim of the Congress has been to develop this great country as a whole as a democratic secular State where all citizens enjoy full rights and are equally entitled to the protection of the State, irrespective of the religion to
('97', 475, 8, 21, 963441) 1 Vide “Speech at Prayer Meeting”, 18 11 1947.
('97', 475, 9, 22, 963488) 2 According to Dilhiman Gandhiji, the draft of this was corrected by Gandhiji.
('97', 476, 0, 1, 963567) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 477
('97', 476, 1, 2, 963617) which they belong.
('97', 476, 1, 3, 963636) The Constituent Assembly has accepted this as the basic principle of the Constitution.
('97', 476, 1, 4, 963723) This lays on every Indian the obligation to honour it.
('97', 476, 2, 5, 963778) The Congress wants to assure the minorities in India that it will continue to protect, to the best of its ability, their citizen rights against aggression.
('97', 476, 2, 6, 963934) The Central Government, as well as the Provincial Governments must accordingly make every effort to create conditions wherein all minorities and all citizens have security and opportunity for progress.
('97', 476, 2, 7, 964136) All citizens have also on their part not only to share in the benefits of freedom but also shoulder the burdens and responsibility which accompany it, and must above all be loyal to India.
('97', 476, 3, 8, 964325) The All India Congress Committee calls upon all Congressmen and the people of India to adhere strictly to those well established principles of the Congress and not to allow themselves to be diverted into wrong channels by passion or prejudice or by the tragic events that have happened.
('97', 476, 3, 9, 964612) Real good and progress of India have yet to be achieved and this can only be done by adhering to the ideals and policy of the Congress and discarding and opposing all false doctrines which have done so much mischief to India and her people.
('97', 476, 4, 10, 964853) (2) REPATRIATION OF REFUGEES
('97', 476, 5, 11, 964882) 15 11 1947
('97', 476, 6, 12, 964893) The tragic events that have taken place in recent months in the Punjab and elsewhere have resulted in vast migrations of populations, and consequently in tremendous suffering to millions of people.
('97', 476, 6, 13, 965091) New problems of relief and rehabilitation have arisen of a magnitude which is unparalleled in history.
('97', 476, 6, 14, 965194) The Government of India have faced these problems with courage and determination.
('97', 476, 6, 15, 965276) Nevertheless it is necessary to state clearly what the national policy should be in dealing with these problems.
('97', 476, 7, 16, 965389) The A. I. C. C. has looked with disfavour on this large scale migration which brings suffering to millions, upsets the nation’s economy and does violence to the ideal which the Congress has held since its inception.
('97', 476, 7, 17, 965605) It is of opinion that these migrations should be discouraged and conditions should be created both in the Indian Dominion and in Pakistan for minorities to live in peace and security.
('97', 476, 7, 18, 965789) If such conditions are created the desire to migrate to another part of the country will disappear.
('97', 476, 7, 19, 965889) In the opinion of the Committee, it is wrong to coerce Hindu and Sikh inhabitants of Pakistan into leaving their homes and migrating to the Indian Union, and Muslims of the Indian Union into migrating to Pakistan.
('97', 476, 8, 20, 966103) While it is impossible to undo all that has been done, every effort should be made to enable the evacuees and refugees from either Dominion ultimately to return to their homes and to their original occupations under conditions of safety and security.
('97', 476, 8, 21, 966354) Those who have not left their homes already should be encouraged to stay there unless
('97', 477, 0, 1, 966440) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 477, 1, 2, 966482) they themselves desire to migrate, in which case facilities for migrating should be made available.
('97', 477, 1, 3, 966582) It is the duty of the Central Government of the Indian Union and the Government of Pakistan to negotiate on this basis and to create conditions which would enable the evacuees and refugees to return with safety.
('97', 477, 2, 4, 966794) In any event the policy to be followed in the Indian Union is to protect the minorities still residing there and to prevent their removal by force or by creating circumstances which compel evacuation.
('97', 477, 3, 5, 966995) During these disorders large numbers of women have been abducted on either side and there have been forcible conversions on a large scale.
('97', 477, 3, 6, 967134) No civilized people can recognize such conversions, and there is nothing more heinous than abduction of women.
('97', 477, 3, 7, 967245) Every effort, therefore, must be made to restore women to their original homes with the co operation of the Governments concerned.
('97', 477, 4, 8, 967376) The A. I. C. C. has noted with satisfaction the declarations made on behalf of the Governments of the two Dominions and East and West Punjab that forcible conversions will not be recognized and that they would co operate in the recovery of abducted women.
('97', 477, 5, 9, 967632) Such being the policy of the Congress, the refugees in the Indian Union are entitled to every care and attention from the authorities and the people within the Union as long as they have to remain there.
('97', 477, 5, 10, 967836) They are not to be regarded as interlopers grudgingly placed upon charity.
('97', 477, 5, 11, 967911) They will have the same rights and be under the same obligations as any other citizen.
('97', 477, 5, 12, 967998) Where they are living in camps they will be expected to render some social service in co operation with fellow refugees, subject to the rules framed for the good government of the camp.
('97', 477, 5, 13, 968184) Sanitary and other services should be performed by the inmates of the camps under instructions from those fitted for the work and who will themselves take part in these services.
('97', 477, 5, 14, 968363) Refugees should be engaged in productive work as far as possible on a co operative basis.
('97', 477, 6, 15, 968453) Refugees from West Punjab shall as a rule be accommodated in East Punjab.
('97', 477, 6, 16, 968527) Those from the other parts of Pakistan shall be accommodated in places that the Central Government, in co operation with the Provincial Governments, may consider more suitable.
('97', 477, 6, 17, 968704) Those from a particular locality should, as far as possible, be kept together.
('97', 477, 7, 18, 968783) In this task the Provincial Governments should offer their full co operation and should take in and make suitable arrangements for as many refugees as they can.
('97', 477, 8, 19, 968944) No house, not vacated willingly by a Muslim, shall be used for the accommodation of refugees, except by proper legal authority.
('97', 477, 9, 20, 969072) The movement of refugees, which is already taking place by train, convoy or otherwise, should be regulated in accordance with the policy laid down above and no one should be sent away unless he expresses his desire to migrate.
('97', 477, 10, 21, 969299) This principle should apply also to the States which have acceded to the Indian
('97', 478, 0, 1, 969379) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 479
('97', 478, 1, 2, 969429) Union and from which large numbers of Muslims have been evacuated or driven out.
('97', 478, 2, 3, 969510) The A. I. C. C. trusts that the Central Government of the Indian Union, the East Punjab and West Bengal Governments, and the Governments of the States affected by these migrations, will give effect to the policy indicated above and will issue directions to all their officers to act strictly in accordance with it.
('97', 478, 3, 4, 969825) (3) STATES
('97', 478, 4, 5, 969836) 15 11 1947
('97', 478, 5, 6, 969847) In view of the fact that in a number of States, people’s organizations, instead of rising in power and influence as a result of freedom, are being suppressed and prevented from functioning; and further in view of the fact that Rulers in Punjab and some parts of Rajputana and Central India and in the South Indian States have shown an unpatriotic attitude and have betrayed a woeful lack of imagination and have been party to the liquidation of the Muslim and Hindu population by inhuman means, it becomes necessary to reiterate in unequivocal language the policy of the Congress in regard to the States.
('97', 478, 6, 7, 970452) Whatever may be the legal implications of accession and lapse of British Paramountcy, the moral result of the independence of India was undoubtedly the establishment and recognition of the power of the people as distinguished from that of Princes and feudal or other interests hostile to natural popular aspirations.
('97', 478, 6, 8, 970769) This power, the Congress is determined to uphold at any cost.
('97', 478, 6, 9, 970831) Therefore, all such interests and specially the Princes should know that the Congress cannot uphold them unless they are demonstrably in favour of regarding the voice of the people as the supreme law.
('97', 478, 6, 10, 971032) In such a democratic State the individual who wants to assert himself against the popular will cannot count, no matter how powerful he may be.
('97', 478, 7, 11, 971175) This meeting of the A. I. C. C. therefore hopes that the Princes will read the signs of the times and co operate with the people, and those who have acted in a contrary spirit will retrace their steps and revise their undemocratic conduct and function through democratic organizations expressing the people’s will.
('97', 478, 7, 12, 971490) This they can best do by seeking the association and advice of the A. I. S. P. C. which has been endeavouring to act on behalf of the people of States.
('97', 478, 8, 13, 971642) (4) COMMUNAL ORGANIZATIONS
('97', 478, 9, 14, 971669) 16 11 1947
('97', 478, 10, 15, 971680) The A. I. C. C. has noted with regret that communal organizations like the Hindu Mahasabha, the Muslim League and the Akali Party have sought to promote their respective interests based on so called religious considerations in conflict with the national interest.
('97', 478, 10, 16, 971944) The national interest must mean and include a healthy synthesis of all interests based not on religious but political, social, material and moral grounds.
('97', 478, 10, 17, 972099) Political activities must accordingly be conducted by political organizations which are based on political and economic policies and which are open to members of all communities.
('97', 479, 0, 1, 972278) 480 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 479, 1, 2, 972320) (5) PRIVATE ARMIES
('97', 479, 2, 3, 972339) 16 11 1947
('97', 479, 3, 4, 972350) The All India Congress Committee has noted with regret that there is a growing desire on the part of some organizations to build up private armies.
('97', 479, 3, 5, 972498) Any such development is dangerous for the safety of the State and for the growth of corporate life in the nation.
('97', 479, 3, 6, 972612) The State alone should have its defence forces or police or home guards or recognized armed volunteer force.
('97', 479, 3, 7, 972721) The activities of the Muslim National Guards, the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh and the Akali Volunteers and such other organizations, in so far as they represent an endeavour to bring into being private armies, must be regarded as a menace to the hard won freedom of the country.
('97', 479, 3, 8, 973000) The A. I. C. C. therefore appeals to all these organizations to discontinue such activities and the Central and Provincial Governments to take necessary steps in this behalf.
('97', 479, 4, 9, 973175) (6) CONTROLS
('97', 479, 5, 10, 973188) 16 11 1947
('97', 479, 6, 11, 973199) The A. I. C. C. has been alarmed at the disturbance of normal life by the various controls, specially in regard to foodstuffs and clothing.
('97', 479, 6, 12, 973339) These have promoted black marketing, hoarding, corruption and other evils.
('97', 479, 6, 13, 973414) They have interfered with the process of self reliance and arrested the incentive to production specially in the matter of growing more foodstuffs and the manufacture of hand spun and hand woven khadi in the thousands of villages in India.
('97', 479, 6, 14, 973654) The Committee is, therefore, of opinion that the Central and Provincial Governments should give urgent consideration to the problem of decontrol as early as possible without detriment to the public good.
('97', 479, 7, 15, 973858) (7) THE CONGRESS CONSTITUTION
('97', 479, 8, 16, 973888) 16 11 1947
('97', 479, 9, 17, 973899) As the goal of complete independence from foreign domination has been achieved and in view of the new role the Congress organization will have to play under the changed circumstances, the A. I. C. C. appoints the following Committee to revise the present Congress Constitution, including the objective as contained in Article I and to submit the revised draft Constitution prepared by it to a special session of the All India Congress Committee, to be convened for the purpose, notlater than the end of January, 1948 and pending the final approval of such a Constitution by the A. I. C. C. to postpone all Congress elections under the present Constitution.
('97', 479, 10, 18, 974556) Shri R. R. Diwakar, Shri P. D. Tandon, Acharya Narendra Deo, Shri S. K. Patil, Dr. Pattabhi Sitaramayya, Shri Surendra Mohan Ghosh and Acharya Jugal Ksihore.
('97', 479, 11, 19, 974714) (8) CONGRESS OBJECTIVES
('97', 479, 12, 20, 974738) 16 11 1947
('97', 479, 13, 21, 974749) Political independence having been achieved, the Congress must address itself to the next great task, namely, the establishment of real democracy in the country and
('97', 480, 0, 1, 974914) VOL. 97 : 27 SEPTEMBER, 1947 5 DECEMBER, 1947 481
('97', 480, 1, 2, 974964) a society based on social justice and equality.
('97', 480, 1, 3, 975012) Such a society must provide every man and woman with equality of opportunity and freedom to work for the unfettered development of his or her personality.
('97', 480, 1, 4, 975167) This can only be realized when democracy extends from the political to the social and the economic spheres.
('97', 480, 2, 5, 975275) Democracy in the modern age necessitates planned central direction as well as decentralization of political and economic power, in so far as this is compatible with the safety of the State, with efficient production and the cultural progress of the community as a whole.
('97', 480, 2, 6, 975546) The smallest territorial unit should be able to exercise effective control over its corporate life by means of a popularly elected Panchayat.
('97', 480, 2, 7, 975688) In so far as it is possible, national and regional economic self sufficiency in the essentials of life should be aimed at.
('97', 480, 2, 8, 975811) In the case of industries, which in their nature must be run on a large scale and on centralized basis, they should belong to the community, and they should be so organized that workers become not only co sharers in the profits but are also increasingly associated with the management and administration of the industry.
('97', 480, 3, 9, 976132) Land, with its mineral resources, and all other means of production as well as distribution and exchange must belong to and be regulated by the community in its own interest.
('97', 480, 4, 10, 976307) Our aim should be to evolve a political system which will combine efficiency of administration with individual liberty and an economic structure which will yield maximum production without the creation of private monopolies and the concentration of wealth and which will create a proper balance between urban and rural economies.
('97', 480, 4, 11, 976637) Such a social structure can provide an alternative to the acquisitive economy of private capitalism and the regimentation of a totalitarian State.
('97', 480, 5, 12, 976784) With a view to drawing up the economic programme for the Congress in accordance with the above mentioned principles, and the election manifesto of the Congress dated December 19th, 1945, the following Committee is appointed:
('97', 480, 6, 13, 977009) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Maulana Abul Kalam Azad, Shri Jaiprakash Narain, Prof.
('97', 480, 6, 14, 977089) N. G. Ranga, Shri Gulzari Lal Nanda, Shri J. C. Kumarappa, Shri Achyut Patwardhan, Shri Shankarrao Deo—with powers to co opt.
('97', 480, 8, 15, 977215) 17 11 1947
('97', 480, 9, 16, 977226) This Committee would have liked Acharya J. B. Kripalani to continue as President of the Indian National Congress till the next elections in the normal course but as he has expressed his inability to reconsider his resignation, it regretfully accepts it.
('97', 480, 10, 17, 977480) The Committee places on record its appreciation of the services rendered by him both before and during the time he has held the office as President.
('97', 480, 11, 18, 977629) Harija n, 23 11 1947
('97', 481, 0, 1, 977650) 482 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('97', 481, 1, 2, 977692) APPENDIX III
('97', 481, 2, 3, 977705) EXTRACT FROM LETTER FROM PYARELAL 1
('97', 481, 3, 4, 977741) This means that unless we can accept partition as unreservedly as once you accepted the British Empire, even to the length of teaching your children to sing ‘God save the King’ in the approved English tune, we cannot stay in Pakistan without being guilty of ‘disloyalty’ to the State.
('97', 481, 3, 5, 978026) How can then those who cannot in all conscience accept partition as something good or irrevocable for all time have any place in Pakistan?
('97', 481, 4, 6, 978165) Feverish preparations are going on to re enact Kashmir on a small scale in Tripura State.
('97', 481, 4, 7, 978255) Pakistan officials are deeply involved in it.
('97', 481, 4, 8, 978301) Some of them are even said to be carrying on a ‘palace intrigue’ in Tripura State to this end.
('97', 481, 4, 9, 978396) Three or four days ago, speeches were delivered at a public meeting in Comilla by Muslims exhorting the people to launch an action against Tripura authorities.
('97', 481, 4, 10, 978556) Hindu subjects of Pakistan were challenged to prove their ‘loyalty’ by joining in that meritorious action for the extension of Pakistan’s boundaries.
('97', 481, 4, 11, 978706) What should be the attitude of the Hindus?
('97', 481, 4, 12, 978749) What should the Hindu refugees from Noakhali, domiciled in Agartala (capital of Tripura) do?
('97', 481, 4, 13, 978842) What advice should we give to those who seek our counsel?
('97', 481, 5, 14, 978900) In one sense, however, the situation in Noakhali may now be said to be normal.
('97', 481, 5, 15, 978979) The policy of the Government is no more to harass or to persecute the Hindus.
('97', 481, 5, 16, 979057) But the complexion of the administration is communal and their behaviour openly partisan.
('97', 481, 5, 17, 979147) Discrimination and a steady squeeze in the name of the ‘Islamic State’ are going on and corruption, inefficiency and lack of discipline in all branches of administration are endemic.
('97', 481, 5, 18, 979330) Before the partition the Central Government exercised, at least in name, some check.
('97', 481, 5, 19, 979415) Now even that is gone.
('97', 481, 5, 20, 979438) For the rest unless war actually breaks out between the two Dominions, there is no imminent danger of any large scale disturbance taking place.
('97', 481, 5, 21, 979582) In other words, peace in East Bengal henceforth will depend more on the overall situation vis a vis the two Dominions than on purely local conditions.
('97', 481, 6, 22, 979733) Mahatm a Gandhi —The Last Phase, Vol. II, pp.
('97', 481, 7, 23, 979779) 1 Vide “Letter to Pyarelal”, after 15 11 1947.
